children.definition: tape or cord used for ligatures, etc., Archig. ap. Orib. 47.13.7, Heraclas ib. 48.1.1. (From κείρεσθαι or καῖρος acc. to Sch. Orib. 4p.537D.; cf. κειρία.)
timely, ἀπαγγελίαι IG 3.769.
appropriate to certain times or seasons, seasonable, ἄνθη PMag.Leid.W. 24.1.

children.label: b
children.definition: belonging to the καιρός or chronocratory, κ. χρόνοι Ἀφροδίτης Nech. ap. Vett.Val. 289.37.

children.label: c
children.definition: ὧραι κ. hours of the kind that vary in length with the season, opp. ἰσημεριναί, Ptol. Alm. 4.11, 7.3, Tetr. 76.
temporal, Eust. 17.3.
καιρικαὶ βαφαί, dub. sens. in Zos.Alch. p.246B., cf. p.228, 239, al.
Macho ap. Ath. 13.581b, cf. Al. Le. 16.21; -ώτερος οἶνος PElor. 143.2 (iii A. D.).
use a word appropriately, Eust. 909.17 ( Pass.).

definition: καίριος, α, ον, also ος, ον Thgn. 341, A. Ch. 1064, S. Ph. 637, Luc. Nigr. 35:

children.label: I
children.definition: Hom. always of Place, in or at the right place, hence of parts of the body, καίριον a vital part, Il. 8.84, 326; ἐν καιρίῳ 4.185; ὁ αὐχήν ἐστι τῶν καιρίων X. Eq. 12.2, cf. 8 ( Sup.); of wounds, mortal, καιρίῃ (sc. πληγῇ) τετύφθαι Hdt. 3.64; πέπληγμαι καιρίαν πληγήν A. Ag. 1343; καιρίας πληγῆς τυχεῖν ib. 1292, cf. X. Cyr. 5.4.5; καιρίας (v.l. -ίους) σφαγάς E. Ph. 1431; ἔχειν τὴν καταφορὰν κ. Plb. 2.33.3; but also, grave, serious, νουσήματα, τρώματα, Hp. Morb. 1.5: generally, καιριωτάτης τετευχέναι χώρας Theol.Ar. 44.

children.label: II
children.definition: in season, timely, εὕρισκε ταῦτα καιριώτατα εἶναι Hdt. 1.125, cf. Emp. 111.6; χρὴ λέγειν τὰ κ. A. Th. 1, cf. Ch. 582; καίριοι συμφοραί ib. 1064; εἴ τι κ. λέγει S. Ant. 724; δρᾶν, φρονεῖν τὰ κ., Id. Aj. 120, El. 228 (lyr.); καίριος σπουδή Id. Ph. 637; -ωτέρα βουλή E. Heracl. 471; κ. ἐνθύμημα X. HG 4.5.4; τὸ ἀεὶ κ. Id. Cyr. 4.2.12, etc.; πρὸς τὸ κ., = καιρίως, S. Ph. 525; critical, αὐτὰ τὰ κ. ἔχων ἑκκαίδεκα (sc. ἔτη) AP 12.22 ( Scyth.); agreeing with the subject, καιρίαν δʼ ἡμῖν ὁρῶ στείχουσαν Ἰοκάστην coming at the right time, S. OT 631; καίριος ἤλυθες E. El. 598; καιρία (Dind. for καὶ δορία) πτώσιμος falling at the exact or fatal moment, A. Ag. 1122 (lyr.); τὰ κ. timely circumstances, opportunities, Th. 4.10; emergencies, D.C. Fr. 70.8.
lasting but for a season, AP 12.224 ( Strato).

children.label: III
children.definition: chief, principal, τὰ καιριώτατα τῶν κλημάτων Thphr. CP 3.15.4, cf. 6.4.2.

children.label: IV
children.definition: Adv. -ρίως in season, seasonably, κ. εἰρημένον A. Ag. 1372; σκοπεῖν E. Rh. 339: Comp. -ωτέρως X. Cyr. 4.5.49.
mortally, οὐτασμένος A. Ag. 1344, cf. Plb. 2.69.2.
carpet-weaver, Judeich Altertümer von Hierapolis 342 (pl.).
guide in season, εἰς τέχνην ὄρνιν ἐκαιρονόμεις ( -μάνεις cod.) AP 9.272 ( Bianor).

definition: καιροπτία or καιροπτ-εία, ἡ, as if from *καιρόπτης, διὰ καιροπτείας by

children.definition: watching their opportunity, J. Ap. 2.11.

due measure, proportion, fitness (not in Hom.), καιρὸς δʼ ἐπὶ πᾶσιν ἄριστος (which became a prov.) Hes. Op. 694, Thgn. 401; κ. παντὸς ἔχει κορυφάν Pi. P. 9.78; κ. Χάριτος A. Ag. 787 (anap.) (cf. ὑποκάμπτω II); εἰ ὁ κ. ἦν σαφής the distinction, the point, E. Hipp. 386; ἡ ἀπορία ἔχει τινὰ κ. has some point or importance, Arist. Metaph. 1043b25; καιροῦ πέρα beyond measure, unduly, A. Pr. 507; μείζων τοῦ κ. γαστήρ X. Smp. 2.19; καιροῦ μεῖζον E. Fr. 626 codd.; προσωτέρω or πορρωτέρω τοῦ κ., X. An. 4.3.34, HG 7.5.13; ὀξύτερα τοῦ κ. Pl. Plt. 307b; νωθεστέρα τοῦ κ. ib. 310e; ὑπερβάλλων τῇ φιλοτιμίᾳ τὸν κ. Plu. Ages. 8, cf. Hp. Loc.Hom. 44.

children.label: II
children.definition: vital part of the body (cf. καίριος I), ἐς καιρὸν τυπείς E. Andr. 1120.

children.label: III
children.definition: exact or critical time, season, opportunity, χρόνου κ. S. El. 1292: usu. alone, κ. [ ἐστιν] ἐν ᾧ χρόνος οὐ πολὺς κτλ. Hp. Praec. 1, cf. Chrysipp. et Archig. ap. Daremberg Notices et extr. des MSS. médicaux 1p.200; κ. ὀξύς Hp. Aph. 1.1; κ. πρὸς ἀνθρώπων βραχὺ μέτρον ἔχει ‘time and tide wait for no man’, Pi. P. 4.286; κ. ὄλβου, = καίριος ὄλβος, Id. N. 7.58; δηλοῦν, ὅ τι περ δύναται κ. Ar. Ec. 576 codd. (sed leg. δύνασαι) ; τίνα κ. τοῦ παρόντος βελτίω ζητεῖτε; D. 3.16; κ. δόσιος for giving, Hp. Acut. 20; κ. τοῦ ποτισμοῦ, τῆς τρύγης, BGU 1003.12 (iii B. C.), PStrassb. 1.8 (V A.D.); τὰ ἐκ τοῦ κ. προγινόμενα Plb. 6.32.3; καιρὸν παριέναι to let the time go by, Th. 4.27 (so in pl., τοὺς κ. παριέναι Pl. R. 374c; τοὺς κ. ὑφαιρεῖσθαι Aeschin. 3.66); κ. τῶν πραγμάτων τοῖς ἐναντίοις καθυφιέναι καὶ προδοῦναι D. 19.6; καιροῦ ( τοῦ κ.) τυχεῖν E. Hec. 593, Pl. Lg. 687a, Men. Mon. 281; καιρὸν εἰληφέναι Lys. 13.6 (but καιρὸς ἐλάμβανε Th. 2.34; cf. καιροῦ διδόντος Lib. Or. 45.7); καιροῦ λαβέσθαι Luc. Tim. 13; καιρὸν ἁρπάσαι Plu. Phil. 15; κ. τηρεῖν Arist. Rh. 1382b11; καιρῷ χρήσασθαι Plu. Pyrrh. 7; καιρῷ χειμῶνος ξυλλαβέσθαι co-operate with the occurrence of a storm, Pl. Lg. 709c; ἔχει κ. τι it happens in season, Th. 1.42, etc.; κ. ἔχειν τοῦ εὖ οἰκεῖν to be the chief cause of . ., Pl. R. 421a; ὑμέας καιρός ἐστι προβοηθῆσαι Hdt. 8.144, cf. A. Pr. 523, etc.; νῦν κ. ἔρδειν S. El. 1368: sts. c. Art., ἀλλʼ ἔσθʼ ὁ κ . . . ξένους . . τυγχάνειν τὰ πρόσφορα A. Ch. 710; ὁ κ. ἐστι μὴ μέλλειν ἔτι Ar. Th. 661, cf. Pl. 255.

data.quote: κ. τῶν πραγμάτων τοῖς ἐναντίοις καθυφιέναι καὶ προδοῦναι
ἀλλʼ ἔσθʼ ὁ κ . . . ξένους . . τυγχάνειν τὰ πρόσφορα
ὁ κ. ἐστι μὴ μέλλειν ἔτι

children.label: b
children.definition: ἐς καιρόν in season, Hdt. 7.144, E. Tr. 744, etc.; ἐς κ. ἐπείγεσθαι Hdt. 4.139; ἐς αὐτὸν κ. S. Aj. 1168; εἰς δέοντα κ. Men. Sam. 294; ἐν καιρῷ A. Pr. 381, Th. 4.59, etc.; ἐν κ. τινί Pl. Cri. 44a; ἐπὶ καιροῦ D. 19.258, 20.90, etc.; κατὰ καιρόν Pi. I. 2.22; ὥς οἱ κατὰ κ. ἦν Hdt. 1.30 (but also οἱ κατὰ κ. ἡγεμόνες in office at the time, BGU 15.10 (ii A. D.), etc.); παρὰ τῷ ἐντυχόντι αἰεὶ καὶ λόγου καὶ ἔργου κ. Th. 2.43; πρὸς καιρόν S. Aj. 38, Tr. 59, etc.; σὺν καιρῷ Plb. 2.38.7: without Preps., καιρῷ S. OT 1516; καιρόν, abs., S. Aj. 34, E. Fr. 495.9 (in Comp. form καιρότερον, Achae. 49); κ. γὰρ οὐδὲν ἦλθες E. Hel. 479; opp. ἀπὸ καιροῦ out of season, Pl. Tht. 187e; ἄνευ καιροῦ Id. Ep. 339d; παρὰ καιρόν Pi. O. 8.24, E. IA 800 (lyr.), Pl. Plt. 277a; πρὸ καιροῦ prematurely, A. Ag. 365 (anap.); ἐπὶ καιροῦ also means on the spur of the moment, ἐπὶ κ. λέγειν Plu. Dem. 8, cf. Art. 5; ἐξενεγκεῖν πόλεμον Id. Ant. 6.

season, πᾶσιν καιροῖς at all seasons of the year, IG 14.1018, cf. LXX Ge. 1.14, Ph. 1.13, Porph. ap. Eus. PE 3.11; κ. ἔτους, later Gr. for Att. ὥρα ἔτους, acc. to Moer. 424; time of day, Philostr. VA 6.14.

children.label: b
children.definition: critical times, periodic states, καιροὶ σωμάτων Arist. Pol. 1335a41.

time, period, κατὰ τὸν κ. τοῦτον Plb. 27.1.7; κατʼ ἐκεῖνο καιροῦ Conon 3, al.: more freq. in pl., κατὰ τούτους τοὺς κ. Arist. Ath. 23.2, al., cf. Plb. 2.39.1; τὰ κατὰ καιρούς chronological sequence of events, Id. 5.33.5; ἐν τοῖς πάλαι, ἐντοῖς μεταξὺ κ., Phld. Rh. 1.28,363 S.

οἱ καιροί the times, i.e. the state of affairs, freq. in bad sense, ἐν τοῖς μεγίστοις κ. at the most critical times, X. HG 6.5.33, cf. D. 20.44; περιστάντων τῇ πόλει κ. δυσκόλων IG 2(2).682.33, etc.: also in sg., X. An. 3.1.44, D. 17.9; ὁ ἔσχατος κ. extreme danger, Plb. 29.27.12, etc.; καιρῷ δουλεύειν AP 9.441 ( Pall.).

children.label: IV
children.definition: advantage, profit, τινος of or from a thing, Pi. O. 2.54, P. 1.57; εἴ τοι ἐς κ. ἔσται ταῦτα τελεόμενα to his advantage, Hdt. 1.206; ἐπὶ σῷ κ. S. Ph. 151 (lyr.); τίνα κ. με διδάσκεις; A. Supp. 1060 (lyr.); τί σοι καιρὸς . . καταλείβειν; what avails it . .? E. Andr. 131 (lyr.); τίνος εἵνεκα καιροῦ; D. 23.182; οὗ κ. εἴη where it was convenient or advantageous, Th. 4.54; ᾗ κ. ἦν ib. 90; χωρίον μετὰ μεγίστων κ. οἰκειοῦταί τε καὶ πολεμοῦται with the greatest odds, the most critical results, Id. 1.36.

children.label: V
children.definition: Pythag. name for seven, Theol.Ar. 44.

definition: καῖρος, ὁ (on the accent v. Eust. 907.13),

children.definition: row of thrums in the loom, to which the threads of the warp are attached, ravel, Ael.Dion. Fr. 400, Phot.:—hence καιρ-όω, make fast these threads:
act of fastening them, Poll. 7.33, Hsch.:
Ael.Dion. l.c.; of the web so fastened, Call. Fr. 295:
woman-weaver, Call. Fr. 356, Hsch.

close-woven, only in gen. pl. fem., καιροσέων ὀθονέων ἀπολείβεται ὑγρὸν ἔλαιον Od. 7.107. (Archaic spelling of καιρουσσέων (trisyll.), Ion. gen. pl. of καιρόεις, like Τειχιόσης for Τειχιούσσης in SIG 3d ( Milet., vi B.C.).)
Hdn. Epim. 63; prob. (for καιρῷ σκόπει) in Men. Mon. 307.
close-woven, ὕφασμα Hermipp. 5.

observe the seasons of change, D.S. 19.16, cf. 13.22: generally, lie in wait for, τινὰς ἀσχολουμένους PAmh. 2.35.8 (ii B. C.), cf. UPZ 19.26 (ii B. C.):— also in Med., -τηρησάμενός με ἐξερχόμενον BGU 909.6 (iv A. D.):
lover or observer of times, epith. of an astrologer, Vett.Val. 271.25.

watch for the right time, c. acc., τὴν πόλιν D. 23.173, Hyp. Phil. 8; τὴν χρῆσιν Arist. Pol. 1337b41; ἔχθραν παλαιάν Olymp.Hist. p.460 D.: abs., App. Pun. 88, Mith. 70; also, attend on, Luc. Abd. 16:— Pass., καιροφυλακεῖται Metrod. Fr. 60.

definition: καιρόω, καίρωμα, καίρωσις, καιρωστίς or καιρωσ-τρίς, v. καῖρος.
Καῖσαρ, ᾰρος, ὁ, (said to be Punic, = elephant, Lyd. Mens. 4.102)

children.definition: Caesar, a cognomen of the Gens Julia; esp. of Julius Caesar, D.S. 5.22, Str. 4.5.3, etc.; Κ. ὁ θεός prob. in OGI 767.5; also of Augustus, ib. 458.9 (9 B.C.), Nic.Dam. Vit.Caes. tit., etc.; ὁ νεὸς Κ., opp. ὁ πρεσβύτερος Κ., ib. 6; in general, the Emperor, OGI 473.8, etc.; Καίσαρος ἀπελεύθερος ib. 629.90, etc.; Πρῖμος Καίσαρος, i. e. P. the Emperorʼs slave, Wilcken Chr. 112.4; ἀπόδοτε τὰ Καίσαρος Καίσαρι Ev.Luc. 20.25: pl., οἱ Καίσαρες OGI 516.21: as title of the designated successor, Καίσαρα ἀποδεικνύει Hdn. 2.15.3, etc.; name of month in the province of Asia, OGI 458.54, etc.:—hence Καισάρειος, ον, of, belonging to Caesar, οἱ Κ. his household or officials, POxy. 477.5 (ii A. D.), D.C. 52.24, al.; οἶκος Κ., hall in Herod the Greatʼs palace, J. BJ 1.21.1; τὸ Κ. temple of Julius Caesar at Alexandria, Str. 17.1.9: Καισάρεια ( Καισάρ-ηα), τά, games in honour of Gaius Caesar at Cos, SIG 1065.9 ( Cos); at Corinth and elsewhere, IG 7.1856 ( Thespiae), etc.: Καισάρειος, or Καισάρ-ιος, ὁ (sc. μήν), name of month in Egypt and elsewhere, POxy. 45.17 (i A. D.), Hemerolog.Flor., etc.:—also Καισαρεών, ῶνος, ὁ, Rev.Et. Gr. 19.268 ( Κεσ-, Aphrodisias):
play the Caesar, D.C. 66.8:

definition: Καισαριανοί, οἱ, the Caesarian party, App. BC 3.91:—also, = Καισάρειοι, PGnom. 241 (ii A. D.): -->
Καισαριασταί, οἱ, worshippers of Caesar, IGRom. 4.1348 ( Mostene). -->
καισάραι περικεφαλαῖαι, Hsch. καισεκπρώπιον· δρέπανον, ξηροκόπιον, Id.
καιτάεις, f.l. for καιετάεις in Sch. Od. 4.1.

children.definition: and indeed, and further, freq. in Hom. with one or more words between, Il. 1.426, al.; καὶ σύ τοι E. Med. 344; καὶ τἆλλά τοι X. Cyr. 7.3.10: once in Hom. as one word, Il. 13.267.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hom. usu., and yet, to mark an objection introduced by the speaker himself, freq. in Rhetorical questions, καίτοι τί φημι; A. Pr. 101; κ. τί φωνῶ; S. OC 1132, cf. Isoc. 4.99, etc.: without a question, κ. φύγοιμʼ ἄν E. Cyc. 480; κ. καὶ τοῦτο . . D. 4.12, 18.122: strengthd., καίτοι γʼ Ar. Ach. 611, E. Fr. 953.10, X. Mem. 1.2.3, Ph. 1.274, etc.: mostly separated, καίτοι . . γε E. Or. 77, Ar. Ra. 43, X. Mem. 3.12.7, etc. ( καίτοι is f.l. in A. Eu. 849); so καίτοι περ v.l. in Hdt. 8.53.

children.label: III
children.definition: Simon. 5.9, Ar. Ec. 159, Pl. R. 511d, Plb. 22.8.13, Phld. Ir. p.22 W., Luc. Alex. 3: once in the Att. Oratt., Lys. 31.34; also καίτοι γε διαχλευάζων Pl. Ax. 364b.

definition: καίτρεαι ὅπλα Ἰβηρικά· οἱ δὲ κυρτίας, Hsch. (Cf. Lat. caetra.)

children.definition: sparrow, PLond. 1821.162 (fort. κέπφος).

definition: καίω, Att. κάω [ᾱ], impf. ἔκαιον Od. 9.553, Att. ἔκᾱον, Ep. καῖον Il. 21.343: fut. καύσω X. Cyr. 5.4.21, ( ἐπι-) Pl.Com. 186.4, ( κατα-) Ar. Lys. 1218; also καύσομαι Id. Pl. 1054: aor. 1 ἔκαυσα Id. Pax 1088, Th. 7.80 (bis), Pl. Grg. 456b, etc.; Ep. ἔκηα (certain Act. and Med. forms have κει- in codd. of Hom., v. infr.), ἔκηα Il. 1.40, al.; 3 sg. ἔκηε ( ν) 22.170, 24.34, al.; unaugm. κῆεν 21.349; 3 pl. ἔκηαν (v.l. ἔκειαν) Od. 22.336; imper. κεῖον 21.176 codd.; 1 pl. subj. κείομεν Il. 7.333 ( κατα-), 377, 396 (better attested than κήομεν); opt. κήαι, κήαιεν, 21.336, 24.38; inf. κῆαι Od. 15.97 (v.l. κεῖαι) , κατα-κῆαι 10.533, 11.46, κακκῆαι ib. 74 (v.l. κακκεῖαι); part. κείαντες 9.231, 13.26, Att. κέαντες A. Ag. 849, S. El. 757, ( ἐκ-) E. Rh. 97, ἐκκέας Ar. Pax 1133 (lyr.), ἐγκέαντι IG 1(2).374.96, 261: pf. κέκαυκα ( κατα-, προσ-) X. HG 6.5.37, Alex. 124.3:— Med., aor. 1 ἐκαυσάμην ( ἀν-) Hdt. 1.202, 8.19; Ep. κείαντο, κειάμενοι, Il. 9.88, 234; κειάμενος Od. 16.2, 23.51:— Pass., fut. καυθήσομαι Hp. Nat.Mul. 107, ( κατα-, ἐκ-) Ar. Nu. 1505, Pl. R. 362a; late κᾰήσομαι 1 Ep.Cor. 3.15: aor. 1 ἐκαύθην Hp. Epid. 4.4, Int. 28, ( κατ-) Hdt. 1.19, Th. 3.74; Ep. and Ion. aor. 2 ἐκάην [ᾰ] Il. 9.212 ( κατ-), Od. 12.13, ( δί-) Hp. Loc.Hom. 40, ( κατ-) Hdt. 2.180; inf. καήμεναι Il. 13.210, καῆναι Parth. 9.8: pf. κέκαυμαι E. Cyc. 457, Th. 4.34, etc., κέκαυσμαι Hp. Int. 28; inf. κεκαῦσθαι Arist. Mete. 343a9. (From κᾰϝ-yω.)

children.label: I
children.definition: kindle, πυρὰ πολλά Il. 9.77; πῦρ κείαντες Od. 9.231; πῦρ κῆαι 15.97, etc.:— Med., πῦρ κείαντο they lighted them a fire, Il. 9.88, cf. 234, Od. 16.2:— Pass., to be lighted, burn, πυραὶ νεκύων καίοντο Il. 1.52; θεείου καιομένοιο 8.135; καιομένοιο πυρός 19.376, cf. Hdt. 1.86, Ar. V. 1372, etc.; φῶς πυρὸς καόμενον Pl. R. 514b; αἱ φλόγες αἱ καιόμεναι . . περὶ τὸν οὐρανόν the meteors which blaze, Arist. Mete. 341b2; of ore, to be smelted, Id. HA 552b10.

children.label: II
children.definition: set on fire, burn, μηρία, ὀστέα, Od. 9.553, Hes. Th. 557; νεκρούς Il. 21.343; δένδρεα ib. 338:— Pass., νηυσὶν καιομένῃσιν 9.602.
make hot, of the sun, ἀνθρώπους Hdt. 3.104: abs., ibid., Pl. Cra. 413b; [ χείμαρρος] ἠελίῳ κεκαυμένος smelted, AP 9.277 ( Antiphil.).
ἡ χιὼν καίει τῶν κυνῶν τὰς ῥῖνας X. Cyn. 8.2, cf. 6.26 ( Pass.); κάειν λέγεται . . τὸ ψυχρόν, οὐχ ὡς τὸ θερμόν Arist. Mete. 382b8.

data.quote: ἡ χιὼν καίει τῶν κυνῶν τὰς ῥῖνας
κάειν λέγεται . . τὸ ψυχρόν, οὐχ ὡς τὸ θερμόν

children.definition: Pass., of fever-heat, τὰ ἐντὸς ἐκάετο Th. 2.49: metaph., of passion, esp. of love, to be on fire, ἐν φρασὶ καιομένα Pi. P. 4.219; κάομαι τὴν καρδίαν Ar. Lys. 9; ἔρως . . ὕβρει καόμενος Pl. Lg. 783a; καίεσθαί τινος (sc. ἔρωτι) Hermesian. 7.37, Charito 4.6, cf. Parth. 14.2; also καομένη Ἑλλάς Greece being in a fever of excitement, Lys. 33.7.
suffer from inflammation, ἐκαύθη ἔσω Hp. Epid. 4.20, cf. 4.

children.label: III
children.definition: burn and destroy (in war), τέμνειν καὶ κ., κ. καὶ πορθεῖν, waste with fire and sword, X. HG 4.2.15, 6.5.27.

children.label: IV
children.definition: cauterize, ὤμους Hp. Art. 11:—in Pass., Id. Aph. 6.60: abs., τέμνειν καὶ κάειν to use knife and cautery, Pl. Grg. 480c, 521e, X. An. 5.8.18, etc.: rarely reversed, κέαντες ἢ τεμόντες A. Ag. 849.

children.label: V
children.definition: burn or bake pottery, κανθάρους dub. in Phryn.Com. 15.
κ, κάμηλος θήλεια κεχαραγμένη κὰκ λὰλ ἄλφα PLond. 3.909a7 (ii A. D.), cf. BGU 153.17 (ii A. D.).

data.quote: κάμηλος θήλεια κεχαραγμένη κὰκ λὰλ ἄλφα

children.definition: κατά before κ, in Hom. mostly κὰκ κεφαλῆς, κὰκ κεφαλήν, Il. 18.24, 16.412, al.; also κὰκ κόρυθα 11.351; κὰκ κορυφήν 8.83; cf. κάγ, κάδ.

definition: κἀκ, crasis for καὶ ἐκ. κάκα· κακία ἢ ὄρνεον, Hsch. κακάβη, ἡ, κάκαβος, ἡ, κακάβιον, τό, v. κακκάβη, κάκκαβος, κακκάβιον.

children.definition: bring evil tidings, Trag.Adesp. 122.
evil tidings, Antig. Mir. 12, prob. in Man. 4.556, cf. Hp. ap. Gal. 19.107.
bringing ill tidings, γλῶσσα A. Ag. 636, cf. Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.241b, Ant.Lib. 15.4.
caused by ill tidings, κ. ἄχη the sorrow of ill tidings, S. Ant. 1286 (lyr.).

definition: κακαγόρος, κακᾱγορία, Dor. for κακηγ-, Pi. O. 1.53, P. 2.53.

children.definition: Dsc. 4.122; cf. κακαλίς· νάρκισσος, Hsch.
A. Fr. 166. (Perh. connected with ποδοκάκκη.)
unmanliness, S. Aj. 1014, E. Rh. 814.
with noxious blossom, Nic. Al. 420.
bear such blossom, Sch. ad loc.

definition: κακάω, cf. κακκάω. κἀκεῖ, κἀκεῖθεν, κἀκεῖνος, Att. crases for καὶ ἐκ-.

children.definition: Egyptian loaves, Str. 17.2.5.

evil-speaking, abuse, slander, Pi. P. 2.53 (pl.), Arist. EN 1131a9, Phld. Ir. p.52 W. (pl.); κ. τινός abuse of one, Pl. Phdr. 243a, 243b; κακηγορίας δίκη action for abusive language, D. 21.32, cf. 81; κακηγορίας δικάζεσθαι Lys. 10.2, etc.; ἔνοχος κακηγορίᾳ D. 57.30.

unfortunate in guests, in Ep. Comp., οὔ τις σεῖο κακοξεινώτερος ἄλλος Od. 20.376.

children.label: II
children.definition: unfriendly to strangers, inhospitable, E. Alc. 558 (v.l. for ἐχθρόξενος), AP 7.699, Lyc. 1286: Comp., Σκυθῶν -ώτεροι Jul. Ep. 89b.
wise for evil, οὐκ ἀξυνετωτέρου, κακοξυνετωτέρου δέ not less wise, but more wise for evil, Th. 6.76.
bad quality of wine, opp. καλλιοινία, Gp. 5.43 tit.

distress, misery, Hp. VM 10, Antipho 3.2.11, Isoc. 6.55, Arist. Pol. 1278b28; σώματος Antipho 5.18; of plants or trees, Thphr. CP 3.7.8; strain, stress, on the parts of a machine, Hero Bel. 93.1: pl., Hp. l.c.; ταῖς παρὰ τὴν ἀξίαν νῦν κακοπαθείαις your present unmerited sufferings, Th. 7.77:—later, usu. written κᾰκο-παθία, IG 2(2).900.16 (ii B.C.) , SIG 685.30 ( Magnesia, ii B.C.), BGU 1209.7 (i B.C.), Ep.Jac. 5.10: pl., IG 12(7).386.24 ( Amorgos, iii B.C.), Phld. Piet. 86, etc.; laborious toil, perseverance, BGU l.c. (i B.C.).

definition: κακοπαθέω, fut. -παθήσομαι PLond. 1.98r73 (i/ii A.D.): pf. κεκακοπάθηκα Aen.Tact. 26.7:—

children.definition: to be in ill plight, be in distress, Th. 1.78, X. Mem. 2.1.17, And. 2.26, Lys. 6.28, D. 18.146; πολλὰ κ. PCair.Zen. 93.17 (iii B.C.); τινι by or from a thing, τοῦ χωρίου τῇ ἀπορίᾳ Th. 4.29; ὑπό τινος Id. 2.41; πρός τι Phld. Oec. p.53 J.; of sickness, Hp. VM 19; κ. σώματι suffer in body, Antipho 5.2, 18, Isoc. 2.46; τῇ ψυχῇ Democr. 191; of plants or trees, Thphr. CP 3.4.4, al.
miserable, in evil plight, Vett.Val. 2.5. Adv. -θῶς in patient wretchedness, Arist. Pol. 1269b10; διάγειν Vett.Val. 121.34.

children.label: II
children.definition: troublesome, difficult, Hero Aut. 5.1.
miserable, Arist. EE 1221a31.
miserable, βίος D.H. 8.83.
troublesome, laborious, κατασκευή Ph. Bel. 56.46; μεταλλεῖαι Posidon. 48 J. (cod. Ath.), cf. A.D. Synt. 187.24.
laborious, persevering, γυνή Muson. Fr. 3p.11H.
accursed maiden, Sch. E. Hec. 612.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj. unbecoming a maid, Μοῖρα AP 7.468 ( Mel.).

definition: κακόπαστος, ον, dub. in A.D. Synt. 187.23.

children.definition: base-born (cf. εὐπατρίδης), prob. in Alc. Supp. 28.11; cf. sq. [κακόπατρις]
base-born, Thgn. 193; masc. in Alc. 37 A. codd. (leg. -ίδαν).
walking ill, of horses, Hippiatr. 115.
flying badly, Arist. HA 616b11.
with a bad wallet or scrip, EM 670.56.
filthy, loathsome, κακοπινέστατόν τʼ ἄλημα S. Aj. 381 (lyr.); οὐ μόνον τοῖς ἤθεσιν ἀλλὰ καὶ ἕξει Ath. 13.565e. Adv. -νῶς, διακείμενος Archig. (?)ap. Aët. 3.114.

data.quote: οὐ μόνον τοῖς ἤθεσιν ἀλλὰ καὶ ἕξει

children.definition: with misplaced confidence, Phld. D. 3 Fr. 75.
ill-conceived, Hermog. Stat. 1.1. Adv. -τως Tz.ad Lyc. 805.
sail badly, Str. 15.1.15.
ill for sailing, θάλασσα Sch. Philostr. Her. p.478B.
difficulty of breathing, Gal. 17(1).757.

definition: κακόπνοος, ον, Att. κᾰκό-πνους, ουν, ( πνοή)

children.definition: breathing with difficulty, Poll. 1.197.
do ill, play the knave, A. Fr. 111, Ar. Pax 731; manage oneʼs affairs ill, X. Oec. 3.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: do mischief to, injure, πολλὰ μὲν τὴν βασιλέως χώραν κ. Id. Mem. 3.5.26, cf. Plb. 4.6.10; τὰς νῆας Id. 13.4.1:— Pass., Id. 27.7.6.
prone to do evil, τρόπος Aristeas 163, cf. Andronic.Rhod. p. 572 M., Hierocl. p. 49 A.: Astrol., maleficent, ἰδιοτροπία Ptol. Tetr. 210.
evil-doing, Arist. Rh.Al. 1432a9, Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.249: pl., injuries, Isoc. 12.122; opp. εὐεργεσίαι, Id. 1.26.

doing ill, mischievous, ὄνειδος Pi. N. 8.33; σκεῦος, of a man, Plb. 15.25.1; κακοποιοί evil-doers, Arist. EN 1125a18; esp. of poisoners and sorcerers, 1 Ep.Pet. 4.15; of things, noxious, χυλός Thphr. CP 2.6.4, etc.; φάρμακα PSI 1.64.21 (i B.C.); τὸ κ. [ τῆς ὕλης] Arist. Ph. 192a15: Astrol., maleficent, Ptol. Tetr. 19, Artem. 4.59, etc.
bad government, Plb. 15.21.3, Plu. Pomp. 75: pl., Id. Lyc. 7, Ph. 1.41, 601.
unfit for toil, ἕξις Arist. Pol. 1335b7.
ill-fated, ill-starred, B. 5.138; τύχαι A. Ag. 1136 (lyr.); ἐμὲ κ. E. Hel. 694 (lyr.); κ. ὄρνις ἡ κρέξ Arist. HA 616b21.

definition: κακόπους, ὁ, ἡ, πουν, τό, gen. ποδος,

children.definition: with bad feet, ἵππος X. Mem. 3.3.4, Eq. 1.2; εὔπτερα μέν, κακόποδα δέ Arist. HA 487b26.
fare ill, fail in an enterprise, Th. 4.55; to be in ill plight, Id. 2.43; κ. ἀναξίως Arist. Rh. 1386b26, cf. Aphth. Prog. 1, al.: in physical sense, ἥπατος ἢ γαστρὸς κακοπραγούντων Gal. 10.789, al.
evil-doing, Hsch.

misadventure, failure, αἱ κατʼ οἶκον κ. Th. 2.60; ἡ ἐκ τῆς Σικελίας κ. Id. 8.2; κ. γίγνεται Arist. Pol. 1296a17; ἡ τοῦ πέλας κ. Corn. Rh. p.393 H.: pl., κ. ἀνάξιαι Arist. Rh. 1386b10, cf. Plb. 8.12.8, Phld. Herc. 1251.11, Artem. 4.56, etc.

children.label: b
children.definition: bad physical condition, Gal. 10.255.

children.label: II
children.definition: ill-doing, LXX Wi. 5.24, J. AJ 2.4.4: pl., misdeeds, Isoc. 15.300.
do ill, Plb. 3.2.8, al.
evil-doing, Democr. 297, D. 25.101, Plb. 4.23.8, al., Phld. Acad.Ind. p.54M.
doing evil, mischievous, X. HG 5.2.36, Isoc. 15.225,236, Arist. Ath. 35.3: Sup. -έστατος, περί τι Plb. 8.9.3. Adv. -μόνως Klio 16.163 (Delph.).
ugly-faced, Posidipp. 43, Plu. Stoic. absurd. 2.1058a; τὸ κακοπρόσωπον Xenocr. ap. Stob. 4.40.24.
with bad wings, weak in the wing, opp. εὔπτερος, Arist. HA 617b4, al.; of the Sphinx, as a bird of ill omen, Epigr. ap. Sch. E. Ph. 50.
with a thin beard, PPetr. 3p.23 (iii B. C.).

definition: κακόρας κατακόψας, Euclus ap. Hsch. (Perh. for κα-κορά<α>ς, cf. κοραίω.) κακόρδαζε· ἀπεχώρει, Hsch.

children.definition: with evil yearnings, ἀνήρ Adam. 2.39.
Hsch.
contrivance of ill, mischievousness, κακορραφίης ἀλεγεινῆς Il. 15.16; κακορραφίῃσι νόοιο Od. 2.236; μή τι κακορραφίῃ ἀλεγεινῇ . . ἀλγήσετε 12.26.
evil-doer, A.R. 3.595.
evil-speaking, Plb. 8.10.3; slander, Poll. 8.80.
telling of ill, ill-omened, A. Ag. 1155 (lyr.).
a poor speaker, D.C. 77.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: τὸ κ., = foreg., Suid. s.v. Ἀρχίλοχος. Adv. -όνως Poll. 8.81.
abuse, revile, E. Hipp. 340, Alc. 707, Ar. Ach. 577, Th. 896.
bringing a grievous flux, of disease, dub. in Ἀρχ.Ἐφ. 1920.80 ( Crete, vi B. C.).
with ugly muzzles, παιδία Arr. Epict. 3.22.77.
in bad rhythm ( κακόρυθμ-), Phld. Rh. 1.162 S.; τὸ κ. Id. Po.Herc. 1676.8; of the pulse, Gal. 19.409.
filthy, Aesop. 73 (= Babr. 10.1).
bad:
ugly, εἶδος μὲν ἔην κακός Il. 10.316, cf. Paus. 8.49.3.

ill-born, mean, γένος ἐστὲ διοτρεφέων βασιλήων . . , ἐπεὶ οὔ κε κακοὶ τοιούσδε τέκοιεν Od. 4.64; Ζεὺς δʼ αὐτὸς νέμει ὄλβον . . ἐσθλοῖς ἠδὲ κακοῖσι 6.189; οὐ κακὸν οὐδὲ μὲν ἐσθλόν 22.415; οὐδʼ ἐὰν . . φανῶ τρίδουλος, ἐκφανῇ κακή S. OT 1063; κακός τʼ ὢν κἀκ κακῶν ib. 1397.

data.quote: γένος ἐστὲ διοτρεφέων βασιλήων . . , ἐπεὶ οὔ κε κακοὶ τοιούσδε τέκοιεν
Ζεὺς δʼ αὐτὸς νέμει ὄλβον . . ἐσθλοῖς ἠδὲ κακοῖσι
οὐδʼ ἐὰν . . φανῶ τρίδουλος, ἐκφανῇ κακή

children.definition: craven, base, Il. 2.365, 6.489; κακοῦ τρέπεται χρὼς ἄλλυδις ἄλλῃ (called δειλὸς ἀνήρ in the line above) 13.279; Ἕκτωρ σε κ. καὶ ἀνάλκιδα φήσει 8.153, cf. Od. 3.375; κ. καὶ ἀνήνορα 10.301; οἵτινες . . ἐγένοντο ἄνδρες κ. ἢ ἀγαθοὶ ἐν τῇ ναυμαχίῃ Hdt. 6.14; κ. καὶ ἄθυμος Id. 7.11; οὐδαμῶν κακίονες ib. 104; κακοὺς πρὸς αἰχμήν S. Ph. 1306; κακή τʼ ἐς ἀλκὴν καὶ σίδηρον εἰσορᾶν E. Med. 264; οὐδενὶ ἐπιτρέψοντας κακῷ εἶναι X. An. 3.2.31.

data.quote: Ἕκτωρ σε κ. καὶ ἀνάλκιδα φήσει
οἵτινες . . ἐγένοντο ἄνδρες κ. ἢ ἀγαθοὶ ἐν τῇ ναυμαχίῃ
κακή τʼ ἐς ἀλκὴν καὶ σίδηρον εἰσορᾶν

children.definition: bad of his kind, i.e. worthless, sorry, unskilled, ἡνίοχοι Il. 17.487; [ τοξότης] ἢ κ. ἢ ἀγαθός ib. 632; νομῆες Od. 17.246; κ. ἀλήτης a bad beggar, ib. 578; ἰατρός A. Pr. 473; κυβερνήτης, ναύτης, E. Supp. 880, Andr. 457; μάγειρος Pl. Phdr. 265e: c. acc. modi, πάντα γὰρ οὐ κακός εἰμι I am not bad in all things, Od. 8.214; κ. γνώμην S. Ph. 910: also c. dat., κακοὶ γνώμαισι Id. Aj. 964: c. inf., κ. μανθάνειν Id. OT 545; [ νῆσος] φυτεύεσθαι κακή Trag.Adesp. 393; cf. 11.

base, evil, Od. 11.384, Hes. Op. 240; opp. χρηστός, S. Ant. 520; ὦ κακῶν κάκιστε Id. OT 334, Ph. 984; πλεῖστον κάκιστος Id. OC 744; κ. πρός τινας Th. 1.86; εἰς φίλους E. Or. 424 codd.; περὶ τὰ χρήματα Pl. Clit. 407c.
wretched, Herod. 3.42.

children.label: II
children.definition: evil, pernicious, freq. in Hom., etc., as δαίμων, θάνατος, μοῖρα, αἶσα, κῆρες, νοῦσος, ἕλκος, φάρμακα, ὀδύναι, Od. 10.64, Il. 3.173, 13.602, 1.418, Od. 2.316, Il. 1.10, 2.723, 22.94, 5.766; χόλος, ἔρις, Il. 16.206, Od. 3.161; πόλεμος, ἔπος, ἔργα, Il. 4.82, 24.767, Od. 2.67, al.; ἦμαρ, ἄνεμος, Il. 9.251, Od. 5.109; of omens and the like, unlucky, ὄρνις, ὄναρ, σῆμα, Il. 24.219, 10.496, 22.30: also in Trag., κ. τύχη, δαίμων, μόρος, S. Tr. 328, A. Pers. 354, 369, etc.; of words, abusive, foul, κ. λόγοι S. Ant. 259, cf. Tr. 461; κ. ποιμήν, i.e. the storm, A. Ag. 657: Astrol., unlucky, τόποι Heph.Astr. 1.12; κ. τύχη, name for the sixth region, Paul.Al. M. 1.

children.label: B
children.definition: κακόν, τό, and κακά, τά, as Subst., evil, ill, δίδου δʼ ἀγαθόν τε κακόν τε Od. 8.63; ἀθάνατον κακόν 12.118; ἐκ μεγάλων κακῶν πεφευγέναι Hdt. 1.65; so κ. ἄμαχον, ἄπρηκτα, Pi. P. 2.76, I. 8(7).8; ἔκπαγλον, ἄφερτον, ἀμήχανον, etc., A. Ag. 862, 1102, E. Med. 447, etc.; κακὸν ἥκει τινί thereʼs trouble in store for some one, Ar. Ra. 552; δυοῖν ἀποκρίνας κακοῖν the least of two evils, S. OT 640, cf. OC 496; κακῶν Ἰλιάς, v. Ἰλιάς; κακόν τι ῥέξαι τινά to do harm or ill to any one, Il. 2.195, etc.; πολλὰ κάκʼ ἀνθρώποισιν ἐώργει Od. 14.289; κακὰ φέρειν, τεύχειν τινί, Il. 2.304, Hes. Op. 265; κακόν τι (or κακὰ) ποιεῖν τινα (v. δράω, ποιέω, ἐργάζομαι) ; κακὸν πάσχειν ὑπό τινος to suffer evil from one, Th. 8.48, etc.: in Trag. freq. repeated, κακὰ κακῶν, = τὰ κάκιστα, S. OC 1238 (lyr.); εἴ τι πρεσβύτερον ἔτι κακοῦ κακόν Id. OT 1365 (lyr.); δεινὰ πρὸς κακοῖς κακά Id. OC 595, cf. Ant. 1281; δόσιν κακὰν κακῶν κακοῖς A. Pers. 1041 (lyr.).

data.quote: δίδου δʼ ἀγαθόν τε κακόν τε
εἴ τι πρεσβύτερον ἔτι κακοῦ κακόν

children.definition: κακά, τά, evil words, reproaches, πολλά τε καὶ κακὰ λέγειν Hdt. 8.61, cf. A. Th. 571, S. Aj. 1244, Ph. 382, etc.
κακόν, τό, Evil, Stoic. 3.18, al., Plot. 1.8.1, al.
pest, nuisance, τουτὶ παρέξει τὸ κ. ἡμῖν πράγματα Ar. Av. 931; also, comically, ὅσον συνείλεκται κακὸν ὀρνέων what a devil of a lot of birds, ib. 294.

data.quote: τουτὶ παρέξει τὸ κ. ἡμῖν πράγματα

children.definition: Comp. in Ep., κακώτερος Od. 6.275, 15.343, Theoc. 27.22, A.R. 3.421, etc.: also in late Prose, Alciphr. 3.62: irreg. κακίων, ον [with ῐ], Od. 2.277, Thgn. 262, etc., with ῑ in Trag., exc. E. Fr. 546 (anap.); κακῑότερος AP 12.7 ( Strato).
Sup. κάκιστος Hom., etc.--Cf. also χείρων, χείριστος, and ἥσσων, ἥκιστος.

children.label: D
children.definition: Adv. κακῶς ill, ἢ εὖ ἦε κακῶς Il. 2.253, etc.; κακῶς ποιεῖν τινα to treat one ill; κακῶς ποιεῖν τι to hurt, damage a thing; κακῶς ποιεῖν τινά τι to do one any evil or harm; κ. πράσσειν to fare ill, A. Pr. 266, etc.; κάκιον ἢ πρότερον πράττειν And. 4.11; κ. ἔχειν Ar. Ra. 58, etc.; of illness, Ev.Matt. 4.24; rarely κακῶς πάσχειν A. Pr. 759, 1041 (anap.); χρῆν Κανδαύλῃ γενέσθαι κ. Hdt. 1.8; κ. ὄλοισθε S. Ph. 1035, etc.; with play on two senses, ὡς κ. ἔχει ἅπας ἰατρός, ἂν κ. μηδεὶς ἔχῃ Philem.Jun. 2; κ. ἐρεῖν τινά, λέγειν τὴν πόλιν, Mimn. 7.4, Ar. Ach. 503; κ. εἰδότες, = ἀγνοοῦντες, X. Cyr. 2.3.13, Isoc. 8.32, cf. Hyp. Eux. 33; κακῶς ἐκπέφευγα I have barely escaped, D. 21.126: Comp. κάκιον Hdt. 1.109, S. OT 428, And. l.c., Pl. Mx. 236a, etc.: Sup. κάκιστα Ar. Ra. 1456, Pax 2, Pl. R. 420b, etc.

data.quote: ὡς κ. ἔχει ἅπας ἰατρός, ἂν κ. μηδεὶς ἔχῃ

children.definition: Adv. and Adj. freq. coupled in Trag., Att., etc., κακὸν κακῶς νιν . . ἐκτρῖψαι βίον S. OT 248; κακὸς κακῶς ταφήσῃ E. Tr. 446 (troch.); ἀπό σʼ ὀλῶ κακὸν κακῶς Ar. Pl. 65, cf. Eq. 189, 190, D. 32.6, Procop. Pers. 1.24; κακοὺς κακῶς ἀπολέσει αὐτούς Ev.Matt. 21.41; κακοὺς κάκιστα S. Aj. 839; in reversed order, ὥσπερ ἀξία κακῶς κακὴ θανεῖται E. Tr. 1055; with intervening words, κακῶς . . ἀπόλλυσθαι κακούς S. Ph. 1369, cf. E. Cyc. 268, Ar. Eq. 2. (Perh. cogn. with Avest. kasu-, Comp. kasyah-, Sup. kasišta- ‘small’, Lith. nukašëti ‘grow feeble, thin’, Germ. hager. )
very harmful, in Sup. -ώτατος (v.l. -ώτερος) Hp. Fract. 46.
lack of appetite, Archig. ap. Orib. 8.23.3, Poll. 6.36; κ. στομάχου Aret. SD 2.6.
eating badly, i.e. having a poor appetite, fastidious, Hp. Steril. 215, Eub. 17; ὁ περὶ τὰ σιτία δυσχερής Pl. R. 475c, Ael. NA 3.45, cf. Arr. Cyn. 8.2.
fastidious, πρὸς Κύπριν οὐ κ. (of Priapus), Ἀρχ.Δελτ. 2 App. 47 ( Thyrrheum).
with bad legs, ἵππος X. Mem. 3.3.4.
of a bad, mean body, AP 7.401 ( Crin.).
a bad smell, Poll. 2.75.
ill-smelling, A. Fr. 180.2, S. Fr. 565, Ar. Pax 38.
with bad seed, Thphr. HP 7.4.4.
faint-hearted, A. Th. 237.
impious sowing, AP 7.175 ( Antiphil.).
to be in bad case, Nic. Th. 431; of the wind, to be contrary, ib. 269.
sighing lamentably, Sch. Ar. Th. 1068, Sch.rec. A. Th. 856.
E. Andr. 1020.
foul-mouthed, sens. obsc., = Lat. fellator, AP 11.155 ( Lucill.).
have a sensitive stomach, S.E. M. 11.212.
bad state of the stomach, Gal. 14.735.
having a sensitive stomach, Cic. Fam. 16.4.1, Aët. 8.45; f.l. in AP 11.155; cf. κακοστόματος.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., bad for the stomach, unwholesome, Heraclid.Tarent. ap. Ath. 3.120c, Philistion Locr. ap. eund. 3.115d, Dsc. 1.127, al., Sor. 1.94, Gal. 6.641: Comp. -ώτερος Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 2.56b.
revile, τινα S. El. 597.
faulty pronunciation, Str. 14.2.28.
foul-mouthed, λέσχαι E. IA 1001.
lacking in eloquence, Ptol. Tetr. 166.

children.label: II
children.definition: bad to pronounce, ill-sounding, Longin. 43.1.
ill-spread, i.e. rugged, A. Ag. 556.
hard to reconcile, Eust. 1946.13.
malesuadus, Gloss.
of bad understanding, Eustr. in EN 368.31; cf. -ξύνετος.
Hsch.:— also κᾰκο-σύνθεσις, εως, ἡ, Phot., Suid.
ill-composed, in Rhet., Quint. 8.3.59; ἔπη Luc. Cal. 14; λόγος Sch. E. Or. 674; ill put together, κ. τὸ σῶμα Sch. Ar. V. 818. Adv. -τως Sch. E. Hec. 801, al.
bad grammar, Eust. 210.29, al.
ill-rounded, Tz. H. 11.492.
with a bad pulse, Gal. 9.831.
bad pulse, Aret. SA 2.8, Gal. 6.238.
badly formed, of a period, Sch. E. Or. 307, cf. Hdn. Epim. 177.
unseemly, only in Adv. -νως Lib. Or. 25.15; Sup. -ονέστατα Pl. Lg. 728b.
play mischievous tricks, Porph. Ep.Aneb. 26 [2.7]; in mal. part., Hsch. s.v. ὀρχιπεδίζειν.
to be mischievous, Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.77; πρὸς ἡδονήν Theano Ep. 4.3.
mischief, malpractice, Delph. 3(1).362i32 (ii B. C.), Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.274d.

mischievous, frivolous, Arr. Epict. 2.19.15; κακόσχολε naughty! AP 5.103 ( Marc.Arg.). Adv. -λως, οἰκονομεῖν act with frivolous delay, Ptol.Philad. ap. Aristeam 24; frivolously, προσφιλονεικεῖν, ἐγκαλεῖν, Simp. in Cat. 67.15, in Ph. 433.7; τὰ καλῶς λεγόμενα -λως ἐκδεχόμενον ἀδόκιμα δεικνύναι Id. in Cat. 7.27; also, = κακεμφάτως, Tryph. Trop. p.193S., EM 634.6, Sch. Ar. Ach. 397, Eust. 1638.17.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., κ. πνοαί winds that enforce harmful idleness, A. Ag. 193 (lyr.).
Hsch.
having bad children, Phryn. PS p.80 B.
ending ill, Sch. A. Pers. 910.
ending ill or with difficulty, ψυγμός Poet. de herb. 94.
use base arts, deal fraudulently, ἔς τινα Hdt. 6.74, PEleph. 1.9 (iv B. C.); περὶ τὰς δίκας D. 46.25: abs., Antipho 1.22, D. 29.11, 35.56.
use false artifices of style, Demetr. Eloc. 28, 250.

children.label: II
children.definition: misuse, τινὰ περὶ τὸ σῶμα Arr. Epict. 4.6.4; mislead, τοὺς νέους Aristaenet. 2.18.
falsify, οὐ κακοτεχνησῶ οὐδὲν τῶν . . γεγραμμένων GDI 5039.19 ( Hierapytna); counterfeit, imitate, [ αἱματίτης] κεκακοτεχνημένος Dsc. 5.126.
base art, Oenom. ap. Eus. PE 5.24.
Luc. Cal. 10 ( Comp.).

base artifice, malpractice, Heraclit. [129], PRein. 16.26 (ii B. C.), OGI 669.55 ( Egypt, i A. D.), CIG 2712.15 ( Mylasa), Ph. 1.636, Iamb. Myst. 10.2 (pl.): freq. in pl., as law-term, fraudulent or malicious conspiracy, κακοτεχνιῶν διαδικάζεσθαι Pl. Lg. 936d; esp. subornation of perjury, D. 47.1, 49.56; δόλοι καὶ ἐπιορκίαι καὶ κ. Luc. Alex. 4.

children.label: II

Alc.Com. 7.
Lys. Fr. 116.

using evil practices, artful, δόλος Il. 15.14: esp. in mal. part., lascivious, AP 5.128 ( Autom.): Sup., ib. 131 ( Phld., v.l. κατατ-); of songs, Plu. QConv. 2.706d. Adv. -νως with bad art, Ph. 1.195.
badness:

children.label: I
children.definition: baseness, cowardice, Il. 2.368, 13.108, Od. 24.455; ἀτιμίη καὶ κ. Tyrt. 10.10; κ. καὶ δειλία Th. 5.100; οὐδεμιῇ κ. λειφθῆναι τῆς ναυμαχίης not through cowardice, Hdt. 7.168.

wickedness, vice, τείσασθαι Ἀλέξανδρον κακότητος Il. 3.366, cf. Hes. Op. 287, Democr. 178; κακότητος ἄπειροι Emp. 112.3; κακότητʼ ἀσκεῖν A. Pr. 1066 (anap.); ἄνευ κακότητος [ συμφορά] Antipho 6.1: pl., Emp. 145.

children.label: II
children.definition: evil case, distress, misery, ἐκφυγέειν κακότητα Od. 5.414, cf. 290, 379, 397, Pi. P. 2.35, Hdt. 2.128, 6.67, S. El. 236 (lyr.); esp. in war, Τρῶες ἀνέπνευσαν κακότητος Il. 11.382, cf. 12.332, Hdt. 8.109, etc.: pl., distresses, miseries, Alc. 59, E. Fr. 303 codd. (lyr.); αἱ ἐντὸς κ. Pl. Ax. 366a.

children.label: III

Apollon. Lex. s.v. ἀ.

badness of habits, mischievousness, Th. 3.83, D.C. 54.21, Artem. 4.63; in argument, malice, unfairness, Simp. in Cael. 156.27.
malignant, D.C. 52.2, Vett.Val. 74.12, PMasp. 97ii20 (vi A.D.): Comp., D.C. Fr. 85.1: Sup., Zen. 5.41. Adv. -πως D.C. 47.4.
mischievous, κτήνη Hippiatr. 129.

children.label: II
children.definition: malignant, Antyll. ap. Orib. 9.23.13.
have poor nourishment, κακοτροφήσας Thphr. HP 5.2.2:—also in Pass., κακοτροφηθείς ibid.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be ill cared for, of vines, Theano Ep. 4.4.
poor nourishment, Thphr. HP 5.2.3; malnutrition, Gal. 7.73.
to be unfortunate, Th. 2.60, D.C. Fr. 36.15.

unfortunate, used by E. in lyr., Med. 1274, Hipp. 669: Sup., ib. 679; τὸ κ., = sq., Id. HF 133; κ. καὶ ἄθλιον γένος Sch.rec. A. Pers. 1013, cf. Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).142.
misfortune, Eust. 1422.44.
uniones ( onions), Gloss. (dub. l.).

do evil, work wickedness, E. Or. 823 (lyr.), etc.; κ. τι Antipho 2.3.2; μηδὲν κ. Pl. Prt. 326a; περί τινας Id. R. 416d; ἵππος ἢν κακουργῇ be vicious, X. Oec. 3.11; ἀδικεῖν καὶ κ. Ar. Nu. 1175; κ. καὶ ἐξαμαρτάνειν Pl. Hp.Mi. 375d:— Pass., εὗρέν τι -ηθέν found that a fraud had been committed, POxy. 1468.19 (iii A.D.).
κ. ἐν τοῖς λόγοις use captious or unfair arguments, Pl. Grg. 489b, cf. 483a, Arist. Rh. 1404b39.
ὁ . . ἱδρὼς κακουργεῖ X. Mem. 1.4.6.

malicious, ἀδικήματα Arist. Rh. 1391a18.

Aj. 1043; also κακουργότατος λόγος D. 20.125; κ. μάχαιρα AP 11.136 ( Lucill.); -ότατα εἰπεῖν Antipho 2.4.2. Adv. -γως Poll. 3.132.

Subst., malefactor, criminal in the eye of the law, Ps.-Phoc. 133, Th. 1.134, PLille 1.7.20 (iii B.C.), Ev.Luc. 23.32, etc.; οὐδεὶς κακοεργός Theoc. 15.47; at Athens, technically, thief, robber, ὁ τῶν κακούργων νόμος Antipho 5.9, cf. 16, Lys. 13.78, D. 22.28, 24.102.

children.label: II

wrong, injure, αὑτόν Teles p. 34 H.; maltreat, esp. a wife, Mitteis Chr. 284.6 (ii B.C.), POxy. 281.17 (i A.D.), etc.:— Pass., to be afflicted or injured, LXX 3 Ki. 2.26; ὑπὸ τοῦ δηγμοῦ D.S. 3.23; κακουχουμένους τελευτῆσαι τὸν βίον Plu. Cons.Apoll. 2.114e.
maltreatment, Pl. R. 615b; of a wife, BGU 1105.18 (Aug.); ‘mobbing’, Plb. 5.15.6 (dub. l.); ἐν χθονὸς κ. devastation, A. Th. 668.

children.label: II
children.definition: bad condition, Alex. 80; misery, distress, Plb. 3.64.8, Vett.Val. 127.13: pl., of ascetic practices, μάτην ἑαυτοὺς καταικισάμενοι ταῖς κ. Plu. Cons.Apoll. 2.117f.
ill-sounding, ill-omened, βοά A. Pers. 936 (lyr.).
evil report, ἡ ἐκ τῶν πολλῶν κ. Ael. VH 3.7.
inclamo, Gloss.

destructive, deadly, Nic. Th. 795, Al. 168: heterocl. gen. κακοφθορέος (as if from κᾰκο-φθορεύς) ib. 465.
bad friend, Phld. Lib. p.24 O., Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).146.

folly, κακοφραδίῃσι τιθήνης h.Cer. 227: sg., Nic. Th. 348, Q.S. 12.554.

definition: κακοφραδμοσύνη, ἡ, = foreg., Democr. 273, Orph. Fr. 285.41 (pl.).

children.definition: Theoc. 4.22; v. -Χράσμων.
ill-conceived, Sch. E. Or. 674.
bear ill-will or malice, A. Ag. 1174 (lyr.).

folly, LXX Pr. 16.18, Opp. H. 3.363 (pl.).

Mx. 248c:—in Pass., to be in ill plight, be distressed, κεκακωμένος ἅλμῃ befouled with brine, Od. 6.137 (v. supr.): generally, Hdt. 1.170, al., A. Pers. 728 (troch.), S. OC 261, And. 2.16, Th. 4.25; πρὸς θεῶν κακοῦται E. Hel. 268; ἐκάκωτο ὑπὸ τῆς πορείας X. An. 4.5.35; ἐκ πυρετοῖο AP 11.382.1 ( Agath.).

cardoon, Cynara Cardunculus, Thphr. HP 6.4.10, Philet. 16, Theoc. 10.4, Antig. Mir. 8, Dsc. Alex. 33.

reaper, mower, Theoc. 5.111.
Phryn. 144.

stalk, esp. the stalk or straw of corn, metaph. in Hom., αἶψά τε φυλόπιδος πέλεται κόρος ἀνθρώποισιν, ἧς τε πλείστην μὲν καλάμην χθονὶ χαλκὸς ἔχευεν, ἄμητος δʼ ὀλίγιστος, i.e. when there is much straw and little harvest, much slaughter and little profit, Il. 19.222; κ. πυρῶν wheat- straw, Hdt. 4.33; σῖτος σὺν τῇ καλάμῃ ἀποκείμενος X. An. 5.4.27; καλάμαν τε καὶ ἱερὰ δράγματα . . ἀσταχύων Call. Cer. 20; prov. of a greedy farmer, πυροὺς ἐπὶ καλάμῃ ἀροῦν to exhaust ground by one corn-crop after another, Lys. Fr. 77: pl., σῖτος ἐπὶ ταῖς κ. D.H. 5.13.

data.quote: καλάμαν τε καὶ ἱερὰ δράγματα . . ἀσταχύων

children.definition: stubble, Arist. Mete. 341b27, PSI 4.380.6 (iii B.C.), 1 Ep.Cor. 3.12, etc.: metaph., of an old man, καλάμην γέ σʼ ὀΐομαι εἰσορόωντα γιγνώσκειν thou mayst still, I ween, perceive the stubble ( i.e. the residue) of former strength, Od. 14.214; τὸ γῆρας καλάμη Arist. Rh. 1410b14; τὴν κ. δωρῇ, δοὺς ἑτέροις τὸ θέρος AP 11.36 ( Phil.); Ῥήσου κ. the remains of Rhesus, i.e. his corpse, Orac. ap. Polyaen. 6.53; ἀπὸ τῆς κ. τεκμαίρεσθαι to judge from the remains, Luc. Alex. 5.

data.quote: τὴν κ. δωρῇ, δοὺς ἑτέροις τὸ θέρος

children.definition: κολχὶς κ., = λίνον, Call. Fr. 265.
like a broken reed, of a kind of fracture, Sor. Fract. 10, Paul.Aeg. 6.89.
gleanings, Thd. Ob. 5.
cutting of stalks, reaping, AP 6.36 ( Phil.).
cutting stalks, reaping, ἅρπη A.R. 4.987.
gatherer of stalks, gleaner, Plu. An seni 2.784a (nisi leg. -τρίδας).
devouring reeds, i.e. cutting or trimming pens, χάλυψ AP 6.65.3 ( Paul.Sil.).
bring a corn-token in order to receive a ration of corn (cf. κάλαμος VI), Them. Or. 23.292a.
carrying reeds, X. HG 2.1.2 (v.l. καλαμοφόρος).
pipe on a reed, Ath. 15.697c ( καλαβίζω cj. Lobeck, cf. Καλλαβίς).
made of reeds, σφυρίδιον PTeb. 120.77 (i B.C.).

definition: καλαμίνθη (so Hsch., but -μίνθα Philum. Ven. 7.9, 14.6, Phot.), ἡ,

children.definition: Ar. Ec. 648 (gen. sg.), Thphr. CP 2.16.4 (pl.).

definition: καλαμινθίνη, ἡ, = foreg., Zopyr. ap. Orib. 14.62.1 codd.
Καλαμίνθιος, ὁ, Minty, comic name of a frog, Batr. 224.

children.definition: flavoured with mint, Dsc. 5.52.
catmint, mint, Nic. Th. 60.
full of mint, Str. 8.5.7, Apollon. Lex. s.v. κητώεσσαν.

of reed, οἰκίαι Hdt. 5.101; ὀϊστοί, τόξα, Id. 7.61, 65; χάραξ PSI 4.393.6 (iii B.C.); σῦριγξ, αὐλός, Ar. Fr. 719, Ath. 4.182d; κ. πλέγμα cheese- crate, Poll. 7.173: σκελετός, ἄπυγος, καλάμινα σκέλη φορῶν with legs like reeds, Pl.Com. 184.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: of cane, bamboo, πλοῖα κ. Hdt. 3.98.

definition: καλάμιον, τό, Dim. of καλάμη, Hsch. (pl.).

children.label: II
children.definition: κάλαμος:
= sq. 1, POxy. 1631.14 (iii A.D.): without diminutive sense, κ. μεγάλα ib. 1742.4 (iv A.D.).
καλάμια τῶν ὑποδέσεων, = ἀναγωγεῖς, Id. 995.30: sg., Sch. Ar. Pl. 784.
splint, Paul.Aeg. 6.8.
limed twig, acc. -ῖδα (perh. metri gr.) AP 10.11 ( Satyr.).
case for a writing-reed, pen-case, Poll. 10.59, Hsch.; pen (?), Phld. Po. 2.41.
toothpick or toothbrush, Dsc. 1.70; = κάλαμος II.7, Id. Eup. 1.60, Paul.Aeg. 6.24; also of quills used as splints for broken noses, ib. 91.
Poll. 5.96, Hsch.
καλαμίδες (sic AB 269), αἱ, reeds put in layers to strengthen buildings, IG ΙΙ(2).144 A 61, 62 ( Delos, iv B.C.), Inscr.Délos 366 A 36 (iii B.C.), IG 2(2).1672.64, cf. AB l.c.; also, bundles, ibid.
Hsch.

definition: καλαμίσκος, ὁ, Dim. of κάλαμος, used as a tube or phial, Ar. Ach. 1034, Gp. 20.24.1; in Surgery, Antyll. ap. Orib. 44.23.39, Gal. 2.873, Paul.Aeg. 6.88.

children.definition: branch of a candlestick, LXX Ex. 25.30(31).
stipula, Gloss.
reed-like, στύραξ Alex.Trall. 5.4, al., Aët. 1.133.

children.label: II
children.definition: ὁ κ. ἥρως, perh. the hero of the probe or, of the splints, nickname of Aristomachus, a surgeon who had a statue at Athens, called ὁ ἥρως ὁ ἰατρός, D. 18.129, cf. 19.249.
AP 7.198 ( Leon.).
noisy with the pen, nickname of Antipater, who dared not argue viva voce with Carneades, Plu. Garr. 2.514d.
cut reeds, make pens, Hdn.Gr. 1.468.
making pens, EM 485.35.
writing with a reed or pen, Man. 4.72.
the reed-warbler, Ael. NA 6.46.
reed-like, Dsc. 3.142.
of reed, συρίγγων καλαμοεσσᾶν E. IA 1038 (lyr.).
reed-case, Gloss.
angler, Procl. in Cra. p.40 P.
overgrown with prickly rush, POxy. 1911.101 (vi A.D.).
reed-bed for cutting, Gp. 2.6.31.
reed-cutter, BGU 1529.2 (iii B.C.).
reed-seller, PCair.Zen. 398.5 (iii B.C.).

reed, used for thatching or wattling, Hdt. 5.101, al., Th. 2.76; for wreaths, κ. λευκός Ar. Nu. 1006 (anap.); for bedding, Plu. Lyc. 16; for fuel, PCair.Zen. 85 (iii B.C.); various species, κ. εὐώδης, ἀρωματικός, sweet flag, Acorus Calamus, Thphr. HP 4.8.4, 9.7.1, Od. 33, Dsc. 1.18; κ. αὐλητικός pole-reed, Arundo Donax, Thphr. HP 4.11.1, 9; κ. εἰλετίας marram, Ammophila arundinacea, ib. 13; κ. ἐπίγειος bush-grass, Calamagrostis epigeios, ibid.; κ. Ἰνδικός bamboo, Bambusa arundinacea, ibid., Dsc. 5.92, PLond. 2.191.11 (ii A.D.), Gp. 2.6.23, cf. Hdt. 3.98; κ. Ἰνδικὸς ὁ ἄρρην male bamboo, Dendrocalamus strictus, Thphr. HP 4.11.13; κ. κύπριος, = δόναξ, Asclep. ap. Gal. 12.414; κ. πλόκιμος spear-grass, Phragmites communis, Thphr. HP 4.11.1; κ. χαρακίας, Arundo Donax, ibid.
reed-pipe, flute, Pi. O. 10(11).84, N. 5.38, E. El. 702 (lyr.), IT 1126 (lyr.).
fishing-rod, Pl.Com. 11, Theoc. 21.43, Luc. DMort. 22[27].9; κ. ἁλιευτικός Arist. PA 693a23.
limed twig used by fowlers, Bion Fr. 10.5, Aesop. 171, 296.
shaft of an arrow, Ptol. Alm. 7.5; made of κ. τοξικός, or Κρητικός, Thphr. HP 4.11.11.
reed-pen, LXX Ps. 44(45).1, 3 Ep.Jo. 13, Plu. Dem. 29, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 38; κάλαμοι γραφικοί PGrenf. 2.38.7 (i B.C.); κ. γραφεῖς Poll. 10.61.
measuring-rod, Apoc. 11.1, al.: hence, a definite measure, IG 9(1).61.50 ( Daulis, ii A.D.); = 5 πήχεις, Hero *Geom. 4.11; = 6 2/3 πήχεις, ib. 23.13.
tube for insufflation, Aret. CA 1.9, Asclep. ap. Gal. 12.985; for fumigation, Dsc. Eup. 1.56; for extraction, Cels. 7.5.2; also, splint, Pall. in Hp.Fract. 12.282 C.
AP 6.292 ( Hedyl.).
stake to which vines were tied, PFlor. 369.4 (ii A.D.), Jul. Or. 3.125b, etc.
reed, i.e. reeds, Arist. Mete. 359b1, POxy. 742.2 (i B.C.), etc.: in pl., reed-beds, Plb. 3.71.4.
ὕλη), nor tree ( δένδρον), X. An. 1.5.1.
mat of reeds, Pl. R. 372b; roof of reeds ( Coan), Hsch.

children.label: IV
children.definition: stalk of wheat, X. Oec. 18.2.

children.label: V
children.definition: ὁ κ. τοῦ σκέλους the shinbone, Sch. Luc. VH 1.23.

children.label: VI
children.definition: ticket for obtaining corn-rations, = tessera frumentaria, Gloss. (Cf. Lat. culmus, OHG. halm, etc.)
fixing of vine-poles, PGiss. 56.12 (vi A.D.).
covered with reed, βύρσαι Batr. 127.
one who kills with a pen, Ph. 2.536.
furnished with reeds cut for vine-poles, κτῆμα BGU 863.16 (ii A.D.).
one who catches birds with limed twigs ( Lacon.), Hsch. ( -ον cod.).
set up poles for vines, PTeb. 120.141 (i B.C.), PSI 4.317.6 (i A.D.):—hence κᾰλᾰμουργ-ία, ἡ, PLond. 2.163.24 (i A.D.).
played on a reed, of tunes, Ar. Ra. 230 (lyr.).
with leaves like those of reeds, Thphr. HP 1.10.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. -φυλλα, τά, = καλάμου φύλλα, Gp. 10.44, Hippiatr. 129.
Plin. HN 32.140.
bind a fractured bone with a splint of reed, Gal. 14.561.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., grow into stalk, Thphr. HP 8.2.4.
rushy, full of reeds, τὰ κ. Arist. HA 550b7, 568a21; κ. λίμνη AP 7.365 ( Zonas); κ. τόπος D.C. 63.28; of a reedy character, Thphr. HP 1.6.7, al.
reed-bed, Posidipp. (?) in PLit.Lond. 60.21, Gp. 3.6.6, Paus.Dam. p.160 D., Sch. Il. 18.576.
fence or edging of reed, Eust. 1533.51; cf. καλαμῶται· εἶδος ἐσχάρας, Hsch.
= Lat. Kalendae, D.H. 6.49, Plu. Cic. 2, etc.:— hence καλανδικά, τά, new yearʼs allowances, POxy. 1869 (vi A.D.), Just. Edict. 13.3.
lark, Dionys. Av. 3.15.

definition: καλάνι, for καλή, barbarism in Ar. Av. 1678.
καλαντίων, dub. sens. in PCornell 33 (iii A.D.).
Καλαοίδια, τά, festival of Artemis in Laconia, Hsch.; cf. καλαβοίδια.

children.definition: shoemakerʼs last, Pl. Smp. 191a, Poll. 10.141:—also κᾱλόπους, v.l. in Pl. l.c., cf. Poll. 2.195, Gal. Thras. 43, Edict.Diocl. 9.1 a, EM 486.6.

children.label: II
children.definition: servant, Suid. s.v. ὄνον ὄρνιν, οἰωνοί ( = Sch. Ar. Av. 722).

definition: καλαπόδιον, τό, Dim. of foreg. [καλάπους] I, Gal. 6.364 (v.l. καλοπόδιον, q.v.).

children.definition: bird, preyed on by the αἰγώλιος and birds of prey generally, Arist. HA 609a27.

definition: καλαρρυγαί τάφροι, Amerias ap. Hsch.:—Ambraciot word, acc. to Sch.Gen. Il. 21.259 (in form καλαρύα).

children.definition: a long Egyptian garment, with tassels or fringe at bottom, Hdt. 2.81, Cratin. 30; also, a Persian garment of like kind, Democr.Eph. 1; used in the Mysteries of Andania, IG 5(1).1390.17 (in form καλάσηρις):—title of a Comedy of Alexis. Cf. τρυφοκαλάσῑρις.

children.label: II
children.definition: Καλασίριες, οἱ, a branch of the military caste in Egypt, Hdt. 2.164, etc.

definition: καλασίριτα τὰ λοχία ἃ καλοῦσιν ὠά, Hsch.
καλαυνεῖ τρυφᾷ, ἐμπίπλαται, and καλαυρεῖ· τρυφᾷ, Hsch.

children.definition: Calauria, an island off Troezen, A.R. 3.1243, IG 4.752.18 ( Troezen, ii B.C.), etc.; later Καλαυρία, Str. 8.6.3, etc.: Κᾰλαύρῐα, ἡ, D.P. 499:—hence Κᾰλαυρεάτης, ου, Dor. -τᾱς, α, ὁ, citizen of C., IG 4.839 ( Calauria, iv B.C.); Καλαυρῖτις λιθάργυρος, f.l. for σκαλαυθρῖτις, Dsc. 5.87.

definition: καλαυρόπιον, τό, Dim. of καλαῦροψ, Artem. 4.72.

children.definition: shepherdʼs staff or crook, which was thrown so as to drive back the cattle to the herd, Il. 23.845, Antim. 61, A.R. 2.33, AP 6.106 ( Zonas), APl. 16.74, D.H. 1.39, Longus 1.8, BSA 16.107 ( Pamphylia, ii/iii A.D.). (Prob. καλά-ϝροψ, from *ϝρέπω, v. ῥέπω: but the first part of the word is uncertain.)
Magnesia), Hsch.
Ephor. (?) in PLit.Lond. 114.
summoner of men, epith. of ἄρκτος, PMag.Lond. 121.696 ( καδ- Pap.).

definition: κάλεσις, εως, ἡ, v. κλῆσις III.
καλεσίχορος [ῐ], ον, only in Ep. form καλεσσ-:

children.definition: calling forth the dance, calling to the dance, Βρόμιος Orph. L. 718.
A. Th. 574: κᾰλεστός, ή, όν, = κλητός, Gloss.

definition: καλεύειν λιθοβολεῖν, Hsch. ( κα- for κατα-). καλέχες· κατάκεισο (Paph.), Id. (cf. foreg. and λέχομαι). κάληβος,

children.definition: Id. καλημνεῖ· καλεῖ σαφῶς, Id.

definition: καλέω, Aeol. κάλημι (q.v.), Ep. inf. καλήμεναι Il. 10.125: Ion. impf. καλέεσκον 6.402; 3 sg. κάλεσκε A.R. 4.1514: fut., Ion. καλέω Il. 3.383, Att. καλῶ Pl. Smp. 175a, X. Smp. 1.15, etc.; later καλέσω LXX Ge. 16.11, al., Ph. 1.69, ( παρα-) D. 8.14 codd., SIG 656.40 ( Teos, ii B.C.), ( ἐγ-) v.l. in D. 19.133, cf. 23.123 codd. ( καλέσω in S. Ph. 1452 (anap.), Ar. Pl. 964, etc., is aor. 1 subj.): aor. 1 ἐκάλεσα, Ep. ἐκάλεσσα, κάλεσσα, Od. 17.379, Il. 16.693 (late Ep. ἔκλησα Nic. Fr. 86, late Prose ἐκάλησα Ps.-Callisth. 3.35): pf. κέκληκα Ar. Pl. 260, etc.:— Med., Att. fut. καλοῦμαι Id. Nu. 1221, Ec. 864; in pass. sense, S. El. 971, E. Or. 1140, etc.; later καλέσομαι ( ἐκ-, ἐπι-) dub.l. in Aeschin. 1.174, Lycurg. 17: aor.1 ἐκαλεσάμην Hdt. 7.189, Pl. Lg. 937a; Ep. καλεσσάμην Il. 1.54, 3 pl. καλέσαντο ib. 270:— Pass., fut. κεκλήσομαι Il. 3.138, A. Th. 698 (lyr.), Pr. 840, etc.; κληθήσομαι Pl. Lg. 681d, LXX Ge. 48.6, v.l. in E. Tr. 13: aor. ἐκλήθην Archil. 78, S. OT 1359, Ar. Th. 862, etc.: pf. κέκλημαι, Ep. 3 pl. κεκλήαται A.R. 1.1128, Ion. κεκλέαται Hdt. 2.164; Ep. 3 pl. plpf. κεκλήατο Il. 10.195; opt. κεκλῄμην, κεκλῇο S. Ph. 119, κεκλῄμεθα Ar. Lys. 253: late pf. κεκάλεσμαι Suid. s.v. κλητή.

children.label: I
children.definition: call, summon, εἰς ἀγορὴν καλέσαντα Od. 1.90; ἐς Ὄλυμπον Il. 1.402; ἀγορήνδε, θάλαμόνδε, θάνατόνδε, Il. 20.4, Od. 2.348, Il. 16.693: c. acc. only, κεκλήατο (for -ηντο) βουλήν they had been summoned to the council, 10.195: folld. by inf., αὐτοὶ γὰρ κάλεον συμμητιάασθαι ib. 197; καιρὸς καλεῖ . . S. Ph. 466; κἄμʼ ὑπηρετεῖν καλεῖς Id. El. 996; κ. τινὰ εἰς ἕ, ἐπὶ οἷ, Il. 23.203, Od. 17.330, etc.; εἰς μαρτυρίαν κληθείς Pl. Lg. 937a; ἐμὲ νῦν ἤδη καλεῖ ἡ εἱμαρμένη Id. Phd. 115a; demand, require, ἡ ἡμέρα ʼκείνη εὔνουν καὶ πλούσιον ἄνδρα ἐκάλει D. 18.172: aor. Med., καλέσασθαί τινα call to oneself, freq. in Ep., Il. 1.270, Od. 8.43, etc.; φωνῇ Il. 3.161; ἀγορήνδε λαόν 1.54; call a witness, Pl. Lg. l.c.

data.quote: ἐμὲ νῦν ἤδη καλεῖ ἡ εἱμαρμένη
ἡ ἡμέρα ʼκείνη εὔνουν καὶ πλούσιον ἄνδρα ἐκάλει

children.definition: call to oneʼs house or to a repast, invite (not in Il.), Od. 10.231, 17.382, al., 1 Ep.Cor. 10.27; later usu. with a word added, κ. ἐπὶ δεῖπνον Hdt. 9.16 ( Pass.), X. Cyr. 2.1.30, etc.; ἐς ἔρανον Pi. O. 1.37; ἐς θοίνην E. Ion 1140; ὑπὸ σοῦ κεκλημένος Pl. Smp. 174d, etc.; κληθέντες πρός τινα invited to his house, D. 19.196; ὁ κεκλημένος the guest, Damox. 2.26.

invoke, Δία Hdt. 1.44, cf. Pi. O. 6.58, A. Th. 223; at sacrifices, Sch. Ar. Ra. 482; μάρτυρας κ. θεούς S. Tr. 1248, cf. D. 18.141:— Med., τοὺς θεοὺς καλούμεθα A. Ch. 201, cf. 216; also μαρτύριά τε καὶ τεκμήρια καλεῖσθε Id. Eu. 486; but ἀράς, ἅς σοι καλοῦμαι which I call down on thee, S. OC 1385:— Pass., of the god, to be invoked, A. Eu. 417.

summon, of the judge, καλεῖν τινας εἰς τὸ δικαστήριον cite or summon before the court, D. 19.211, etc.; simply καλεῖν ib. 212, Ar. V. 851, etc.; ἐὰν μὲν καλέσῃ D. 21.56; also ὁ ἄρχων τὴν δίκην καλεῖ calls on the case, Ar. V. 1441:— Pass., ἡ πατροκτόνος δίκη κεκλῇτʼ ἂν αὐτῷ S. Fr. 696; πρὶν τὴν ἐμὴν [ δίκην] καλεῖσθαι before it is called on, Ar. Nu. 780; καλουμένης τῆς γραφῆς D. 58.43; but,

data.quote: ἡ πατροκτόνος δίκη κεκλῇτʼ ἂν αὐτῷ

children.label: b
children.definition: Med., καλεῖσθαί τινα to sue at law, bring before the court, Ar. Nu. 1221, al., D. 23.63; κ. τινὰ ὕβρεως Ar. Av. 1046; κ. τινὰ πρὸς τὴν ἀρχήν Pl. Lg. 914c; ὁ καλεσάμενος the plaintiff, PHal. 1.224 (iii B.C.).
demand, require, καλεῖ ἡ τάξις c. inf., CPHerm. 25ii7 (iii A.D.).
Pass., καλουμένης τῆς δυνάμεως πρὸς τὴν συναναληψίαν called forth, summoned, Sor. 1.29.

children.label: II
children.definition: call by name, name, ὃν Βριάρεων καλέουσι θεοί Il. 1.403, cf. Od. 5.273, etc.; κοτύλην δέ τέ μιν καλέουσι Il. 5.306; ὥς σφας καλοῦμεν Εὐμενίδας S. OC 486, cf. A. Pr. 86, etc.; ὄνομα καλεῖν τινα call him by a name, εἴπʼ ὄνομʼ ὅττι σε κεῖθι κάλεον Od. 8.550, cf. E. Ion 259, Pl. Cra. 383b, etc. (in Pass., οὔνομα καλέεσθαι Hdt. 1.173, cf. Pi. O. 6.56): without ὄνομα, τί νιν καλοῦσα τύχοιμʼ ἄν; A. Ag. 1232; τοῦτο αὐτὴν κάλεον Call. Fr. 66b; τούτοις τὸ ὄνομα ἱμάτια ἐκαλέσαμεν Pl. Plt. 279e ( Pass., τύμβῳ δʼ ὄνομα σῷ κεκλήσεται shall be given to thy tomb, E. Hec. 1271); κ. ὄνομα ἐπί τινι give a name to something, Pl. Prm. 147d; but call (a man) a name because of some function, Id. Sph. 218c; κ. τινὰ ἐπὶ τῷ ὀνόματι τοῦ πατρός Ev.Luc. 1.59; ἐπʼ ὀνόματος καλεῖν τινα Plb. 35.4.11:— Pass., to be named or called, Μυρμιδόνες δὲ καλεῦντο Il. 2.684; εἰ τόδʼ αὐτῷ φίλον κεκλημένῳ A. Ag. 161 (lyr.); ὁ καλούμενος the so-called, ἐν τῇ Θεράπνῃ καλεομένῃ Hdt. 6.61; ὁ κ. θάνατος Pl. Phd. 86d; οἱ τῶν ὁμοτίμων κ. X. Cyr. 2.1.9; κεκλημένος τινός called from or after him, Pi. P. 3.67; καλεῖσθαι ἐπί τινι LXX Ge. 48.6; κέκληνται δέ σφιν ἕδραι Pi. O. 7.76.

data.quote: εἴπʼ ὄνομʼ ὅττι σε κεῖθι κάλεον
κ. τινὰ ἐπὶ τῷ ὀνόματι τοῦ πατρός

children.definition: Pass., to be called, almost = εἰμί, esp. with words expressing kinship or status, ἐμὸς γαμβρὸς καλέεσθαι Od. 7.313, cf. A. Pers. 2 (anap.); ἀφνειοὶ καλέονται Od. 15.433; esp. in pf. Pass. κέκλημαι, οὕνεκα σὴ παράκοιτις κέκλημαι because I am thy wife, Il. 4.61; φίλη κεκλήσῃ ἄκοιτις 3.138; αἲ γὰρ ἐμοὶ τοιόσδε πόσις κεκλημένος εἴη Od. 6.244; ἠγάγετʼ ἐς μέγα δῶμα φίλην κεκλῆσθαι ἄκοιτιν Hes. Th. 410; σὴ κεκλημένη . . ἦα h.Ap. 324; μηδʼ ἔτι Τηλεμάχοιο πατὴρ κεκλημένος εἴην Il. 2.260; οὔτινος δοῦλοι κέκληνται A. Pers. 242, cf. S. El. 366, etc.

data.quote: αἲ γὰρ ἐμοὶ τοιόσδε πόσις κεκλημένος εἴη
ἠγάγετʼ ἐς μέγα δῶμα φίλην κεκλῆσθαι ἄκοιτιν
μηδʼ ἔτι Τηλεμάχοιο πατὴρ κεκλημένος εἴην

children.label: a
children.definition: Ἀλησίου ἔνθα κολώνη κέκληται where is the hill called the hill of Alesios, Il. 11.758; ἵνα κριοῦ καλέονται εὐναί A.R. 4.115; ἔνθα ἡ Τριπυργία καλεῖται X. HG 5.1.10, etc.: -so in Act., ἔνθα Ῥέας πόρον ἄνθρωποι καλέοισιν where is the ford men call the ford of Rhea, Pi. N. 9.41, cf. κικλήσκω, κλῄζω, κλέω.

children.label: b
children.definition: ἐκάλεσσέ νιν ἰσώνυμον ἔμμεν said that his name should be the same, Id. O. 9.63; καλεῖ με πλαστὸς ὡς εἴην πατρί, i.e. καλεῖ με πλαστόν S. OT 780; καλοῦμέν γε παραδιδόντα μὲν διδάσκειν we say that one who delivers teaches, Pl. Tht. 198b, cf. Smp. 205d; τὰς ἀμπέλους τραγᾶν καλοῦσιν Arist. HA 546a3.
bringing a fair day (opp. κακήμερος), AP 9.508 ( Pall.); καλήμερε, χαῖρε Mim.Oxy. 413.67.
Aeol. for καλέω, Sapph. 1.16 ( v.l. κάλ-ημμι), Supp. 21.4: 3 sg. impf. ἐκάλη Alc. Supp. 10.5.
crier, κήρυκα καλήτορα τοῖο γέροντος Il. 24.577: pr. n. in 15.419.

wooden dwelling, hut, Hes. Op. 374, 503, Call. Fr. 131; esp. barn, granary, Hes. Op. 301, 307; birdʼs nest, Theoc. 29.12, Ps.-Phoc. 84, A.R. 1.170, 4.1095, Luc. Syr.D. 29, Anacreont. 25.7; lair, ὕστριχος Call. Dian. 96; shrine or grotto, containing the image of a god, AP 6.253 ( Crin.), IG 12(2).484.15 (Mytil.). Cf. καλιός. [ ῑ in Hes., etc.; ῐ in Theoc. and Ps.-Phoc.]
model of a hut, κ. ἐλεφάντινον JHS 41.196 ( Delos, ii B. C.).
hut, AP 11.44 ( Phld.), Plu. Def.orac. 2.418a; chapel, shrine, IG 2(2).1533.5 (iv B. C.), D.H. 3.70, Plu. Num. 8, etc.; nest, in form καλειάς, Max.Tyr. 16.5 (pl.).
Dim. of Lat. caliga, boot, PSI 8.886 (iv A. D.), Anon. in Rh. 123.21; written καλήγιον Aët. 7.101.

definition: καλίδιον [ῑδ], τό, Dim. of καλῑά, Eup. 42, prob. in Com.Adesp. 1335:—also καλίδια· ἔντερα (Cypr.), Hsch.

children.definition: live in huts, in Lacon. aor. 1 ἐκαλίξαντο, Hsch.

definition: κάλικα, ἡ, only in gen. pl. καλικῶν,

children.definition: = Lat. caliga, boot, Edict. Diocl. 9.5, al.:—hence κᾰλῐκαρικός, ή, όν, belonging to boots, φόρμαι ibid.
= Lat. calcei, Plb. 30.18.3.

definition: καλινδέομαι, only in pres. and impf.,

children.definition: roll about, wallow, ἀποθνῄσκοντες ἐν ταῖς ὁδοῖς ἐκαλινδοῦντο, of plaguestricken persons, Th. 2.52; of birds, κ. ἐν τῇ γῇ, κ. τοῖς πτεροῖς πρὸς τὴν κόνιν, Arist. HA 612a20, b24; < ἐν> ῥεύμασι Plu. Tim. 28; ἐπὶ ἐλαίου, as a form of exercise, Gal. 6.220, cf. 324; roam, κατὰ τὰς νάπας X. An. 5.2.31; ἐν τῇσι στοιῇσι Hdt. 3.52: metaph., ἐν θιάσοις καὶ μεθύουσιν ἀνθρώποις κ. D. 19.199: hence, to be continually busy with, pass oneʼs time in a thing, ἐν τῷ πειρᾶσθαι X. Cyr. 1.4.5 (v.l. κυλινδ-) ; περὶ τὰς ἔριδας, περὶ τὰ δικαστήρια, Isoc. 13.20, 15.30; κ. ἐπὶ τοῦ βήματος Id. 5.81 (v.l. κυλ-) ; ἐν ἀγοραῖς S.E. M. 2.27.
place for horses to roll after exercise, Ael. NA 3.2.
a throw of the dice, Alciphr. 3.42 (pl.).
wooden, Lyc. 1418, Epich. 100a, A.R. 2.381a; κολοσσός Berl.Sitzb. 1927.167 ( Cyrene).

definition: κάλιον, τό, Dim. of κᾶλον, Hsch.

children.definition: cabin, hovel, Epich. 39.
fowl-coop, Cratin. 72.
prison, Hsch.
f.l. in X. Eq. 5.3.
D. 47.60 (restored fr. Harp. s.v. ἐκαλίστρουν), Call. Dian. 67, Cer. 98.
PGen. 80.9 (iv A. D.).

definition: καλλά, Adv., Dor. for καλά, Alcm. 98, cf. A.D. Adv. 155.10.

children.definition: a wanton dance, Καλλαβίδας βαίνειν Eup. 163 (lyr.), cf. Phot.:—written Καλαβίς in Hsch.
makers of blue dye, PBodl.ined. c. 88 (P.).
cockʼs comb, Arist. HA 631b10, 28: pl., κάλλαια, τά, wattles, Ar. Eq. 497, Ael. NA 5.5, 15.2, Paus. 9.23.4.
cockʼs tail-feathers, Ael.Dion. Fr. 219.

definition: καλλαμβάνω, aor. part. Pass. καλλάφθεις, Aeol. for καταληφ-, IG 12(2).526.20 ( Eresus).

children.definition: cod-fish, Archestr. Fr. 14, Opp. H. 1.105, Hsch. s.v. λαζίνης.
καλλείπω, Ep. for καταλείπω. κάλλειψιν· κατάλειψιν, Id. κάλλης· καρπίμου, Id.
beautiful: καλο- is later and less common.
Adj. with its Subst., as καλλίπαις, = καλὴ παῖς.
to be a member of the κάλλιον (q.v.) at Cyzicus, IGRom. 4.153,157:—also καλλῐ-αρχέω, to be president of the κάλλιον (q.v.) at Cyzicus, CIG 3661.
auspicious sacrifice (cf. καλλιερέω), Abh.Berl.Akad. 1928(6).16 ( Cos).

definition: καλλίας, ου ( Lacon. καλλίαρ Hsch.), ὁ,

children.definition: tame ape, Din. Fr. 6.2; Ion. καλλίης Herod. 3.41: a euphemism, cf. Gal. 18(2).236, 611.
with fine ankle, Arist. HA 499b22.

definition: καλλιβάντες ὅμοια σμιλίοις καὶ ψαλίσιν, ἐν αἷς τὰς ὀφρῦς κοσμοῦσιν αἱ γυναῖκες, Hsch.

children.definition: with beautiful eyelids: beautiful-eyed, E. Ion 189 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., κ. (sc. φάρμακον), τό, paint for the eyelids and eyelashes, Dsc. 1.69, I Enoch 8.1, Gal. 12.211: as Adj., κ. δυνάμεις ib. 62.
beautiful-sounding, αὐλός Simon. 46.3, S. Tr. 640 (lyr.), Ar. Av. 682 (lyr.).
throw at dice, Poll. 7.204.
with fine pastures, Nonn. D. 35.59.
beautiful-clustering, νάρκισσος S. OC 682 (lyr.).
with rich soil, Ἴδας ὄρος E. Or. 1382 (lyr.).
beautiful in its calm, πρόσωπα E. Tr. 837 (lyr.).
of happy marriage, λέκτρα AP 9.765 ( Paul.Sil.).
beautifully formed, καρπός prob. in Poet. de herb. 104.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., having a fair offspring, Corinn. 23, Procl. H. 6.1.

bearer of a fair offspring, name by which Demeter was invoked in the Thesmophoria, Ar. Th. 299, Alciphr. 2.4, cf. IG 14.205 ( Acrae); or her nurse, Ar. ap. Phot.; epith. of the Moon, Hymn.Mag. 5.31; of the Earth, Apollod. ap. Phot.:—neut. pl., Καλλιγένεια θύειν offer sacrifice to Demeter K., Alciphr. 3.39 (nisi leg. τῇ Κ.).
with beautiful bridges, ποταμός E. Rh. 349 (lyr.).
Nic. Fr. 23.
of noble race, Porph. ap. Eus. PE 3.11 (v.l. καλλιγόνης) ; τέκνων καλλιγόνους σταχύας IG 12(3).1188 ( Melos):—fem. Καλλιγόνη, ἡ, epith. of Demeter at Pergamon, Ath.Mitt. 37.288.

write beautifully, in point of style, metaph. in Med., κ. τὴν ἀπομίμησιν τοῖς τῆς ἀρετῆς στοιχείοις Arist. Rh.Al. 1420b17: pf. Pass. in act. sense, Longin. 33.5; in pass. sense, κεκαλλιγραφημένοι λόγοι J. Ap. 2.31, cf. D.L. 7.18: later use for Att. εἰς κάλλος γράφειν, Phryn. 99.

data.quote: κ. τὴν ἀπομίμησιν τοῖς τῆς ἀρετῆς στοιχείοις

children.label: II
children.definition: paint beautifully, τὸ πρόσωπον Poll. 5.102.

beautiful writing, whether of the characters or the style, cf. Plu. Pyth. 2.397c with Coniug. 145f; as a subject of competition in schools, good handwriting, CIG 3088 ( Teos): in pl., elegances of style, D.L. 3.66.
suited for fine penmanship, ἐργαλεῖον Suid. s.v. κανονίς; but σφάλμα κ. copyistʼs error, Steph. in Hp. 2.407 D.
penman, copyist, Edict.Diocl. in IG 5(1).1406 ( Asine), Hdn. post Moer. p.477 P., An. Ox. 2.397, Pall. in Hp. 2.102 D.
with beautiful women, poet. word, only in obl. cases, Ἑλλάδα καλλιγύναικα, Ἀχαιΐδα κ., Σπάρτην κ., Il. 2.683, 3.75, Od. 13.412: gen., Sapph. [26]: dat., Pi. P. 9.74.
with fine trees, of places, Plb. 5.19.2 ( Sup.), Sch. Pi. O. 9.27.
with beautiful eddies, Πηνειός E. HF 368 (lyr.).
with beautiful chariot, πῶλοι E. Hec. 467 (lyr.).
with beautiful reeds, Εὐρώτας E. Hel. 493.
with beautiful hair, Orph. H. 50.7: pecul. fem. καλλιέθειρα Nonn. D. 27.248.
garden olive, opp. ἀγριέλαιος, Ep.Rom. 11.24:—fem. καλλῐ-ελαία, ἡ, Arch.Pap. 2.218 (iii/iv A.D.): as Adj., κ. ἐλαία PCair.Zen. 125.3 (iii B. C.), Gp. 9.8; φυτόν ib. 9.10.6.
beautiful language, Herm. in Phdr. p.68A., Hsch.

say in fine phrases, κ. ὡς . . εἰκότως ἄρχομεν Th. 6.83; εἰ δοῦλος καλλιεποῖτο use fine language, Arist. Rh. 1404b16; ῥημάτων ὧν οἱ δεξιοὶ περὶ τὰς δίκας -εποῦνται Pl. Hipparch. 225c:— Pass., λόγοι κεκαλλιεπημένοι ῥήμασί τε καὶ ὀνόμασι Id. Ap. 17b:—later in Act., καλλιεπέω, Them. Or. 20p.285D.

data.quote: ῥημάτων ὧν οἱ δεξιοὶ περὶ τὰς δίκας -εποῦνται
λόγοι κεκαλλιεπημένοι ῥήμασί τε καὶ ὀνόμασι

children.definition: elegant in diction, Ar. Th. 49 (of Agathon), 60, D.H. Comp. 18; etym. of Καλλιόπη, Corn. ND 14.
to be worked beautifully, Phlp. in Ph. 327.1; of land, to be well-cultivated, Sammelb. 5168.27 (ii A. D.).
good work, of improvements made by a tenant, Just. Nov. 64.1: generally, good cultivation, Sammelb. 4481.16 (V A.D.), etc.

definition: καλλίεργος, ον, f.l. for καλεῖ ἔργον (cj. Bernays) in Ph. 2.490.
καλλιερέω, pf. κεκαλλιέρηκα Ph. 1.319: plpf. ἐκεκαλλιερήκειν X. Cyr. 6.4.12: ( ἱερόν):—

children.definition: have favourable signs in a sacrifice, obtain good omens, of the person, κἂν καλλιερῆτε Pl.Com. 51, cf. X. l.c., IG 1(2).45.5, etc.:—also in Med., Hdt. 6.82, Isoc. 14.60, X. An. 5.4.22, etc.; ἐς τὸν (sc. ποταμὸν) . . ἐκαλλιερέοντο σφάζοντες ἵππους (where ἐς τόν is constructed with σφάζοντες) Hdt. 7.113.

sacrifice with good omens, ταῖς Νύμφαις τὰν ἀμνόν Theoc. 5.148; καλλιερεῖν βοῦν prob. l. in Orac. ap. D. 21.53; ἑαυτὸν τῷ πατρίῳ νόμῳ Plu. Alex. 69: abs., κ. τοῖς θεοῖς X. Eq.Mag. 3.1, cf. Pl. Lg. 791a:— Med., Ar. Pl. 1181:— Pass., ἐὰν καὶ καλλιερηθῇ τοῖς θεοῖς Men. 319.8; τοὺς ξένους τῇ Ἀρτέμιδι καλλιερεῖσθαι S.E. P. 1.149.

children.label: II
children.definition: give favourable omens, καλλιερησάντων [ τῶν ἱρῶν] Hdt. 9.19; καλλιερῆσαι θυομένοισι οὐκ ἐδύνατο (sc. τὰ ἱρά) Id. 7.134: c. inf., οὐκ ἐκαλλιέρεε ὥστε μάχεσθαι Πέρσῃσι Id. 9.38; οὐκ ἐκαλλιέρεε οὐδαμῶς διαβαίνειν μιν Id. 6.76:— Med., ὡς οὐδὲ ταῦτα ἐκαλλιερεῖτο X. HG 3.1.17.
auspicious sacrifice, Hsch., EM 487.14.

definition: καλλιέρησις, εως, ἡ, = foreg., IG 1(2).98.23, Onos. 10.26.

children.definition: beautifully yoked, ἅρμα E. Andr. 278 (lyr.).
with beautiful girdles, γυναῖκες Il. 7.139, 24.698, Od. 23.147; Ἥρα B. 5.89: in late Prose, κόραι Hld. 3.2.
with beautiful foundations, νηός Musae. 71.
with beautiful manes, καλλίτριχας ἵππους Il. 5.323, Od. 3.475, etc.; of sheep, with fine wool, καλλίτριχα μῆλα νομεύων 9.336, cf. 469: in late Prose, with beautiful hair, Herm. ap. Stob. 1.49.45.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., καλλίθριξ, waterwort, Asplenium trichomanes, Plin. HN 25.132.
offer in auspicious sacrifice, κάπρον AP 6.240 ( Phil.).
offered auspiciously, αἶγες Epigr.Gr. 872 ( Patmos).
bear fine fruit, Thphr. HP 3.15.2, Gp. 3.3.6.
beauty of fruit, Thphr. HP 1.4.1, Gp. 10.1.4.
rich in fine fruit, of places, Σικελία A. Pr. 371, cf. E. HF 464, Str. 17.3.21: Comp. -ότερος Thphr. HP 3.8.1: Sup. -ότατος, τόπος Plb. 5.19.2.
bearing fine fruit, μῖλαξ E. Ba. 108 (lyr.), cf. Thphr. CP 1.17.10 ( Comp.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Διόνυσος κ., identified with Domitian, Jahresh. 18 Beibl. 55 ( Anazarba).
beautiful-sounding, Suid.
with beautiful horns, δάμαλις B. 18.24.

definition: καλλίκερως, (ῐ) = foreg., ταῦρος, ἔλαφος, AP 7.744 ( D.L.), 9.603 (Antip.).

children.definition: inkstand, Lyd. Mag. 2.14. (Lat. caliculus, late Lat. callicula.)
with beautiful seeds, ῥόα Thphr. CP 1.9.2.
Fair-hill, a hill near Troy, on the Simois, Il. 20.53, 151:— also Καλλικόλωνος, ὁ, Demetr.Sceps. ap. Sch. Il. 20.53.
= sq., πλόκαμος E. IA 1080 (lyr.).

beautiful-haired, of women, Il. 9.449, Od. 15.58, Pi. P. 9.106; Ὧραι Hes. Op. 75, cf. Th. 915; Ἀφροδίτη Epimenid. 19; Μοῖσαι Sapph. 60; χάριτες Ar. Pax 798 (lyr.), IG 1(2).821; also of trees, with beautiful foliage, IG 2.3412.
with beautiful head-band, ἄλοχοι Od. 4.623; θεά B. Scol.Fr. 5i22.
with beautiful spring, Pi. Fr. 198.

definition: καλλίκριτα χελώνην, οἱ δὲ φώκην, Hsch.

children.definition: beautifully built, Nonn. D. 26.85.
beautifully shining, Ἥλιος Anacr. 27.
use elegant diction, S.E. M. 2.55, D.L. 5.66.
beauty of language, Herm. in Phdr. p.191 A., Simp. in Epict. p.129 M.
express in elegant diction, embellish, D.H. 8.32, Comp. 3 ( Pass.):— Med., use specious phrases, Luc. Tox. 35.
elegance of language, D.H. Comp. 16; ἡ Προδίκου κ. Max.Tyr. 23.1.
one who gives good evidence, Hdn. Epim. 186.
fighting nobly, Lib. Or. 18.280 (sed fort. pr. n.).
with beautiful thighs, Herm. ap. Stob. 1.49.45.
beautifully formed, δέμας E. Andr. 1155; χορὸς τέκνων Id. HF 925; ταὧς Antiph. 175.5.
beautiful, δῶρα Od. 4.130, 8.439; οὖρος 11.640; χρόα, ὄπα κάλλιμον, 11.529, 12.192.
beautifully flowing, Κηφισός E. Med. 835 (lyr.), cf. Alc. 589 (lyr.); κρήνη A.R. 1.1228: Sup., Hsch. ( καλλινοτάτη cod.).

gloriously triumphant, τήνελλα ὦ καλλίνικε χαῖρʼ ἄναξ Ἡράκλεες Archil. 119, cf. IG 12(5).234 ( Paros); κῦδος κ. the glory of noble victory, Pi. I. 1.12; χάρμα κ. ib. 5(4).54; καλλίνικος ἅρμασι Id. P. 1.32: c. gen., τῶν ἐχθρῶν triumphant over oneʼs enemies, E. Med. 765; ἐραστῶν Pl. Alc. 2.151c; epith. of Helios, IG 12(2).127 ( Mytil.); of kings, as Seleucus II, Plb. 2.71.4, Str. 16.2.4, etc.; of martyrs, Cod.Just. 1.3.35.3 (Zeno).

data.quote: τήνελλα ὦ καλλίνικε χαῖρʼ ἄναξ Ἡράκλεες

children.label: II
children.definition: adorning or ennobling victory, μέλος, ὕμνος, Pi. P. 5.106, N. 4.16 codd.; ᾠδά, μοῦσα, E. El. 865 (lyr.), Ph. 1728 (lyr.); στέφανος, στέφη, Id. IT 12, Alex. in Gött. Nachr. 1922.10; κ. ἡλαίη Call. Iamb. 1.283; τὸ κ. the glory of victory, Pi. N. 3.18; so καλλίνικος (sc. ὕμνος) Id. O. 9.2; καλλίνικον οἴσεται E. Med. 45; τὸν καλλίνικον μετὰ θεῶν ἐκώμασε Id. HF 180; also τὰν Ἡρακλέους κ. (sc. ᾠδὰν) ἀείδω ib. 681 (lyr.).

children.label: III
children.definition: τὸ κ. an air for the flute, Trypho ap. Ath. 14.618c.
goodness of wine, Gp. 6.3.10, 5.2.19.

definition: κάλλιον (A), neut. of καλλίων, used as Adv., v. sub καλός c.
κάλλιον (B), τό, precinct used as a Court at Athens, AB 269, cf. Androt. ap. Poll. 8.121 ( Κάλλειον, fr. καλλίας, Phot.); at Cyzicus, apptly. a

children.definition: board or bench of magistrates, ἄρχων τοῦ κ. IGRom. 4.153 (ii A. D.); cf. καλλιάζω, καλλιαρχέω.

Calliope, the beautiful-voiced, name of the Epic Muse, Hes. Th. 79, h.Hom. 31.2, Sapph. 82, etc.; ἡμετέρη Κ. my Muse, Call. Aet. 3.1.77 [Fr. 75.77 Pf.]:—also Καλλιόπεια, AP 4.3b.61 ( Agath.): as Adj., κούρᾳ καλλιόπᾳ, of Echo, Theoc. Syrinx 19.
possession of fine armour, subject of competition at Priene, Inscr.Prien. 112.109 (i B. C.).

definition: καλλίουλος [ῐ], ὁ, a song to Demeter, Semus 19; cf. ἴουλος.

children.definition: work artistically, in Pass., Them. Or. 20.237d:
work of art, Jul. Ep. 205 (pl.).
make more beautiful, LXX Ca. 4.10 ( Pass.).

with beautiful children, blessed with fair children, Λητώ Trag.Adesp. 178; κ. πότμος A. Ag. 762 (lyr.); κ. στέφανος E. HF 839: also in Prose, Pl. Phdr. 261a, Arist. ap. Ael. VH 1.14, Aristid. Or. 17(15).20.

children.label: II
children.definition: beautiful child, Περσέφασσα κ. θεά E. Or. 964 (lyr.).

definition: καλλιπάρηος (so, not -ῃος, in most codd., cf. εὐπάραος) [πᾰ], ον,

children.definition: beautiful-cheeked, Χρυσηΐς, Ἑλένη, Il. 1.143, Od. 15.123; Λητώ Il. 24.607, al., cf. B. 19.4 (prob. l.), AP 9.96 ( Antip. Thess.):— written καλλι-πάρειος Poll. 2.87.
with beautiful nymphs, Νείλου . . κ. ῥοαί E. Hel. 1; δέρη κ. neck of a beauteous maiden, Id. IA 1574:—later καλλι-παρθένιος, ον, πηγή Inscr.Magn. 252.

definition: κάλλιπε, Ep. for κατέλιπε, inf. καλλιπέειν, v. καταλείπω.

children.definition: with beautiful sandals, h.Merc. 57.
with beautiful robe, beautifully clad, of women, Pi. P. 3.25, E. Tr. 338 (lyr.).
with beautiful leaves, AP 9.64 ( Asclep. or Arch.), 10.16 ( Theaet.).
beautiful arm, κ. βραχίων E. Tr. 1194; with beautiful arms, παρθένος Alciphr. 3.67.
with beautiful locks, Δημήτηρ, Θέτις, Il. 14.326, 18.407; Ἑλένα Pi. O. 3.1; Πιερίδες E. IA 1040 (lyr.); Χρυσέαν ἄρνα κ. Id. El. 705 (lyr.).
adorned with riches, πόλιες Pi. O. 13.111.
beautifully breathing, αὐλός Telest. 2.1; also of smell, κ. ἄνθη Hsch. s.v. κρίνα, prob. in Porph. in Ptol. 182.
fair city, Pl. R. 527c: freq. as pr.n.:— hence Καλλιπολῖται, οἱ, Hdt. 7.154, etc.

definition: κάλλιπον, Ep. for κατέλιπον, v. καταλείπω.

children.definition: of beautiful rivers, νοτίς E. Ph. 645 (lyr.).
with beautiful feet, Hsch. s.v. ἀργυρόπεζα.
with beautiful sheep, Suid. s.v. εὔρηνος, EM 395.54.
with beautiful face, Γαλάτεια Philox. 8.
with beautiful prow, of ships, E. Med. 1335: metaph., of men, with beautiful face, beautiful, βλάστημα A. Th. 533; στόμα κ. Id. Ag. 235 (lyr.).
with beautiful πυγή, Cerc. 14; epith. of Aphrodite, Ath. 12.554c: Comp., ibid.
with beautiful gates, Θήβη Epigr.Gr. 993.
with beautiful towers, ἄστυ E. Ba. 1202; τὰ κ. πεδία, of Thebes, Id. Supp. 618 (lyr.); κ. σοφία high-towering, Ar. Nu. 1024.

definition: καλλίπυρος, ον, dub. sens. in Epic.Alex.Adesp. 9 ii 22.

children.definition: with beautiful steeds, Pi. O. 14.1.
beautifully flowing, κρήνη Od. 10.107; Ἴστρος Hes. Th. 339; Δίρκα E. HF 784 (lyr.).

definition: καλλίροος, ον, poet. for καλλίρροος (q. v.):—also καλλῐρόας, B. 10.26,96, Inscr.Prien. 376.

children.definition: with beautiful wand, Hsch. s.v. ἀκαλαυρόπις.
speak beautifully, Eust. 829.50.
elegance of language, D.H. Th. 23, Luc. JTr. 27.

children.label: II
children.definition: braggart language, Id. DDeor. 1[21].2.
elegant, λέξις D.H. Comp. 3; λέξεως μόρια ib. 16.

definition: καλλίρροος, ον, poet. also καλλίροος [ῐ] ( contr. καλλίρους S. Fr. 649.39),

children.definition: beautiful-flowing, ὕδωρ, κρουνώ, Il. 2.752, 22.147; ποταμοῖο κατὰ στόμα καλλιρόοιο Od. 5.441; κρήνην καλλίροον 17.206; πηγή A. Pers. 201; Ὠκεανός Orph. Fr. 15: metaph., of the voice, καλλιρόοισι πνοαῖς Pi. O. 6.83:—fem., Καλλιρόη, one of the Oceanids, h.Cer. 419, Hes. Th. 288, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Καλλιρρόη, a famous spring at Athens, later Ἐννεάκρουνος, Th. 2.15, Pl. Ax. 364a.
with a fine race-course, Ἀχιλλῆος δρόμοι E. IT 437 (lyr.).
with fine grapes, gloss on ἐριστάφυλος, Hsch.

offering of what is fairest, E. IT 23: pl., name of a festival and beauty-contest at Lesbos, Sch. Il. 9.129: in pl. also, the fairest prize, τὰ πρῶτα κ. ἀριστεύσας στρατοῦ S. Aj. 435 (cf. Sch.); τῶν φαλύρων τὰ κ. SIG 56.9 ( Argos, v B. C.); so in sg., IG 12(9).189.36 ( Eretria, iv B. C.), 207.19 (ibid., iii B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: beauty-prize, of the apple of Paris, Luc. Dear.Iud. [DDeor. 20.]1.
beautiful-breasted, Nonn. D. 5.553.
offering of what is most beautiful, E. Ph. 215 (lyr., pl.); the fairest prize, Id. Or. 1639.

children.label: II
children.definition: τὰ δευτερεῖα καλλιστευμάτων second prize for beauty, Lyc. 1011.

to be the finest or most beautiful, Hdt. 1.196, al., E. Tr. 226 (lyr.); of animals, Hdt. 4.72, 163: c. gen., καλλιστεύσει πασέων τῶν γυναικῶν Id. 6.61, cf. 7.180:— Med., δῶρʼ ἃ καλλιστεύεται τῶν νῦν ἐν ἀνθρώποισι E. Med. 947, cf. Ba. 409 (lyr.), Hipp. 1009: pf. part. Pass., ἀγώνων τῶν κεκαλλιστευμένων E. Oen. p.39A.; κεκ. θέαμα Procop. Aed. 1.1.

data.quote: δῶρʼ ἃ καλλιστεύεται τῶν νῦν ἐν ἀνθρώποισι

children.definition: beautiful-crowned, of Demeter, h.Cer. 251, 295; of Hera, Tyrt. 2; εὐφροσύναι E. Ba. 376 (lyr.); Λιβύη Orac. ap. D.S. 8.29.

children.label: II
children.definition: κ. ἐλαία the wild olive tree at Olympia, from which the crowns of victory were taken, Arist. Mir. 834a12, Paus. 5.15.3.

definition: κάλλιστος, η, ον, Sup. of καλός; v. καλός B.

children.definition: win glory in war, Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.227.
fig, Ath. 3.75e: callistruthis in Colum. 10.416.

definition: καλλίσφυρος, ὁ, ἡ (fem. -σφύρα Sch. B. Scol.Fr. 5i24),

children.definition: beautiful-ankled, of women, καλλισφύρου εἵνεκα νύμφης Il. 9.560, cf. 14.319, Od. 5.333; Νίκη Hes. Th. 384; Ἥβη Poet. ap. Luc. DMort. 11[16].1.
have beautiful children, OGI 308.9 ( Hierapolis, ii B.C.).
possession of beautiful children, IG 12(7).397 ( Amorgos), Parth. 33.1.
with beautiful children, IG 12(7).397 Eleg. 2, IG 12(7).477 ( Amorgos), Inscr.Prien. 225 (Aug.): Comp., Luc. DDeor. 18[16].1: Sup., Plu. Aem. 5:—also καλλίτεξ, ἡ, Hdn. Epim. 186.
beautiful artist, Anacreont. 4.1: pl., -τέχνεις Epigr.Gr. 796.
beauty of workmanship, Plu. Per. 13, Ath. 5.191b.
making beautiful works of art, Str. 1.2.33, 16.2.24, Them. Or. 4.56b.

definition: καλλιτόκεια, ἡ, pecul. poet. fem. of sq., Opp. C. 1.6.

children.definition: Hsch.
with beautiful bow, E. Ph. 1162.
with beautiful, i.e. well-spread, table, Call.Com. 5, Amips. 19.
Dsc. 4.134, Ael. NA 1.35, Archig. (?) ap. Gal. 14.321.

definition: καλλίτριχος, ον, later form for καλλίθριξ, Opp. C. 1.321.

children.label: II
children.definition: producing luxuriant hair, Dsc. 1.125.
beautiful-shining, ἡλίου σέλας, Ἕως, E. Tr. 860, Hipp. 455, cf. Theodect. 10.1.
beautiful-sounding, ᾠδαί E. Ion 169 (lyr.); ἱστοί Id. IT 222 (lyr.).
auspiciously burning, πέλανος E. Ion 706 (lyr.).
of beautiful growth or shape, Nonn. D. 15.171.
Hp. Epid. 7.59 ( καλλῐ-φυτον Gal. 19.107).
with beautiful petals, ῥόδον Anacreont. 42.3.
bringing beauty to birth, ὧραι Orph. Fr. 183; καλλιφύτων κοίρανον ἡμερίδων lord of the beautiful vine, Nonn. D. 47.38.
speak beautifully, opp. κακοφωνέω, Phld. Rh. 1.176 S.; pronounce euphoniously, ὁ τὴν τετράπεζαν -φωνήσας εἰς τράπεζαν Eust. 664.41.
beauty of sound or pronunciation, D.H. Rh. 1.5, 4.1, Luc. Pisc. 22.
euphony, D.T. ( Suppl.) 675.14.
with a fine voice, ὑποκριταί Pl. Lg. 817c; expl. of Καλλιόπη, Corn. ND 14.
shining gloriously, epith. of a divinity, PMag.Par. 1.594.
with beautiful hands, ὠλέναι Chaerem. 14.7.
with a beautiful tortoise on it, ὀβολός Eup. 141.
beauty-fish, = ἀνθίας, Arist. Fr. 316, cf. Hedyl. ap. Ath. 8.344f, Numen. ap. eund. 7.295b; but distd. from it by Dorion ib. 282e, cf. Opp. H. 3.335.
with fine pigs, ὗς Arist. HA 573b12.
with fair dancing-grounds, epith. of cities, Od. 11.581, h.Hom. 15.2, Pi. P. 12.26, E. Heracl. 359 (lyr.); of Olympia, B. 10.32; ἀγορή Simon. 164.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: of or for beautiful dances, στέφανοι, ἀοιδαί, E. Ph. 786 (lyr.), Fr. 453.7 (lyr.); τρόπον τὸν καλλιχορώτατον παίζοντες Ar. Ra. 452 (lyr.); ὁ Κ., a sacred spring near Eleusis, the fount of goodly dances, h.Cer. 272, cf. E. Ion 1075 (lyr.), Supp. 392, 619 (lyr.).
beautiful in the dance, of Apollo, Id. HF 690 (lyr.); κ. δελφῖνες Id. Hel. 1454 (lyr.).
beautiful-coloured, νάρκισσος prob. l. in Cypr. Fr. 4.6.

definition: καλλίων, ον, gen. ονος, Comp. of καλός; v. καλός B.

children.definition: with beautiful name: as Subst., a kind of fish, Uranoscopus scaber, Hp. Vict. 2.48, Arist. HA 598a11, Men. 31, Anaxipp. 2.2: sens. obsc., Com.Adesp. 1023.
broom, besom, Gloss.

beauty, rarer form of κάλλος, Hdt. 3.106, 7.36, E. Tr. 977, Ba. 459, IA 1308 (lyr.), Pl. Smp. 206d, Herod. 1.35, Lyr.Alex.Adesp. 4b4, etc.; [ κιόνων] IG 5(2).268.51 ( Mantinea, i B.C. /i A.D.): metaph., κ. βίου Hp. Decent. 1; fine quality, of pitch, Thphr. HP 9.2.4; οἴνου PFlor. 65.12 (vi A.D.).
producing beauty, ἄνθος κάλλους κ. Plot. 6.7.32, cf. Procl. in Ti. 1.269 D., in Prm. p.543 S.; cf. καλοποιός.

definition: κάλλος, εος, Att. ους, τό, ( καλός)

children.definition: beauty, esp. of body, Il. 9.130, 20.235, etc.; κάλλεΐ τε στίλβων καὶ εἵμασιν 3.392; κάλλεϊ καὶ Χάρισι στίλβων Od. 6.237; περί τʼ ἀμφί τε κ. ἄητο h.Cer. 276: in a concrete sense, as though external to the body, κάλλεϊ μέν οἱ πρῶτα προσώπατα καλὰ κάθηρεν ἀμβροσίῳ, οἵῳ Κυθέρεια χρίεται Od. 18.192: freq. in Trag. and Prose, γυναῖκε . . κάλλει ἀμώμω A. Pers. 185; κ. σώματος Democr. 105; opp. αἶσχος, Pl. Smp. 201a: in a general sense, τῶν ἔργων τῷ μεγέθει καὶ τῷ κάλλει χαλεπὸν ἐξισῶσαι τοὺς ἐπαίνους Isoc. 12.36; χώρη κάλλεϊ καὶ ἀρετῇ μέγα ὑπερφέρουσα Hdt. 8.144, cf. Pl. Chrm. 157e, D.S. 1.30; of ships, Th. [3.17]; ἀρετὴ ἂν εἴη κ. ψυχῆς Pl. R. 444d; τὸ τῶν μαθημάτων κ. Id. Grg. 475a; ἐς κάλλος with an eye to beauty, so as to set off her beauty, E. El. 1073; οὐ γὰρ ἐς κ. τύχας δαίμων δίδωσιν so as to regard beauty or show, Id. Tr. 1201; ὁ εἰς κ. βίος, opp. αἰσχρουργία, X. Ages. 9.1; ἐς κ. ζῆν Id. Cyr. 8.1.33; but ἐς κ. κυνηγετεῖν hunt for pleasure, Arr. Cyn. 25.9: in pl., σωμάτων κάλλη, opp. ψυχῶν ἀρετή, Pl. Criti. 112e.

data.quote: περί τʼ ἀμφί τε κ. ἄητο
κάλλεϊ μέν οἱ πρῶτα προσώπατα καλὰ κάθηρεν ἀμβροσίῳ, οἵῳ Κυθέρεια χρίεται
τῶν ἔργων τῷ μεγέθει καὶ τῷ κάλλει χαλεπὸν ἐξισῶσαι τοὺς ἐπαίνους
χώρη κάλλεϊ καὶ ἀρετῇ μέγα ὑπερφέρουσα

children.definition: κ. κακῶν ὕπουλον S. OT 1396; of a bird, Clitarch. 21 J. codd.; mostly of women, a beauty, τὴν θυγατέρα, δεινόν τι κάλλος καὶ μέγεθος X. Cyr. 5.2.7; Γαλάτεια, κάλλος Ἐρώτων Philox. 8 (nisi leg. θάλος) ; Ἑλένη καὶ Λήδα καὶ ὅλως τὰ ἀρχαῖα κάλλη Luc. DMort. 5[18].1, cf. Im. 2.

data.quote: τὴν θυγατέρα, δεινόν τι κάλλος καὶ μέγεθος
; Ἑλένη καὶ Λήδα καὶ ὅλως τὰ ἀρχαῖα κάλλη

children.definition: beautiful things, as garments and stuffs, ἐν ποικίλοις . . κάλλεσιν βαίνειν A. Ag. 923; βάπτειν τὰ κ. Eup. 333, cf. Pl. Phd. 110a, Poll. 7.63, Hsch. s.v.; κυπαρίττων ὕψη καὶ κάλλη Pl. Lg. 625c; μεγέθεσιν κάλλεσίν τε ἔργων Id. Criti. 115d, etc.; τὰ κ. τῆς ἑρμηνείας beauties of style, Longin. 5.1 (also in sg., τὸ κ. τῆς ἑρμ. D.H. Comp. 3); κάλλεα κηροῦ beautiful works of wax, i.e. honeycombs, AP 9.363.15 ( Mel.); κάλλη τοιαῦτα καὶ τοσαῦτα ἱερῶν D. 3.25; κ. οἰκοδομημάτων, = καλὰ οἰκοδομήματα, Plu. Pyth. 2.409a, cf. Fac.lun. 935a, D.C. 65.15.
Pythag. name for six, Iamb. in Nic. p.34 P.

definition: καλλοσύνη, Dor. -σύνα, ἡ, poet. for κάλλος, in lyr., E. Or. 1386, Hel. 383; also eleg., Supp.Epigr. 1.570; κ. ἐπέων, title of work by Democr.

children.definition: sweeper, duster made of palm-leaves, κ. φοινίκων LXX Le. 23.40, BGU 1120.17 (i B.C.).
of or for beautifying: hence τὰ Κ., a festival on the 19th Thargelion, when the statue of Athena Polias was fresh adorned, Phot., EM 487.13.
sweeper, cleaner, esp. in temples, οἱ ἐκ τοῦ ἱεροῦ κ. UPZ 8.6 (ii B.C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch.
broom, brush, Cleanth.Stoic. 1.130, Plu. Dio 55; ἀντὶ τοῦ δόρατος κ. φέρων Anon. ap. Suid.

children.label: II
children.definition: Arist. HA 553a20.
beautify, νέα πρόσωπα S. Fr. 871.6:— Pass., Plot. 6.1.20; λίθῳ Λακαίνῃ Them. Or. 18.223a.
gloss over, ὅταν ἐν κακοῖσί τις ἁλοὺς ἔπειτα τοῦτο καλλύνειν θέλῃ S. Ant. 496; εὐδιάβολον κακὸν κ. Pl. Lg. 944b.

data.quote: ὅταν ἐν κακοῖσί τις ἁλοὺς ἔπειτα τοῦτο καλλύνειν θέλῃ

children.definition: Med., pride oneself in a thing, Id. Ap. 20c; ἐπί τινι Ael. VH 3.19.

children.label: II
children.definition: sweep clean, Arist. Pr. 936b27, UPZ 79.17 (ii B.C.); ὡς ῥαίνηται καὶ καλλύνηται [ ἡ πλατεῖα] Plb. 6.33.4.
sweeping, in pl., IG 12(5).593 A 22 ( Ceos), prob. in Thphr. Char. 10.6, cf. Hsch. s.v. σάρματα.

beautify the face: hence, give a fair appearance to a thing, embellish, κ. ὄνομα Pl. Cra. 408b, cf. 409c ( Pass.), Phld. Hom. p.58 O.; τὴν πόλιν, ὥσπερ γυναῖκα Plu. Per. 12; τὸ λογικόν Arr. Epict. 3.1.26:— Pass., οἰκία . . δαπάνῃ κεκαλλωπισμένη X. Hier. 11.2, cf. Oec. 9.4; κεκ. τὸ χρῶμα, i. e. painted, Id. Mem. 2.1.22: metaph., λόγος κεκ., opp. καθαρός, Hermog. Id. 1.3; λέξις κεκ. S.E. M. 2.55.

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., adorn oneself, make oneself fine or smart, Pl. Smp. 174a.

pride oneself in or on a thing, τινι Id. Phdr. 252a, X. Ages. 11.11; ἐπί τινι Pl. R. 405b: also κ. ὅτι . . Id. Prt. 317c; ὡς . . c. part., Id. Cri. 52c, Tht. 195d: abs., make a display, show off, Arist. Rh.Al. 1421a4; of a horse, X. Eq. 10.5: c. acc. cogn., πολλὰ πρὸς αὑτούς Phld. Rh. 1.238 S.; ταῦτα -ίζεται makes a fair show, Iamb. Protr. 20.
to be coy or mock-modest, τινι or πρός τινα towards another, Pl. Prt. 333d, Phdr. 236d: c. inf., κ. παραιτεῖσθαι affecting to deprecate, Plu. Caes. 28, cf. Phalar. Ep. 92.
ornament, χρυσᾶ, ἀργυρᾶ κ., Plu. Lyc. 9; τραπέζης Porph. Abst. 3.19; source of pride, Luc. Merc.Cond. 36.
ornament of speech, D.H. Th. 46.
fair show, pretence, Pl. Grg. 492c (pl.).
adorning oneself, making a display, Pl. R. 572c; showing off, ὁ πρὸς ἵππους κ. X. Eq. 10.16, cf. Jul. Mis. 349c.

children.label: II
