cross-bar of κιθάρα, Porph. in Harm. p. 207 [22.17].

children.label: II
children.definition: rule, standard, κανόνι τοῦ καλοῦ μαθών E. Hec. 602; γνώμης πονηροῖς κανόσιν ἀναμετρούμενος τὸ σῶφρον Id. El. 52; κανόνα προσάγειν Luc. Hist.Conscr. 5; of the law, Lycurg. 9; ὁ σπουδαῖος . . ὥσπερ κ. καὶ μέτρον αὐτῶν (sc. καλῶν καὶ ἡδέων) ὤν Arist. EN 1113a33, cf. Arr. Epict. 3.4.5; τὴν ἐλευθερίαν καὶ τὸ μηδένʼ ἔχειν δεσπότην αὑτῶν, ἃ τοῖς προτέροις Ἕλλησιν ὅροι τῶν ἀγαθῶν ἦσαν καὶ κανόνες D. 18.296; ὡς κανόνι τῷ πάθει πᾶν ἀγαθὸν κρίνοντες Epicur. Ep. 3p.63U.; ὁ Ἐπικούρου κ. his treatise on Logic, Id. Fr. 34, Damox. 2.15; ὁ τῆς φιλοσοφίας κ. LXX 4 Ma. 7.21: Κανόνες, οἱ, title of treatise by Democritus; of a philosophic principle, Dam. Pr. 312.

data.quote: γνώμης πονηροῖς κανόσιν ἀναμετρούμενος τὸ σῶφρον
τὴν ἐλευθερίαν καὶ τὸ μηδένʼ ἔχειν δεσπότην αὑτῶν, ἃ τοῖς προτέροις Ἕλλησιν ὅροι τῶν ἀγαθῶν ἦσαν καὶ κανόνες
ὡς κανόνι τῷ πάθει πᾶν ἀγαθὸν κρίνοντες

children.definition: model, standard, ὁ κ., a statue by Polyclitus which furnished a model of proportions, Plin. HN 34.55; also his treatise on the same, Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.122 (adnot.); also in Literature, Ἡρόδοτος τῆς Ἰάδος ἄριστος κ., Θουκυδίδης δὲ τῆς Ἀτθίδος D.H. Pomp. 3.

data.quote: Ἡρόδοτος τῆς Ἰάδος ἄριστος κ., Θουκυδίδης δὲ τῆς Ἀτθίδος

children.label: c
children.definition: severe critic, κ. scriptorum, Cic. Fam. 16.17.1.
general rule, AB 1180, Choerob. in Theod. 2 p.xxi; paradigm, οἱ κ. τῶν ὀνομάτων A.D. Adv. 141.25.

children.label: b
children.definition: scheme showing all possible forms of a verse, Heph. 14.1, al.
table of dates, κανόνες χρονικοί Plu. Sol. 27; sg., κανών, ὁ, system of chronology, D.H. 1.74.

children.label: b
children.definition: table, κανόνων καὶ εἰσόδων πήξεις Vett.Val. 108.19.
limit, boundary, expl. as τὸ μέτρον τοῦ πηδήματος, Poll. 3.151.

children.label: b
children.definition: province’, sphere of action, 2 Ep.Cor. 10.15.
assessment for taxation, PLond. 1.99.5 (iv A. D.), etc.; οἱ δεσποτικοὶ κ. the Imperial taxes, ib. 234.9 (iv A. D.); ἰδιωτικὸς κ. POxy. 2124.10 (iv A. D.).
tariff, Stud.Pal. 20.143.5 (v/vi A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: cake, POxy. 1774.15 (iv A. D.); cf. Κανωβικός.
elder-flower, Paul.Aeg. 7.3; elder-bark, Alex.Trall. 12.
that which burns, etym. of χάος, Corn. ND 17.
Ep. for κατά before π, φ, κὰπ πεδίον Il. 6.201; κὰπ φάλαρα 16.106; also Thess., IG 9(2).517.20 ( Larissa).
of the crib or manger, epith. of Zeus, Antiph. 111.
Hsch.:—also καπαλαί· κάπηλοι, φάτναι, and καπαλίζω, = ζευγηλατέω, Id.
chariot, Thess. for ἀπήνη, Xenarch. 11. (Prop. the cross-piece in a chariot seat, the side-pieces being καπάνᾰκες, Poll. 1.142.)

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch.; also, a felt helmet, Id.

definition: καπανῆται, sine gl., Suid. καπάνια· ἁρπεδόνες, Hsch.

children.definition: τὰ Θετταλικὰ (sc. δεῖπνα) μὲν πολὺ καπᾱνικώτερα Ar. Fr. 492: expld. by Ath. 9.418d as, = ἁμαξιαῖα, enormous, by Hsch. as χορταστικώτερα, more foodful, more plenteous (from καπάνη = κάπη).

definition: κὰπατᾶ (sic): κατακόψεις (Paph.), Hsch. κάπατας· καθορῶν, Euclus ap. Hsch. (leg. καπατάς, cf. ἰμπάταὁν, ἰνκαπάταὁν).
καπέτις, ιος, ἡ, a Persian measure, 1/48 of the ἀρτάβη, Polyaen. 4.3.32; = χοῖνιξ, Hsch.; cf. καπίθη.
κάπετον, Dor. for κατέπεσον, Pi. O. 8.38.

children.definition: ditch, trench, ὄχθας καπέτοιο βαθείης Il. 15.356, cf. 18.564; hole, grave, ἐς κοίλην κάπετον θέσαν [ ὀστέα] 24.797, cf. S. Aj. 1165, 1403 (both anap.); groove for lever, Hp. Art. 72, 74.

children.label: II
children.definition: shovel, spade (?), GDI 4992aii6 ( Gortyn).

definition: Καπετώλιον, τό, = Lat. Capitolium, D.H. 1.34 (v.l.), etc.:—hence Κᾰπετώλιος, ὁ, = Capitolinus, epith. of Zeus = Jupiter, Paus. 2.4.5, SIG 694.24 ( Elaea, ii B. C.), etc.: Κᾰπετωλιονίκης [νῑ], ὁ,

children.definition: victor in the Ludi Capitolini, Sammelb. 5725: Κᾰπετώλιος, ὁ (sc. μήν), name of month of December, Gloss., cf. Cat.Cod.Astr. 2.140: Κᾰπετώλια, τά, = Ludi Capitolini, IG 3.129.
crib, manger, [ ἵππους] κατέδησαν ἐπʼ ἀμβροσίῃσι κάπῃσιν Il. 8.434; ἐφʼ ἱππείῃσι κάπῃσι Od. 4.40; βουστάθμου κάπης S. Ichn. 8; ἀντὶ κάπης Lyc. 95: κάπηθεν as Adv., Suid.
retail trade, esp. provision-dealing, tavern-keeping, Pl. Lg. 849d, 918d, Arist. Pol. 1256a41: in pl., petty trades, ib. 1291a6; κ. ἀσκεῖν προσώπῳ, of women who paint, Poll. 5.102.

shop of a κάπηλος, freq. of a tavern, Com.Adesp. 493 (in a parody of Sophocles), Ar. Lys. 427, Ec. 154, Lys. 1.24, Eub. 80, Isoc. 7.49, cf. Theopomp. Hist. 65, Tab.Defix. 87 (iv B. C.), Ἀρχ.Ἐφ. 1923.39 (pl., Orop., iv B. C.), PTeb. 43.18 (ii B. C.), POxy. 2109.11 (iii A. D.): pl., καπηλεῖα, τά (prob. l. for κάπηλα), the meat-market at Tarentum, Hsch.
Pl. Lg. 842d.

to be a retail-dealer, drive a petty trade, Hdt. 1.155, 2.35, Isoc. 2.1, Nymphod. 21, IG ΙΙ(2).161 A 16 ( Delos, iii B. C.), BGU 1024 vii 23 (iv A. D.); διʼ ἀψύχου βορᾶς σίτοις καπήλευʼ drive a trade, chaffer with your vegetable food, E. Hipp. 953.

children.label: II
children.definition: sell by retail, τὸν ἕρπιν Hippon. 51.

κ. τὰ πρήγματα, of Darius, Hdt. 3.89; κ. τὰ μαθήματα sell learning by retail, hawk it about, Pl. Prt. 313d; κ. τὸν λόγον τοῦ θεοῦ 2 Ep.Cor. 2.17; so ἔοικεν οὐ καπηλεύσειν μάχην will not peddle in war, i. e. fight half-heartedly, A. Th. 545; κ. τῇ χάριτι τὴν ἀμοιβήν Epicur. Sent.Vat. 39; κ. τὴν πολιτείαν traffic in grants of citizenship, D.C. 60.17; κ. τῆς ὥρας ἄνθος or τὴν ὥραν, of prostitutes, Ph. 2.394, 576; εἰρήνην πρὸς Ῥωμαίους χρυσίου κ. Hdn. 6.7.9; τύχη καπηλεύουσα . . τὸν βίον playing tricks with life, corrupting it, AP 9.180 ( Pall.).
steersmanʼs seat, hold, or belaying-pin, Hsch.

of or for a κάπηλος, ζυγόν Dinol. 2 (fort. καπανικόν) ; ἀργύρωμα IG ΙΙ(2).110 ( Delos, iii B.C.), cf. 111; mercenary, ἦθος M.Ant. 4.28; σοφιστής Poll. 4.48; ἡ -ική (sc. τέχνη), = καπηλεία, Pl. Sph. 223d, Arist. Pol. 1257a18: καπηλικόν, τό, camp-followers, sutlers of an army, Arr. Tact. 2.1; but also, tax on retail-traders, BGU 1237 (iii/ii B.C.).

like a petty trader, knavish, cozening, κ. μέτρα φιλεῦσα AP 9.229 (Marc. Arg.); ὕθλος Porph. Chr. 49. Adv. -κῶς, ἔχειν to be vamped up for sale, Ar. Pl. 1063; τὰ πράγματα κ. διανέμων Plu. Isid. 2.369c; in a mercenary spirit, Gal. 14.216: Comp. -ώτερον Numen. ap. Eus. PE 14.8.
Tab.Defix.Aud. 70 (iii B.C.).

definition: καπηλίς, ίδος, ἡ, fem. of κάπηλος, Ar. Th. 347, Pl. 435, 1120, Com.Adesp. 567, Aeschin.Socr. 4, PFay. 12.23 (ii B.C.): Καπηλίδες, αἱ, title of play by Theopomp. Com.:—accented κάπηλις, acc. to Hdn.Gr. 1.91, cf. Oenom. ap. Eus. PE 6.7:—late καπήλισσα, ἡ, Sch. Ar. Pl. 426.

children.definition: attubernalis, Gloss.
tavern-haunter, Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.242, Hsch.

retail-dealer, huckster, Hdt. 1.94, 2.141, Sophr. 1, etc.; opp. ἔμπορος, Lys. 22.21, X. Cyr. 4.5.42, Pl. R. 371d, Prt. 314a; also opp. the producer ( αὐτοπώλης), Id. Sph. 231d, Plt. 260c; applied to Darius, Hdt. 3.89; κ. ἀσπίδων, ὅπλων, a dealer in . . , Ar. Pax 447, 1209.
tavern-keeper, Ar. Th. 347, Lys. Fr. 1, PMagd. 26.2 (iii B.C.), PTeb. 612 (i/ii A. D.), Luc. Herm. 58, etc.
κ. πονηρίας dealer in petty roguery, D. 25.46.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., ος, ον, = καπηλικός, βίος D.H. 9.25; esp. cheating, knavish, κ. προσφέρων τεχνήματα A. Fr. 322; κ. φρόνημα Com.Adesp. 867.

definition: καπήλτια γυναικεῖα ἱμάτια, Hsch. (leg. καππάτια). κάπηξ,

children.definition: projecting piece at a shipʼs stern, Id. κᾰπητόν, τό, ( κάπη) fodder, Id.

children.label: II
children.definition: = wicker baskets, Lyd. Mag. 1.46.
onions (at Cerynea), Hsch.
a Persian measure containing two χοίνικες, X. An. 1.5.6; = two Attic κοτύλαι, Hsch.
halter, Hsch.
smoke-observer, diviner, IG 14.617 ( Rhegium): pl. -αῦγαι ib. 618 (ibid.).

with smoke-coloured grapes, Thphr. HP 2.3.2, PCair.Zen. 33.14 (iii B.C.):—written κάπνεος in Arist. GA 770b20; καπνέως in Thphr. CP 5.3.1 (cod. Urb., v.l. κάπνεος); καπνία in Suid., Sch. Ar. V. 151; καπνός in cod. Hsch. s.v. καπνίας; κάπνιος in App.Prov. 3.43.
turn into smoke, Nic. Th. 36.
oily resin from trees, Gal. 13.626, Alex.Trall. 3.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: Edict.Diocl.Delph.

children.label: II
children.definition: PHolm. 5.11.
smoky, ὀδμή Nic. Th. 54.
Moer. 292, Gloss.
smoky quartz, PHolm. 10.9, cf. 4.6.
smoky, nickname of the Comic poet Ecphantides, Sch. Ar. V. 151.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst.,

κ. οἶνος, ὁ, expl. by Hsch., Phot. as wine that had a smoky taste from having been long hung up in smoke, Pherecr. 130.6, Anaxandr. 41.71 (anap.), Pl.Com. 244: perh. rather to be expld. as made from the vine κάπνειος.
κ. (sc. λίθος), ὁ, a kind of jasper, Dsc. 5.142, Plin. HN 37.118.
smoke a bee-hive, A.R. 2.131.
make smoke, i.e. make a fire, Ep. aor. 1 κάπνισσαν Il. 2.399; use as a fumigation, τροχίσκον Paul.Aeg. 3.28.

children.label: II
children.definition: smoke, blacken with smoke, D. 54.4, Sopat. 6.9, PMasp. 141 ii a 25 (vi A.D.):— Pass., to be smoked, ὁ ἠπίολος φεύγει -όμενος Arist. HA 605b16; of the eyes, suffer from smoke, Id. Pr. 957b33, cf. 896b8; of cookery, καπνιζομένη τυραννίς empire of the smoke, Demetr.Com.Nov. 1.4; κλίβανος -όμενος smoking furnace, LXX Ge. 15.17.

Act., to be black with smoke, pf. κεκάπνικα Ar. Pax 892; τὸ ὄρος τὸ καπνίζον LXX Ex. 20.18; κρύσταλλος ἡ -ίζουσα smoky quartz, PHolm. 6.38: metaph., [ θυμὸν] καπνίζοντα (v.l. -ιῶντα) καὶ διακαιόμενον Plu. Cohib. 2.454e.

children.label: II
children.definition: κάπνιος, ἡ, = καπνός II, Gal. 12.8.
exposure to smoke, Arist. Pr. 896b9.
offering of smoke, i.e. incense, AP 9.174.5 ( Pall.).
one must smoke, ‘gas’, τοὺς ἐν τοῖς μετάλλοις ὄντας Ph. Bel. 99.18.
vapour-bath, Inscr.Prien. 112.98 (i B.C.).
smoked, κρέα Posidon. 1 J.; but τροχίσκος κ. for use as a fumigation, Paul.Aeg. 3.28; κ. ἔλαιον fragrant oil, Aët. 1.138; κ. μύρον Id. 16.66(67).
smoky quartz, Alex.Trall. 1.15.

children.label: II
children.definition: καπν-ῖτις (v.l. -ίτης), = καπνός II, Ps.- Dsc. 4.109.

definition: καπνοβάτης [βᾰ], ου, ὁ, epith. of a pastoral people, dub. in Posidon. 104J.

children.definition: smoke-receiver, i.e. hole in the roof for the smoke to pass through, Hdt. 4.103, 8.137, Pherecr. 141, Eup. 133:—later καπνο-δόχη LXX Ho. 13.3 codd. AQ, Luc. Icar. 13, Gal. 2.727.
receiving smoke, Gloss.
smoke-coloured, Ael. NA 6.20.
leap, frisk, Epich. 195.
smoke-diviner, Lact.ad Stat. Theb. 4.411.
to be turned into smoke, burnt to ashes, Pi. P. 5.84, E. Supp. 497, Tr. 8.
making smoke, smoky, Sch. Ar. V. 145.

smoke, Il. 1.317, etc.; κνισάεντι καπνῷ Pi. I. 4(3).66; καπνῷ πυρός A. Ag. 497; spray, καπνοῦ καὶ κύματος ἐκτὸς ἔεργε νῆα Od. 12.219 (hence metaph., Porph. Abst. 1.47): prov., καπνοῦ σκιά, of things worth nothing, A. Fr. 399, S. Ph. 946; τἄλλʼ ἐγὼ καπνοῦ σκιᾶς οὐκ ἂν πριαίμην Id. Ant. 1170; also περὶ καπνοῦ στενολεσχεῖν Ar. Nu. 320; κ. καὶ φλυαρία Pl. R. 581d: and in pl., γραμμάτων καπνοί learned trifles, E. Hipp. 954; καπνοὺς . . καὶ σκιάς Eup. 51; nickname of a man, Id. 122: metaph. also of envy, ὕδωρ καπνῷ φέρειν to throw water on the smoking embers, Pi. N. 1.24: prov., ἐς αὐτὸ τὸ πῦρ ἐκ τοῦ καπνοῦ βιαζόμενος ‘out of the frying-pan into the fire’, Luc. Nec. 4, al.

data.quote: καπνοῦ καὶ κύματος ἐκτὸς ἔεργε νῆα
τἄλλʼ ἐγὼ καπνοῦ σκιᾶς οὐκ ἂν πριαίμην

children.label: II
children.definition: fumitory, Fumaria officinalis, Anon.Lond. 36.58, Dsc. 4.109.
smoke-sniffer, of a miser or a parasite, Com.Adesp. 1025: as pr. n., Alciphr. 3.49.
chimney, Gloss.
smoky, opp. ἀτμιδώδης, Arist. Mete. 360a10, al.; [ φλόξ] Thphr. Ign. 76; κ. καὶ συννεφὴς ἀήρ Plb. 9.16.3. Adv. -δῶς Gal. 4.507.
dark, dusky, Thphr. CP 5.3.2, Luc. Philops. 16; φύλλον δριμὺ καὶ κ. D.Chr. 66.5.
altar, Gloss.
breath, Eust. 1280.34, Hsch.:—also κάπυς, Id.; κάφος, Eust. l.c. κάπουπλος· ῥάρυγξ, Hsch.

definition: κάππα, τό, v. sub K κ.

children.definition: Cappadocians, Hdt. 5.49, etc.:—also Καππάδοκες, ων, Str. 6.4.2, etc.:—fem. Καππαδόκισσα Id. 14.2.17:—hence Καππαδοκία, Ion. -ιη, ἡ, Cappadocia, Hdt. 1.71, etc.; Καππαδοκίζω, favour the Cappadocians, App. Mith. 53:— Pass., to be Cappadocianized (with pun on Joannes Cappadox), [ Demod.] 5.

definition: καππάριον, τό, Dim. of sq., Gloss; πρὸς καππάριον ζῆν prov. in Com.Adesp. 459: καπάριον, PGen. 62.17 (iv A.D.).

children.definition: caper-plant, Capparis spinosa, or its fruit, caper, Hp. Fist. 10 (v.l. καπαρ-), Arist. Pr. 924a1, Antiph. 62, Timocl. 23, Alex. 127.6, Thphr. HP 6.5.2, PCair.Zen. 488 (iii B.C.), LXX Ec. 12.5, Dsc. 2.173, etc.; ὁ Ζήνων ὤμνυε τὴν κ. Empedus ap. Ath. 9.370c.
fish, PCair.Zen. 83 (iii B.C.).

definition: κάππαστον (i.e. κατάπαστον) · ποικίλον, Hsch. καππύτια· γυναικεῖα ἱμάτια, Id.
κάππεσον, Ep. aor. 2 Act. of καταπίπτω.

children.definition: catch fire, aor. 1 part. καππυρίσασα dub. in Theoc. 2.24.

definition: Καππώτας, α, ὁ, Ζεὺς Κ., Doric name given to a large unworked stone at Gythium on which Orestes was said to have sat down and recovered his sanity ( παύσασθαι τῆς μανίας), Paus. 3.22.1.
κάπρα αἴξ, Τυρρηνοί, Hsch.; but κάπρας· ἀκολασίας, Id.

children.definition: wild sow: metaph., lewd woman, Phryn.Com. 33, Hermipp. 10: dub. sens. in Lyr. in Philol. 80.334.
want the boar, Arist. HA 572b24: metaph., to be lecherous, καπρῶσα γραῦς Ar. Pl. 1024, cf. Men. 917.
of the wild boar, ὀδόντες Nonn. D. 18.245.
the ovary of sows, cut out to prevent their breeding, Arist. HA 632a21.

children.label: II
children.definition: virus in sows, like ἱππομανές in mares, ib. 572a21, 573b2.

children.label: III
children.definition: dance in armour, Hsch.
Ar.Byz. Epit. 145.12.

definition: καπρίδιον, τό, Dim. of κάπρος, Ar. Fr. 506.2.

children.definition: Arist. HA 572a16.
furcilla, Gloss.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj. κάπριος, ον, = κάπρειος, like a wild boar, καπρίους ἔχειν τὰς πρῴρας Hdt. 3.59.

definition: καπρίσκος, ὁ, Dim. of κάπρος, Crobyl. 7, Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 5.355f.

children.definition: Hsch.

boar, esp. wild boar, Il. 17.725, Pl. La. 196e, etc.; also σῦς κ. Il. 5.783, 17.21, cf. Ar. Lys. 202 (ubi v. Sch.); ἧπαρ κάπρου Id. Fr. 318.5: in fem. sense, sow, ὀχευομένους τοὺς κάπρους Anaxandr. 47.

children.label: II
children.definition: sea-fish, Capros aper, Philem. 79.21, Arist. HA 505a13; a species found in the Achelous, ib. 535b18. (Cogn. with Lat. caper, ONorse hafr ‘he-goat’, but not with Lat. aper.)
eating boarʼs flesh, epith. of Artemis at Samos, Hsch.
killing wild boars, κύων AP 9.83 ( Phil.).
rut, of the boar, Sciras 1.
pig-sty, IG 11(2).154 A 41 ( Delos, iii B.C.).
Anon. in Rh. 74.11, Gloss.
Gloss.

gulp down, ἐμπίδας Ar. Av. 245 (lyr.), cf. Sophr. 64; [ ἄλφιτα] Nicocl. 2; of liquids, Xenarch. 9 codd. Ath., Arist. HA 593a21; ἀφρόν ib. 620a13; κ. αὔρας Eub. 10: c. gen. partit., κ. τῶν θυλημάτων Telecl. 33: abs., ἄχρις ἑσπέρης κ. Herod. 7.41; expressing greater greediness than φαγεῖν, Ar. Ec. 687; ἡ ἄρκτος οὐδὲ σπάσει οὐδὲ λάψει ἀλλὰ κάψει Arist. HA 595a10: metaph., σευ τὸ ὥριον τέφρη κάψει Herod. 1.38. (Cogn. with Lat. capio, Germ. haben, Heft. )

data.quote: ἡ ἄρκτος οὐδὲ σπάσει οὐδὲ λάψει ἀλλὰ κάψει

definition: καπυκτά πνέοντα, Hsch. καπύνιοι· ἀκόλουθοι, Id.

children.definition: cakes, Chrysipp.Tyan. ap. Ath. 3.113d codd.:—perh. καπύρια ( καπήρια Suid.), cf. POxy. 1655.3 (iii A.D.); καπύριον, crustulum, Gloss.
live riotously, revel (cf. καπυρός II), Str. 17.1.16.
Persian gown with sleeves, Poll. 7.58.
debauchee, Str. 14.2.26.
become dry or parched, Str. 4.4.1; become crackly, Orib. Fr. 74.
dried by the air, κάρυα Epich. 150; χοιρίων σκέλη Antiph. 185; ἄλφιτον κ. Arist. Pr. 927a24, cf. Dieuch. ap. Orib. 4.7.3; τυρός Test.Epict. 5.36; χαῖται (of thistle-down) Theoc. 6.16.

children.label: b
children.definition: brittle, ὀστέον Hp. VC 19 (v.l. εὔπριστον); cj. in Thphr. HP 3.13.4 and 7 ( Comp.); crisp, crackly, Diocl. Fr. 147.
Act., drying, parching, κ. νόσος, of love, Theoc. 2.85.

children.label: II
children.definition: crackly, καπυρὸν ψοφεῖν Gal. 6.434: metaph., κ. γελάσας laughing loud, AP 7.414 ( Nossis), cf. Longus 2.5; κ. γέλως Alciphr. 3.48; κ. στόμα clear-sounding, of Poets, Theoc. 7.37; κ. συρίζειν to play clearly on the syrinx, Luc. DDeor. 2[22].3; καπυρώτεραι ᾠδαί rude songs, opp. ἐσπουδασμέναι, Ath. 15.697b.
dry, Hsch. s.v. ἴτρια, EM 479.39.
breathe forth, Ep. aor.1 κάπυσσεν Q.S. 6.523; cf. κεκαφηώς.
capon, Gloss.
κατά before ῥ, κὰρ ῥόον Il. 12.33; κάρ ῥα 20.421.
τίω δέ μιν ἐν κᾰρὸς αἴσῃ I value him at a ... ʼs worth, Il. 9.378: καρός is variously expld. by Ar.Byz. etc. ap. Sch., e.g. as = κηρός or as pr.n. Καρός.

children.label: II
children.definition: head-long (nisi junctim scrib.), Il. 16.392; ἀνὰ κάρ upwards, Hp. ap. Gal. 19.79.

definition: Κάρ, ο, gen. Κᾱρός, pl. Κᾶρες ( contr. fr. Κᾰερ-),

children.definition: Carian, Il. 2.867, etc.:—fem. Κάειρα [ᾰ] (q.v.): employed as mercenaries, καὶ δὴ ʼπίκουρος ὥστε Κὰρ κεκλήσομαι Archil. 24, cf. Ephor. 12 J.: hence prov., ἐν τῷ Καρὶ κινδυνεύειν (cf. experimentum facere in corpore vili), E. Cyc. 654, cf. Sch. Pl. La. 187b, Euthd. 285c; ἐν Καρὶ τὸν κίνδυνον . . πειρᾶσθαι Cratin. 16, cf. Philem. 18; δεῖ ἐν Καρὶ τὴν πεῖραν, οὐκ ἐν τῷ στρατηγῷ γίνεσθαι Plb. 10.32.11; ἐν τῷ Καρὶ καὶ οὐκ ἐν τοῖς ἑαυτῶν σώμασι τὰς πείρας ποιούμενοι Aristid. 1.163 J.

data.quote: καὶ δὴ ʼπίκουρος ὥστε Κὰρ κεκλήσομαι
δεῖ ἐν Καρὶ τὴν πεῖραν, οὐκ ἐν τῷ στρατηγῷ γίνεσθαι
ἐν τῷ Καρὶ καὶ οὐκ ἐν τοῖς ἑαυτῶν σώμασι τὰς πείρας ποιούμενοι

definition: κάρα (A), Ep. and Ion. κάρη [ᾰ], τό, poet. for κεφαλή, Luc. Lex. 5:—

children.definition: head, of men or animals, πολιόν τε κάρη πολιόν τε γένειον Il. 22.74; ὑψοῦ κάρη ἔχει [ ἵππος] 6.509; περὶ πόδα περὶ κάρα from head to foot, A. Eu. 165 (lyr.): metaph., ἐν δʼ ἐμῷ κάρᾳ θεός μʼ ἔπαισεν S. Ant. 1272, cf. OC 564; of the face, γέλωτι φαιδρὸν κ. Id. El. 1310; μου κ. τὸ δυσπρόσοπτον Id. OC 285.

data.quote: πολιόν τε κάρη πολιόν τε γένειον
ἐν δʼ ἐμῷ κάρᾳ θεός μʼ ἔπαισεν

children.definition: peak, top, κάρη νιφόεντος Ὀλύμπου Hes. Th. 42; of a tree, S. Fr. 23; edge, brim of a cup, Eub. 56.6.

a person, Οἰδίπου κάρα, i.e. Οἰδίπους, S. OT 40, 1207 (lyr.); αὐτάδελφον Ἰσμήνης κ. Id. Ant. 1; ὦ κασίγνητον κ., for ὦ κασίγνητε, Id. El. 1164; ὦ φίλον κ. Id. OC 1631; φίλον κ. A. Ag. 905.-- Hom. uses nom. acc. κάρη, gen. dat. κάρητος, κάρητι, Od. 6.230, Il. 15.75; also καρήατος, καρήατι, 23.44, 19.405, nom. pl. καρήατα 11.309 (whence was formed nom. sg. κάρηαρ, Antim. 76); acc. pl. κάρη Il. 10.259 (but perh. sg.), nom. acc. pl. κάρᾱ Sannyr. 3, perh. S. Ant. 291; κάρᾰ ἐξεπεφύκει h.Cer. 12; dat. pl. κάρησι f.l. in Tryph. 602:—post-Homeric Poets inflected κάρη as if it were of decl. 1, gen. κάρης Mosch. 4.74, Call. Fr. 125; dat. κάρῃ Thgn. 1024, Nic. Th. 249; acc. κάρην D.P. 562, Nic. Th. 131; Trag. dat. κάρᾳ with neut. Prons., A. Ch. 230, etc.; late acc. κάραν Anacreont. 50.9. (Cf. Skt. śiras (neut.) ‘head’, gen. śīrṣṇás, abl. śīrṣatás: κάρηνα (fr. κᾰρᾰσ-ν-α) and κράατα (perh. fr. κρᾱσ-ṇ- τα) are forms of this word, v. κάρηνον, κράς, κρανίον: cogn. with Lat. cerebrum (fr. ceres-ro-), ONorse hjarne ‘brain’, and prob. κέρας, κόρση.)
tame goat (Cret.), Hsch.; also, fig, Id. καραβαία· δίκρουν ξύλον, Id.
Dim. of κάραβος III, Hsch. s.v. ἐφόλκια, Sch. E. Hec. 631.
Hsch.

of the κάραβος kind, Arist. HA 526b26, PA 679a31.
with the face of a κάραβος, Luc. VH 1.35.
horned or cerambycid beetle, Arist. HA 531b25, 551b17 (with vv.ll. καράβιοι, καράμβιοι).

children.label: II
children.definition: crayfish, Epich. 57, Ar. Fr. 318.7, Gal. 12.313, etc.: disted. from καρκίνος, Arist. PA 684a1, cf. HA 525b32, 590b20; μαλακόστρακος ib. 490b11, cf. Specus. ap. Ath. 3.105b; an Eastern species, Nearch. ap. Arr. Ind. 29.14.

children.label: III
children.definition: light ship, EM 490.31.

children.label: VI
children.definition: gate, Hsch.
Arist. HA 607b4, GA 758a12.

definition: κάραγος ὁ τραχὺς ψόφος, οἷον πρι<όντ>ων, Hsch. καραδάλη· ἀρμενοθήκη, Id.

children.definition: wait for the outcome of, κ. τὴν μάχην, τὸν πόλεμον τῇ πεσέεται, wait to see how the battle will end, Hdt. 7.163, 168; τὸν πόλεμον κῇ ἀποβήσεται Id. 8.67; τἀκεῖθεν οἷ προβήσεται E. Med. 1117; ἀδήλους ἐλπίδας Trag.Adesp. 16; τἀνθένδε E. Heracl. 279; ἀγῶνας Id. Hel. 739; κ. ὅταν στράτευμα . . ἐξιῇ κάλως Id. Tr. 93: simply, wait for, αὔραν ἱστίοις κ. ib. 456 (troch.); παρουσίαν τινός Id. IA 1432; τἀπιόντα τραύματα Id. IT 313, etc.; τὰ προσταχθησόμενα X. Mem. 3.5.6: freq. in later Prose, κ. τὸν καιρόν Plb. 1.33.11, al.; τὸ μέλλον Cic. Att. 9.10.8; τινα Zos. 3.15, PMasp. 2.2 (vi A.D.); also κ. εἴς τινα look expectantly at one, Ar. Eq. 663.
eager expectation, Aq. Ps. 38(39).8, Pr. 10.28.

definition: Καραιός, ο, ( κάρα A) name of Zeus in Boeotia, IG 7.3208 (Orchom.), Hsch., cj. Mein. in Cratin. 111; cf. Κάριος.

children.definition: hood, AP 11.345, Edict.Diocl. 26.120:— Dim. καρα-κάλλιον, τό, Sammelb. 7033.37 (v A.D.), PMasp. 6ii64 (vi A.D.), Gloss.
Ar.Byz. Epit. 9.11, v.l. in Arist. HA 551b17.
beheading, touching the head, κ. δίκαι A. Eu. 186:—also κᾰρᾱν-ιστὴς μόρος E. Rh. 817.

definition: κάραννος κεκρύφαλος, κρήδεμνον, ἢ ἔριφος (cf. κάρνος) , ἢ ζημία (cf. κάρνη, αὐτόκαρνος), Hsch.

children.definition: a chief, X. HG 1.4.3, cj. in Anacreont. 15.3.
achieve, A. Ch. 528 ( Pass.), 705.
goat (Cret.), Hsch. κάραξι· στρώσω, Id. καραρύες, Scythian travelling-wagons, Id. καράς· ο ἀποσπερματισμός, Id. καραταί· κεφαλαί, Id.
behead, E. Rh. 586, J. BJ 1.17.8, al.:— Pass., Lyc. 313, Agath. 1.12.
beheaded, Γοργών E. Alc. 1118 (dub.l.); κ. ἐρημία νεανίδων, i. e. their slaughter, Id. Tr. 564 (lyr.); so Ἕκτορος . . κ. σφαγαί Id. Rh. 606.
cut off from the head, κ. χλιδαί oneʼs shorn locks, S. El. 52.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., beheading, c. gen., Ἑλλάδος Lyc. 187.
Hsch.
outlandish, foreign, A. Supp. 914; χείρ Id. Ag. 1061, cf. Lyc. 1387: also καρβάν, Hsch. s.v. ἐκαρβάνιζεν; acc. καρβᾶνα, αὐδάν A. Supp. 129 (lyr.).

definition: Κάρβας, name in Cyrene for the wind Εὖρος, Arist. Vent. 973b4 ( ἀπὸ τῶν Καρβανῶν τῶν κατὰ φοινίκην): Phoenician word, acc. to Thphr. Vent. 62.

children.definition: made of hide, οἰκίαι Ph. Bel. 101.31:—esp. καρβάτιναι, αἱ, shoes of undressed leather, brogues, X. An. 4.5.14, Arist. HA 499a30, Luc. Alex. 39:—also καρπάτινον, τό, Hsch.
engine of war, βάλλοντες λίθοις ἀπὸ τῶν κ. Ph. Bel. 92.28 codd. (fort. καρβατίνων (sc. οἰκιῶν)).
coal, PMasp. 58 viii 14 (vi A.D.): pl., Anon. in EN 428.13.
foreign mercenaries, Theopomp. (Hist. or Com.) ap. Paus.Gr. Fr. 222, Plb. 5.79.11 and 82.11: derived by Str. 15.3.18 from Pers. κάρδα, = τὸ ἀνδρῶδες καὶ πολεμικόν.
loaf or cake made of κάρδαμον, Trypho ap. Ath. 3.114f, Hsch., Phot.:—also καρδάμη Poll. 6.76: παρδαμάλη Phot.
to be like cress, τί καρδαμίζεις; why chatter so much about cresses, i.e. about nothing? Ar. Th. 617.
Nic. Al. 533, Plu. Tranq. 2.466d.

nose-smart, Lepidium sativum, of which the seed was eaten like mustard, X. Cyr. 1.2.8, POxy. 1429.5, Ael. VH 3.39: pl., Ar. Nu. 234; κάρδαμʼ ἐσκευασμένα Eub. 36: metaph., βλέπειν κάρδαμα look sharp and stinging, Ar. V. 455: prov. of worthless things, ὅσῳ διαφέρει σῦκα καρδάμων Henioch. 4.2.
Hsch., EM 490.53.
cardamum, Elettaria Cardamomum, Thphr. HP 9.7.2, Dsc. 1.6, etc.

children.definition: Dsc. 3.116. (For καρδαμάμωμον.)
Gloss.

definition: καρδία, ἡ, Ion. καρδίη, Ep. κρᾰδίη ( καρδίη in Hom. only in καρδίῃ ἄλληκτον πολεμίζειν ἠδὲ μάχεσθαι Il. 2.452, al., καρδία always in Trag., exc. in some dact. and anap. verses, A. Pr. 881, Th. 781, E. Med. 99, Hipp. 1274); Aeol. κάρζα EM 407.21 (but καρδία Sapph. 2.6); Cypr. κορζία (Paph.), Hsch. (fort. κόρζα):—

children.definition: heart, ἐν δέ τέ οἱ κραδίη μεγάλα στέρνοισι πατάσσει Il. 13.282; κραδίη δέ μοι ἔξω στηθέων ἐκθρῴσκει, of one panic-stricken, 10.94; πηδᾷ ἡ κ. Pl. Smp. 215e, cf. Ar. Nu. 1391 (lyr.): esp. as the seat of feeling and passion, as rage or anger, οἰδάνεται κραδίη χόλῳ Il. 9.646; τέτλαθι δή, κραδίη Od. 20.18, cf. E. Alc. 837; καρδίης πλέως full of heart, Archil. 58.4; of fear or courage, κυνὸς ὄμματʼ ἔχων, κραδίην δʼ ἐλάφοιο Il. 1.225; [ σφηκῶν] κραδίην καὶ θυμὸν ἔχοντες 16.266; ἐν μέν οἱ κραδίῃ θάρσος βάλε 21.547, etc.; ὀρχεῖται καρδία φόβῳ A. Ch. 166; θερμὴν ἐπὶ ψυχροῖσι κ. ἔχεις S. Ant. 88; τὸν νέον τίνα οἴει κ. ἴσχειν; what do you think are his feelings? Pl. R. 492c; of sorrow or joy, ἐν κραδίῃ μέγα πένθος ἄεξε Od. 17.489; κ. καὶ θυμὸς ἰάνθη 4.548; ἄχος κραδίην καὶ θυμὸν ἵκανεν Il. 2.171, cf. 10.10, B. 10.85, etc.; καρδίην ἰαίνεται Archil. 36; κελαινόχρως . . πάλλεταί μου κ. A. Supp. 785; ὦ τάλαινα κ. ψυχή τʼ ἐμή E. Or. 466; of love, Sapph. l.c., etc.; ἐκ τῆς κ. φιλεῖν Ar. Nu. 86; φιλέειν ἀπὸ κ. Theoc. 29.4 (but ἐρεῖν τἀπὸ κ. to speak freely, E. IA 475); λαλῆσαι ἐπὶ καρδίαν τινός speak kindly to . . , LXX Jd. 19.3.

data.quote: ἐν δέ τέ οἱ κραδίη μεγάλα στέρνοισι πατάσσει
κυνὸς ὄμματʼ ἔχων, κραδίην δʼ ἐλάφοιο
ἐν μέν οἱ κραδίῃ θάρσος βάλε
ὦ τάλαινα κ. ψυχή τʼ ἐμή

children.definition: inclination, desire, purpose, ἔμʼ ὀτρύνει κραδίη καὶ θυμός Il. 10.220; πρόφρων κ. ἐν πάντεσσι πόνοισι ib. 244; καρδίας δʼ ἐξίσταμαι S. Ant. 1105.

mind, ὡς ἄνοον κραδίην ἔχες Il. 21.441; κραδίη πόρφυρε Od. 4.572; κραδίη προτιόσσετʼ ὄλεθρον 5.389; εἰ θεάσῃ τοῖς τῆς καρδίας ὀφθαλμοῖς Corp.Herm. 4.11, cf. 7.2; διαλογισμοὶ ἀναβαίνουσι ἐν τῇ κ. Ev.Luc. 24.38.

data.quote: εἰ θεάσῃ τοῖς τῆς καρδίας ὀφθαλμοῖς

suffer from heartburn, Hp. Epid. 2.2.1.
suffering from heartburn, Hp. Acut. 30, Gal. 6.604.
heartburn, Gal. 8.343, al., Ruf. ap. Orib. 7.26.8.

knower of hearts, Act.Ap. 1.24, 15.8.
feasting on menʼs hearts, PMag.Par. 1.2865.
gnawing the heart, κ. ἐκ γυναικῶν κράτος (prob. for καρδίᾳ δηκτόν) A. Ag. 1471 (lyr.).
heart-shaped, σχῆμα Herm. in Phdr. p.199A.

X. An. 3.4.12 (ed. L. Dindorf).
praecordia, Gloss.
wounded in the heart, Gal. 1.112.

Hsch. s.v. καρδιοῦσθαι.
breastplate, Plb. 6.23.14.
hearten, LXX Ca. 4.9.

Hp. Prog. 24, Aph. 4.17 (pl.), Dsc. 1.7, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 2.35, etc.
have heartburn or stomach-ache, Hp. Prog. 24, Mul. 1.9, Arist. Pr. 873b29, Ael. NA 9.11, Aret. SA 2.3, prob. l. in Ar. Fr. 362.

cover of a kneading-trough, Hsch.

scooping out kneading-troughs or other wooden utensils, Crates Com. 6.
kneading-trough, Eup. 228 (pl.), Ar. Ra. 1159; κ. πλατεῖα Pl. Phd. 99b: generally, wooden vessel, Hom. Epigr. 15.6; mortar, Nic. Th. 527: Com. fem. καρδόπη, ἡ, coined by Ar. Nu. 678.
Ath. 2.70e.
Phlp. in GA 23.7, al.

definition: κάρειον [ᾰ], τό, poet. for κάρα (A), Nic. Fr. 74.51 (fort. καρήνοις).
Κάρειος, ὁ (sc. μήν), name of month in Western Locris, IG 9(1).331, BCH 22.10.
κάρζα, Aeol. for καρδία (q.v.). κάρη, κάρηαρ, v. κάρα (A).

children.definition: to be heavy in the head, drowsy, τὴν κεφαλὴν κ. Arist. PA 653a14; [ ἰχθύδια] κ. ὑπὸ τοῦ ψόφου bewildered, Id. HA 534a4; stagger as one drunken, Ph. 2.123; τῷ σώματι κ. καὶ σφάλλεσθαι Plu. Art. 11, cf. Ant. 85, Q.S. 6.266; to be top-heavy, of a spindle charged with yarn, AP 6.160 ( Antip. Sid.); μῆλα -έοντα κορύμβοις ib. 5.257 ( Paul.Sil.); have a headache, ναυτιῶντα καὶ -οῦντα ὑπὸ τοῦ σάλου Luc. Herm. 28:—also κᾰρηβᾰρ-άω Pherecr. 218 ( καραι- codd. Eust.), Thphr. Od. 46 (but -βαρεῖν HP 9.8.6), v.l. in Luc. Lex. 13; and κᾰρηβᾰρ-ιάω v.l. in Ar. Fr. 792, prob. l. in Telecl. 44, cf. Sch. Opp. H. 3.368:—the form κᾰρηβοάω, = ἰλιγγιάω is quoted by Ael.Dion. Fr. 221, and καρηβορᾶν, καρυβοᾶν are vv.ll. in Ar. l.c.
drowsy, comatose, prob. l. in Hp. Epid. 3.6, cf. Gal. 16.579.

children.label: II

heaviness in the head or headache, Polem.Hist. 83.

definition: καρηβαρία, Ion. -ιη, ἡ, = foreg., Hp. Acut. 49, Aph. 5.22, Arist. Somn.Vig. 456b29, Porph. Abst. 1.28, Agath. 2.38; κ. βάκτρου, paraphrase for a ‘knobby’ stick, AP 9.249 ( Maec.).

children.definition: subject to headache, Hp. Epid. 3.17.ϛʹ; τὸ -κόν, = καρηβαρία, Telecl. 47.

with hair on the head, long-haired, epith. of the Achaians, Il. 2.11, al. (sed divisim scrib.): Com. metaph., ἐχῖνοι κ. ἀκάνθαις Matro Conv. 18:—hence Verb καρηκομόω, coined by Diog. Ep. 19.

definition: καρῆναι, aor. 2 inf. Pass. of κείρω.
κάρηνον [ᾰ], τό, Dor. κάρᾱνον A. Ch. 396 (lyr.), Mosch. 1.12 ( Ion. κάρηνον 2.87); in derivs. the ᾱ prevails: (v. κάρα A):—

children.definition: head, mostly in pl. (as always in Hom.), ἀνδρῶν κάρηνα, periphr. for ἄνδρες, Il. 11.500; νεκύων ἀμενηνὰ κ. Od. 10.521, etc.; βοῶν ἴφθιμα κ. Il. 23.260; ἵππων ξανθὰ κ. 9.407: metaph., of mountain peaks, Οὐλύμποιο κ. 1.44, etc.; of towns, πολλάων πολίων κατέλυσε κάρηνα 2.117, 9.24; Μυκάλης αἰπεινὰ κ. 2.869: in pl., of a single person, κάρηνα . . Μελανίππου σπάσας E. Fr. 537: sg. in h.Hom. 8.12, 28.8, Mosch.ll. cc., Coluth. 264, Anacreont. 1.11.
Hsch.
wages for clipping or shearing, Edict.Diocl. 7.20; cf. κάρτρα.
Hdn.Gr. 1.354; ἀπὸ κάρεως ἀναθυμίασις perh. caraway, Gal. 17(1).563; cf. κάρον, καρώ.

definition: καριδάριον, τό, Dim. of καρίς, Anaxandr. 27 (anap.):—also κᾱρίδιον, τό, Arist. HA 547b17.

kill, Hsch.

V. 1522 (lyr.), Cratin. 283, Eup. 7, 107: later ῑ, gen. ῖδος, Arar. 8, Anaxandr. 22, Eub. 78, Archestr. Fr. 25, Numen. ap. Ath. 7.287c.]

quake, of the earth, κάρκαιρε δὲ γαῖα πόδεσσιν ὀρνυμένων Il. 20.157.

children.definition: ἐκάρκαιρεν· ἐπλήθυεν, and ἐκάρκαιρον· ψόφον τινὰ ἀπετέλουν, Hsch.
ἐπιτυρά cod.), Semon. 33.
load of timber, Hsch. κάρκαροι· τραχεῖς, Id.
prison, Sophr. 147:—also κάρκᾰρος, ὁ, D.S. 31.9: indeterm. in Vett.Val. 68.26: pl. κάρκαροι, = δεσμοί, and κάρκαρα, = μάνδραι, Hsch.
Dim. of καρκίνος I, Gal. 6.717, Ael. NA 7.31, Artem. 2.14, Opp. C. 2.286, H. 1.320.
crab-catcher, Artem. 2.14.
Polygonum, Gloss.; f.l. for -ωθρον, Dsc. 4.4.
crab-coloured gem, Plin. HN 37.187.
Dim. of καρκίνος, hermit-crab, Pagurus, Arist. HA 529b20; a smaller species, ib. 547b17.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hp. Morb. 2.37.

children.label: III
children.definition: slipper, in pl., Herod. 7.128.
walking like a crab, Aristonym. 2 (sed leg. καρκινοβήτης).
of the crab kind, τὰ κ. Arist. PA 684a14, cf. Ael. NA 6.20.

children.label: II
children.definition: like a still, Zos.Alch. p.140 B. (cf. intr. p.149B.).
crab-footed, i.e. lame, IG 3.171a.

definition: καρκίνος [ῐ], ὁ, heterocl. pl. καρκίνα (v. sub. fin.: on the accent v. Hdn.Gr. 2.926):—

children.definition: crab, Epich. 53, Hellanic. 103 J., S. Ichn. 298, Ar. Eq. 608, Pl. Euthd. 297c, Batr. 299; κ. ποδήνεμοι Crates Com. 29.3: various species distinguished, Arist. HA 525a34, cf. 601a17, al.: prov., οὔποτε ποιήσεις τὸν καρκίνον ὀρθὰ βαδίζειν Ar. Pax 1083; εἴς μʼ ὁρεῦσα καρκίνου μέζον ‘with saucer-eyes’, Herod. 4.44.

data.quote: οὔποτε ποιήσεις τὸν καρκίνον ὀρθὰ βαδίζειν

children.label: II
children.definition: Cancer, as a sign in the zodiac, Eudox. ap. Hipparch. 1.2.18, Euc. Phaen. p.10 M., Arat. 147, etc.

children.label: III
children.definition: eating sore or ulcer, cancer, = καρκίνωμα, Hp. Aph. 6.38, D. 25.95, Gal. 10.83.

pair of pincers, Aen.Tact. 20.3, 32.5, IG ΙΙ(2).165.11 ( Delos, iii B.C.), AP 6.92 ( Phil.), Ath. 10.456d; κ. σιδηροῦς POxy. 521.14 (ii A.D.); used as an instrument of torture, D.S. 20.71: in Surgery, forceps, κ. ἰατρικός IG 2(2).47.16: metaph., λήψεται τὸν τράχηλον ἐντόνως ὁ κ. E. Cyc. 609.
Poll. 2.85.
shoe, Pherecr. 178.
bandage, Heliod. ap. Orib. 48.54 tit., Gal. 18(1).777.
pair of compasses, Ph. Bel. 55.25, Ph. 2.192, Gal. Opt.Doctr. 3, S.E. M. 10.54: heterocl. pl., καρκίνα σπειροῦχα AP 6.295.5 ( Phan.).
still, implied in καρκινοειδής II (q. v.).

children.label: V
children.definition: Καρκίνου ποιήματα, = τὰ αἰνιγματώδη, Men. 525; Megarian pr. n. Κερκίνος SIG 201.12 (iv B.C.). (Cf. Lat. cancer, Skt. karkaṭas ‘crab’.)
with crabʼs claws for hands, Luc. VH 1.35.

make crab-like, κ. τοὺς δακτύλους crook oneʼs fingers like crabʼs claws, Antiph. 55.15:— Pass., of roots, spread crab-wise, Thphr. HP 1.6.3, CP 3.21.5:—also in Act., cause to spread, ὁ χειμὼν πιλώσας καὶ καρκινώσας τὰς ῥίζας ib. 3.23.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., also, suffer from cancer, Hp. Nat.Mul. 31; become cancerous, ἐκινδύνευσεν καρκινωθῆναι τὰ ἕλκεα Id. Mul. 1.40.
Arist. PA 683b31, Plu. Sollert. 2.980b.

children.label: II
children.definition: cancerous, Dsc. Eup. 2.72, Ruf. ap. Orib. 45.11.1; ὄγκος Gal. 18(1).80, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.92.
Nic. Th. 902; = πολύγονον ἄρρεν, prob. in Dsc. 4.4.
Hp. Epid. 5.101, 7.111, Xenophon Med. ap. Ruf. ap. Orib. 45.11.2, Dsc. 2.10, Plu. Adul. 2.65d.
formation of a cancerous growth, Aët. 16.41 (pl.).
wool shorn off, Hsch.; cream skimmed off, Id.
caraway, Carum Carui, Gp. 9.28.2.

definition: Καρνεᾶται, οἱ (cf. sq. [Καρνειάσιον, Κάρνειος]), unmarried ministrants of Apollo, Hsch.

children.definition: grove sacred to Apollo Carneus, IG 5(1).1390.54, al. ( Andania, i B. C.): written Καρνάσιον in Paus. 4.33.5, al.

definition: Κάρνειος, ὁ, ( κάρνος) title of Apollo in Peloponnesus, Pi. P. 5.80, Call. Ap. 71, etc.:—hence Κάρνεια, τά, ( Κάρνεα metri gr., Theoc. 5.83)

children.definition: festival held in his honour by Dorians, esp. by the Spartans, Hdt. 7.206, Th. 5.75, SIG 735.25 ( Argos, i B.C.), etc.; τὰ Κ. νικᾶν Ath. 14.635e; πανηγυρίζειν Plu. Herod. 2.873e:— Κάρνειος or Καρνήϊος, ὁ (sc. μήν), name of month in which the festival was held, E. Alc. 449 (lyr.), Th. 5.54, cf. IG 4.1485 (Epid.), GDI 5009 ( Crete), etc.; Κάρνειαι θυσίαι at Argos, IG 4.620.

definition: κάρνειος Δωρικός dub. l. in Thphr. HP 3.16.4.

children.definition: victor in the Carnean games, IG 5(1).82, 209 ( Sparta): in pl., Κ., οἱ, title of work by Hellanicus.
Gallic horn, Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: cart, PFlor. 140.2, al. (iii A.D.):—hence καρνάριος, ὁ, carter, ib. 207.5, al.

definition: κάρνος, ὁ, (cf. κέρας) expld. by Hsch. as βόσκημα, πρόβατον, i.e.

children.definition: ram:—hence καρνοστάσιον, τό, pen, fold, Id.

children.label: II
children.definition: = φθειρ, Id.
sweet wine boiled down, καροίνου Μεονίου Edict.Diocl. 2.13 ( v.l. καρυηνου), cf. Hippiatr. 2, Gloss.; οἶνος Καρύϊνος produced in Maeonia, Gal. 15.632, 6.801, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἀβόλλης, χιτὼν καρόϊνος perh. = καρύϊνος, nut-brown, Stud.Pal. 20.46.13 (iii A.D.), cf. POxy. 929.9 (ii/iii A.D.), unless a geographical name, cf. I.
Head and Tail of Dragon ( Οὐροβόρος), Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.123.
Theb.Ostr. 135 (i A.D.); also v.l. for καρώ, Dsc. 3.57.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch.

definition: κάροπερ ἔπακμος παῖς, Hsch. καρορύς· ὕδρα (Cret.), Id.

children.definition: heavy sleep, torpor, κ. καὶ κραιπάλη Arist. Pr. 873b14, cf. A.R. 2.203, Phld. D. 1.18, Str. 16.4.19, Max.Tyr. 16.1, Gal. 8.231; κάρῳ προσφερὴς κατάληψις Iamb. Myst. 3.2: pl., μελαγχολίαι καὶ κάροι καὶ λήθαργοι Stoic. 3.57; drowsiness, Luc. Am. 39.

definition: καρός κωφός, οἱ δὲ σκοτόδινος, Hsch. κάρουα, Lacon.,

children.definition: carruca, carriage, Sm. Is. 66.20, Sch. E. Ph. 847:— also καρ-οῦχον, τό, Edict.Diocl. 15.37:— Dim. καρ-ούχιον, τό, PFlor. 335.8 (iii A. D.), Gloss.:—also καρ-ουχάριος, cisiarius, mulio, ib.
soporiferous, Gloss.

plunge into deep sleep or torpor, stun, stupefy, πληγαὶ καροῦσαι Hp. Art. 30; of wine, Antipho Soph. 34, Anaxandr. 3, cf. Ath. 1.33a; ὀδμὴ καροῦσα a stupefying smell, Id. 15.675d:— Pass., to be stupefied, ὑπὸ βροντῆς, of certain fish, Arist. HA 602b23; ὑπὸ μύρου, of bees, Id. Mir. 832a3; ὑπὸ τῶν εὐωδιῶν Str. 16.4.19; θανάτῳ κεκαρωμένα . . πέλωρα Theoc. 24.59; τραύμασι D.H. 3.19, cf. Plu. Art. 11; τὴν διάνοιαν D.H. Th. 34; of drunken sleep, LXX Je. 28(51).39.
mimic dance of the Thessalians, in which a peasant scuffles with a cattle-stealer, τὴν καρπαίαν . . ἐν τοῖς ὅπλοις ὀρχεῖσθαι X. An. 6.1.7, cf. Ath. 1.15f:—also κάρπεα, ἡ, Maced., acc. to Hsch.

definition: καρπάλιμος [πᾰ], ον, ( κάλπη A) Ep. Adj.

children.definition: swift, πόδες Il. 16.342, 809, A.R. 3.280, cf. Ar. Th. 957 (lyr.): more freq. in Adv. -μως swiftly, Il. 1.359, etc.
eager, ravenous, γένυες Pi. P. 12.20.
made of κάρπασος, LXX Es. 1.6, Str. 7.2.3, D.H. 2.68.
flax, CPR 61.13 (iii A.D.):—but λίνον Καρπάσιον,
asbestos (from Carpasia in Cyprus), Paus. 1.26.7.

definition: κάρπασος, ἡ, with heterocl. pl. κάρπασα, AP 9.415.6 ( Antiphil., with play on the meanings ‘sails’ and ‘clothesʼ); also κάλπᾰσος (q.v.):—

children.definition: flax, Linum usitatissimum (or perh. L. angustifolium), D.H. 2.68, Sch. Ar. Lys. 736.
cotton, Peripl.M.Rubr. 41 (cf. Skt. karpāsas).

children.label: II
children.definition: κάρπασον, τό, white hellebore, Veratrum album, Orph. A. 922; ὀπὸς καρπάσου Archig. ap. Gal. 12.445, Dsc. Alex. 13; sucus carpathi, Plin. HN 32.58; cf. ὀποκάρπασον, καρπησία.

usufruct, enjoyment, Plb. 31.21.8, Test.Epict. 3.5, v.l. in Ph. 2.380; τῶν κρεῶν IG 12(5).721 ( Andros): in pl., profits or emoluments of an office, PEleph. 14.13 (iii B.C.), PTeb. 6.34 (ii B.C.), etc.
Nic. Al. 277: pl., Ar. Fr. 177; = καρπεία, Πρακτικὰ τῆς Ἀκαδ. Ἀθηνῶν 1928.109 ( Epid., iii/ii B.C.).
fruit, in pl., dub. in Sosith. 2.17.

enjoy the fruits of, χώραν Hyp. Fr. 107, IG 9(1).693.3 (Corc.), cf. Plb. 10.28.3: generally, profit by, Gal. 9.790: abs., SIG 1044.18 ( Halic., iv/iii B.C.):— Med., Supp.Epigr. 3.378 B30 ( Delph., ii/i B.C.).

definition: καρπέω, inf. καρπεῖν· πληώττειν, Hsch. κάρπη· τὰ σπέρματα· καὶ τήγανα ὀβελίσκους ἔχοντα, Id. κάρπημα, ατος, τό,

children.definition: an aromatic plant, Valeriana Dioscoridis, chiefly brought from Asia, Gal. 12.15, Alex.Trall. 9.1:—but καρπησία, ἡ, = κάρπασος II, Paul.Aeg. 5.44.

enjoy the fruits of, IG 12(5).243 ( Paros):— elsewh. always in Med., κ. γῆν Theopomp.Hist. 217b; κλῆρον PFrankf. 7.7 (iii B.C.), cf. Hyp. Fr. 119, LXX Jo. 5.12, IG 5(2).419.14 ( Phigalea, iii B.C.), ib. 7.413.28, al. ( Oropus, i B.C.), etc.; χρόνον Epicur. Ep. 3p.61U.; but also, exhaust the soil, καρπίζεται τὴν γῆν μάλιστα πυρός Thphr. HP 8.9.1, cf. CP 4.8.1: metaph., δόξαν ἐσθλήν E. Hipp. 432; κῦδος ἐκαρπίσατο Epigr.Gr. 516.4 ( Aegae), cf. Supp.Epigr. 3.781 ( Gortyn); exploit, BGU 1571 (i A.D.); βέλτιον ἐμὲ (sc. τὴν σοφίαν) καρπίζεσθαι ὑπὲρ χρυσίον LXX Pr. 8.19.

children.label: II
children.definition: make fruitful, fertilize, E. Ba. 408 (lyr.), Hel. 1328 (lyr.).
enfranchise a slave by touching him with the rod, καρπίζομαι ἐπὶ ἐλευθερίᾳ, = Lat. adseror, Gloss.

fruit-bearing, fruitful, θέρος A. Pr. 455; στάχυς, πέδον, E. Supp. 31, Or. 1086; καρπίμους ἐτῶν κύκλους Id. Hel. 112; μυρρίναι Ar. Pax 1154; κισσοῦ κλάδοι Alex. 119.5; ξύλον LXX Ge. 1.11; κάρπιμα πρῷα early crops, Ar. V. 264; θερίσαι κάρπιμα to reap the fruits, CIG 4310.15 ( Limyra), cf. PSI 4.292.13 (iii A.D.); κ. [ ἀγαθά] property that yields a produce, opp. ἀπολαυστικά, Arist. Rh. 1361a17; opp. ἄκαρπα, Id. EN 1125a12: metaph., ἀμέλγεις τῶν ξένων τοὺς κ. from whom money can be wrung, Ar. Eq. 326.

definition: καρπίον, τό, Dim. of καρπός (A), Thphr. Od. 32, BGU 1120.50 (i B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: ἐλλέβορος, Hippiatr. 11.

children.label: III
children.definition: καρπία· κλονία (fort. κλωνία), Hsch.
screw-pine, Pandanus odoratissimus, Ctes. Fr. 57.28.

definition: Κάρπιος, ὁ, variant for Ἐπικάρπιος, title of Zeus in Arist. Mu. 401a19 (ap. Stob. 1.1.36).

children.definition: exhaustion, τῆς γῆς Thphr. CP 4.8.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: profit, Arist. Pr. 952b6.

definition: καρπισμός (B), ὁ, ( καρπίζω B), καρπ-ιστεία and καρπ-ιστία, ἡ,

children.definition: = Lat. vindiciae, Gloss.
emancipator, Arr. Epict. 3.24.76, 4.1.113.
connected with emancipation, Gloss.; of a suit, = liberale judicium, ib.
the fruit of the balsam, Gal. 14.166, v.l. in Dsc. 1.58.
with edible fruit, ξύλον LXX De. 20.20.
to be productive, bear fruit, Thphr. HP 9.1.1, CP 3.9.2, Porph. Abst. 4.20.
productiveness, X. Smp. 2.25, Thphr. CP 1.5.5, Sor. 1.42 (pl.), Lib. Or. 25.67, Aen.Gaz. Thphr. p.54B.
bearing fruit, Dsc. 5.141, prob. in Lyr. in Philol. 80.338.
distributor of produce, GDI 4993 ( Gortyn).
chains for the arms, armlets, Luc. Lex. 10:
bandage for wrist, Sor. Fasc. 50, Cass.Fel. 24.
wearing a knee-halter, Horap. 2.78.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. -δέσμιον, τό, armlet, POxy. 1153.13 (i A.D.).
giver of fruit, Orph. H. 43.9.
gather fruit, SIG 1000.29 ( Cos):—in Pass., of trees, Thphr. CP 1.15.1.
gathering of fruit, Gp. 10.78.1.
gathering fruit, Polyaen. 3.10.9.
bearing fruit, of Demeter, cj. for καρποδόχος in AP 12.225 ( Strat.).
running to fruit, luxuriant, S. Fr. 652.
making fruit, of Demeter, E. Rh. 964:— later καρπο-ποιητικός Phlp. in GA 193.21.

fruit, in Hom. and Hes. (only in sg.), usu. of the fruits of the earth, corn, ἀρούρης κ. Il. 6.142; κ. δʼ ἔφερε ζείδωρος ἄρουρα Hes. Op. 117; κ. Δήμητρος Hdt. 1.193, etc.; Δηοῦς Ar. Pl. 515; κ. ἀρούρης, also of wine, Il. 3.246; ἀμπέλινος κ. Hdt. 1.212; so κ. alone, Ar. Nu. 1119 (codd. and Sch.); but of corn, opp. Βάκχιον νᾶμα, Id. Ec. 14; καρποῦ ξυγκομιδή harvest, Th. 3.15; κ. λωτοῖο, κρανείης, Od. 9.94, 10.242; μελιηδέα κ., of grapes, Il. 18.568; κ. ἐλαίας Pi. N. 10.35; τὸν ἐπέτειον κ. the crops of the year, Pi. P. 470b: generally, produce, κ. ὑγρός, of honey, Porph. Abst. 2.20; also κ. εὐανθὴς μήλων, of wool, Opp. H. 2.22: pl., καρπῶν ἐστερήθητε διξῶν robbed of two years’ produce, Hdt. 8.142; καρπῶν ἀτελεῖς Id. 6.46; κ. ὑγροὶ καὶ ξηροί produce of trees and fields, X. Oec. 5.20; ξύλινοι, σιτικοὶ κ., Str. 5.4.2; of fruits offered in sacrifice, BMus.Inscr. 975.7 ( Amathus), cf. κάρπωσις II; also of taxes paid in kind, opp. χρυσικά, PHib. 1.47.5 (iii B.C.), al.
seed, X. Oec. 16.12; defined as seed with seed-vessel, Thphr. HP 1.2.1.
Δῖοι κ. offspring of Zeus, E. Ion 922 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: returns, profits, οἱ κ. οἱ ἐκ τῶν ἀγελῶν γενόμενοι X. Cyr. 1.1.2; τῶν ἀνηλωμένων . . τοὺς κ. Is. 5.29.

data.quote: οἱ κ. οἱ ἐκ τῶν ἀγελῶν γενόμενοι

children.label: III
children.definition: fruit, profit, εἰ κ. ἔσται θεσφάτοισι Λοξίου if his oracles shall bear fruit, i.e. be fulfilled, A. Th. 618; γλώσσης ματαίας κ., i. e. curses, Id. Eu. 831 codd.; ὁμιλίας κακῆς κάκιον οὐδέν, κ. οὐ κομιστέος Id. Th. 600; οὐκ ἐξάγουσι καρπὸν οἱ ψευδεῖς λόγοι S. Fr. 834, cf. Pl. Phdr. 260d: freq. in Pi., κ. ἐπέων οὐ κατέφθινε, i. e. poesy, I. 8(7).50; κ. φρενῶν wisdom, P. 2.74; κ. φρενός, of his own ode, O. 7.8; ἥβας κ., of the bloom of youth, ib. 6.58, P. 9.109; later, reward, profit, ἐπιτηδευμάτων Epicur. Sent.Vat. 27; ὅπου ὁ κίνδυνος μέγας, καὶ ὁ κ. Diog.Oen. 27; κ. νίκης Hdn. 8.3.6: freq. in NT, κ. εἰρηνικὸς δικαιοσύνης Ep.Hebr. 12.11, etc. (Cf. Lat. carpo, Engl. harvest.)

data.quote: ὁμιλίας κακῆς κάκιον οὐδέν, κ. οὐ κομιστέος
οὐκ ἐξάγουσι καρπὸν οἱ ψευδεῖς λόγοι

children.definition: wrist, Il. 24.671, Od. 24.398, Hp. Fract. 3, Arist. HA 494a2, etc.; ἐπὶ καρπῷ χερός E. Ion 1009; καρποὶ χειρῶν ib. 891, cf. X. Cyr. 6.4.2. (Perh. cf. ONorse huerfa ‘turn round’.)
sowing fruit, Man. 4.256.
bringing fruit to perfection, fruitful, A. Supp. 688.

definition: καρποτόκεια, ἡ, poet. fem. of καρποτόκος, Nonn. D. 21.26.

children.definition: bear fruit, Thphr. CP 5.2.3, Ph. 1.444.
bearing of fruit, Thphr. HP 1.2.1, CP 2.1.2 (pl.).
bearing fruit, epith. of Demeter, v.l. in AP 12.225 ( Strat.), of Isis, APl. 16.264: metaph., Ph. 1.53.
rearing or ripening fruit, δρῦς Lyc. 1423: metaph., ἧβαι E. Ion 475 (lyr.); epith. of Demeter, Milet. 7.64; of the clouds, Orph. H. 21.1.
live on fruit, Arist. HA 593a15; κ. πρώτης δρυός Porph. Abst. 2.5.
living on fruit, opp. σαρκοφάγος, παμφάγος, ζῷα Arist. HA 488a15, cf. Pol. 1256a25, Max.Tyr. 35.7.
spoiling fruit, δένδρων AP 9.256 ( Antiphan.), cf. Orph. Fr. 285.55.

bear fruit, X. Vect. 1.3, Arist. GA 755b10, Ph. 1.602, al., Orph. Fr. 255: metaph., of virtue, Ph. 1.154; τῷ θεῷ Ep.Rom. 7.4; also τῷ θανάτῳ ib. 5:— Med., Ep.Col. 1.6, BMus.Inscr. 918 (Halic.):— Pass., Ptol. Tetr. 80.
fruit borne, Eust. 1572.33.
fruit-bearing, Ocell. 4.9 (pl.), Ph. 1.105, Cod.Just. 1.3.38.2 (pl.).

fruit-bearing, fruitful, of trees, Hdt. 1.193, 2.156, X. Cyr. 6.2.22, etc.; of lands, Λιβύα, πεδία, Pi. P. 4.6, E. Hel. 1485 (lyr.); τῇ κ. γαίῃ Sammelb. 6598 (iii A. D.), al.; of Demeter, τὴν κ. βασίλειαν Ar. Ra. 384 (lyr.), cf. Paus. 8.53.7, CIG 4082 ( Pessinus), IG 12(5).226 ( Paros), SIG 820.5 ( Ephesus, i A. D.): hence of Agrippina, IG 12(2).212 ( Mytilene), IGRom. 4.1300 (Aeolis, in fem. -φόρα) ; κ. καιροί Act.Ap. 14.17.
watcher of fruit, AP 6.22 ( Zonas).
Plin. HN 15.131.

definition: καρπόχειρ, late word for μετακάρπιον, Eust. 1572.38.

children.definition: bear fruit or bear as fruit, metaph., ὕβρις γὰρ ἐξανθοῦσʼ ἐκάρπωσε στάχυν ἄτης A. Pers. 821:— Pass., τὰ πλεῖστα τῶν ῥιζοφύτων καρπωθέντα Ocell. 1.13.

data.quote: ὕβρις γὰρ ἐξανθοῦσʼ ἐκάρπωσε στάχυν ἄτης

children.definition: offer by way of sacrifice, LXX Le. 2.11; ἐπὶ τοῦ βωμοῦ, of burnt-offerings, SIG 1025.33 ( Cos, iv/iii B. C.):—so in Pass., ib. 997.9 ( Smyrna), cf. Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: take as fruit or produce, LXX De. 26.14:—elsewh. in Med., καρπόομαι get fruit for oneself, i.e.,

reap crops from, c. acc. rei, [ ἀρούρας] Hdt. 2.168; χθόνα A. Pr. 851, Supp. 253; δὶς τοῦ ἐνιαυτοῦ τὴν γῆν καρποῦσθαι to crop the land twice a year, Pl. Criti. 118e: metaph., βαθεῖαν ἄλοκα διὰ φρενὸς καρπούμενος A. Th. 593: hence, exhaust, drain, exploit, καρπουμένῳ τὴν Ἑλλάδα Ar. V. 520, cf. Isoc. 4.133,166; οὐσίας D. 19.249.

enjoy the usufruct or interest of money, ἔδωκεν ἑβδομήκοντα μνᾶς καρπώσασθαι Id. 27.5; τοὺς λιμένας καὶ τὰς ἀγορὰς καρποῦσθαι to derive profits from . . , Id. 1.22; ἔθνη X. HG 6.1.12; ἰδία κ. τὰς τῆς πόλεως συμφοράς Lys. 25.25; [ πλεονεξίαν] D. 23.126: in pf. Pass., τὸ ἐργαστήριον κεκαρπωμένος having enjoyed the profits of the shop, Id. 27.47: abs., make profit, Ar. Ach. 837.

data.quote: ἰδία κ. τὰς τῆς πόλεως συμφοράς

children.definition: enjoy the free use of, τὰ αὐτοῦ ἀγαθὰ γιγνόμενα Th. 2.38; τὴν τῶν πολεμίων [ χώραν], τὰς τῶν θεῶν τιμάς, X. Ages. 1.34; τὴν οἰκείαν ἀδεῶς κ. D. 1.25, cf. 28.

enjoy, ἄελπτον ὄμμα . . φήμης S. Tr. 204; τἀμὰ . . λέχη E. Andr. 935; ἐλευθερίαν Th. 7.68; τὴν σοφίαν Pl. Euthd. 305e; ἡδονὴν ταύτην Id. Phdr. 252a, cf. 240a, etc.; ἀσφάλειαν καὶ εὔκλειαν X. Cyr. 8.2.22; τὴν δόξαν τινός D. 20.69; τὴν ἡλικίαν Id. 59.19; δωρεάς Plu. Them. 31: in bad sense, ἰδίας καρποῦσθαι λύπας Hp. Flat. 1; φρενῶν τὴν ἁμαρτίαν A. Ag. 502; τὰ ψευδῆ καλά ib. 621; πένθη E. Hipp. 1427; ἄπαιδα κ. βίον Id. Fr. 571.3; τὰ μέγιστα ὀνείδη Pl. Smp. 183a; λοιδορίας Phld. Vit. p.34J.
Indian plant, Clitopho ap. Stob. 4.36.22.

definition: καρπυραί ξύλων ξηρῶν κοῖται, Hsch.; cf. καρφηρός.

fruit, A. Supp. 1001; profit, Hsch.

fruit-buying, PLond.ined. 2338 (iii B. C.), BGU 830.8 (i A. D.).
yielding fruit, profitable, Hermipp.Hist. 81.
use, profit, X. Cyr. 4.5.16.

children.definition: offering of fruits, LXX Le. 4.10, al., IG 3.77 (pl., ii A. D.); sacrifice to Aphrodite at Amathus, Hsch.
reaching to the wrist, κ. χιτών a coat with sleeves down to the wrist, LXX 2 Ki. 13.18, 19.
sufficient to fill a wagon, γόμος OGI 629.16 ( Palmyra, ii A. D.).
covinnus, Gloss.
car, cart, LXX 1 Es. 5.55 (cod. A), PGoodsp.Cair. 30xxix 21 (ii A. D.), Edict.Diocl. 15.38a: κάρρος, ὁ, ib. 39:—hence καρροπηγός, ὁ, and καρρο-ποιός, ὁ, coach-builder, Gloss.

stronger, better, Dor. for κρείσσων, Alcm. 89, Epich. 165, Sophr. 59, Ti.Locr. 94c, AP 7.413.7 (Antip.), Plu. Lyc. 25; κάρρον ἐστίν c. inf., it is better to . . , Cerc. 5.13:—hence καρρόθεν, Adv. from something better, Dam. ap. Suid. s.v. κάρρων.
crosswise, Hsch. Adv. -ίως Suid.; cf. ἐγκάρσιος.

definition: κάρτα (cf. κράτος), Adv., freq. in Ion. and Trag., rare in Com. and Att. Prose (v. infr.):—with Adjs. and Advbs.,

children.definition: very, extremely; with Verbs, very much; κ. κακῶς ῥιγῶ Hippon. 16; ἐσθλοὺς κ. μαχητάς Aristeas Epic. Fr. 3 [5 Bernabé]; κ. ἀπὸ θερμέων χωρέων very hot, Hdt. 2.27; κ. θεραπεύειν τινά, opp. μετρίως, Id. 3.80; κ. δεόμενος Id. 8.59; κ. ὀξύ Hp. Acut. 58; κ. πρευμενεῖς A. Ag. 840; κ. ἰδεῖν ὁμόπτερος Id. Ch. 174; εἰ καὶ μακρὰ κ. ἐστίν S. Tr. 1218; ὥς σου κ. νῦν μνείαν ἔχω E. Med. 328, cf. 222, etc.; once in Pl., πηλοῦ κ. βραχέος Ti. 25d; ληρεῖς ἔχων κ. Ar. Av. 342 (troch.).

data.quote: ὥς σου κ. νῦν μνείαν ἔχω

children.definition: surely, in very deed, κ. δʼ ἔστʼ ἐγχώριος A. Th. 413; κ. δʼ ὢν ἐπώνυμος true to thy name, Id. Eu. 90, cf. Th. 658; κ. δʼ εἰμὶ τοῦ πατρός all on the fatherʼs side, Id. Eu. 738; κ. δʼ εἴσʼ ὅμαιμοι Id. Th. 939 (lyr.); ἦ κ. Id. Ag. 592, 1252, S. El. 312, 1278, etc.; σὺ δὲ κ. φείδῃ Amips. 22.

καὶ κ., used to increase the force of a previous statement, τὰ ἀνέκαθεν λαμπροί, ἀπὸ δὲ Ἀλκμέωνος . . καὶ κ. λαμπροί Hdt. 6.125; esp. in dialogue, yes, verily, ἦ γάρ τινες ναίουσι . . ; Answ. καὶ κ. . . S. OC 65; ἆρʼ ἄν τί μου δέξαιο . . ; Answ. καὶ κάρτα γ E. Hipp. 90; once in Ar., καὶ κ. μέντἂν . . καθείλκετε Ach. 544; in Hdt. also, τὸ κ. 1.71, 4.181; esp. with a slightly iron. sense, with a vengeance, ἐς ὃ δὴ καὶ τὸ κ. ἐπύθοντο 1.191, cf. 3.104, 6.52.

data.quote: τὰ ἀνέκαθεν λαμπροί, ἀπὸ δὲ Ἀλκμέωνος . . καὶ κ. λαμπροί
ἐς ὃ δὴ καὶ τὸ κ. ἐπύθοντο

children.definition: Hsch.
Ael. NA 16.20.

definition: καρταίπους, ὁ, ἡ, πουν, τό, gen. ποδος,

children.definition: Pi. O. 13.81: neut. pl., καρταίποδα, τά, larger cattle, beasts, Leg.Gort. 4.36, al.: sg., καρταῖπος, τό, GDI 4998i 17 ( Gortyn), al.
Lyd. Mag. 2.13:— Dim. καρταλ-άμιον, τό, = fiscella, Gloss.

basket with pointed bottom, LXX 4 Ki. 10.7, al., Sammelb. 6801.4 (iii B. C.), Ph. 1.694, Hsch.; also, of a feast, Ph. 2.298 ( κάρταλος cod.):— Dim. καρτάλλιον, τό, Sammelb. 6801.26 (iii B. C.), Gloss.; cf. κερτύλλιον.
one must shear, Muson. Fr. 21p.115H.

to be steadfast, patient, S. Ph. 1274, Men. Sam. 112, etc.; ῥᾷον παραινεῖν ἢ παθόντα καρτερεῖν E. Alc. 1078, cf. Th. 7.64; κ. μάχῃ E. Heracl. 837; κ. ἐλπίδι τινός Th. 2.44: freq. with a Prep., κ. πρός τι to hold up against a thing, e.g. πρὸς ἡδονάς τε καὶ λύπας Pl. R. 556c; πρὸς λιμὸν καὶ ῥῖγος X. Cyr. 2.3.13; ἐπὶ τοῖς παροῦσι Isoc. 6.48, cf. Pl. La. 194a; κ. ἐν ταῖς ἡδοναῖς to be patient or temperate in . . , Id. Lg. 635c; ἐν πολέμῳ Id. La. 193a; κ. ἀπὸ τοῦ ὕπνου refrain therefrom, Ael. NA 13.13: c. part., persevere in doing, οἱ δʼ ἐκαρτέρουν πρὸς κῦμα λακτίζοντες E. IT 1395; κ. ἀναλίσκων ἀργύριον φρονίμως Pl. La. 192e; ἀκούων Aeschin. 3.241; κ. ἐν ἐπιτηδεύμασιν Isoc. 2.32; also τὰ δείνʼ ἐκαρτέρουν was strangely obdurate or obstinate, S. Aj. 650: in later Prose meaning little more than wait, καρτέρει καὶ θεώρει wait and see, LXX 2 Ma. 7.17; οὐ κ. μέχρι θαλάμων ἐλθεῖν S.E. M. 1.291.

data.quote: οἱ δʼ ἐκαρτέρουν πρὸς κῦμα λακτίζοντες

children.label: II

Mem. 1.6.7; τὸν τῶν ὑπεροπτικῶν ὄγκον Isoc. 1.30; πολλὴν κακοπάθειαν Arist. Pol. 1278b27:— Pass., κεκαρτέρηται τἀμά my time for patience is over, E. Hipp. 1457.--In Hsch., οὐ καρτεριάδδει· οὐ φρόνιμος εἶ, should prob. be οὐ καρτερίδδει ( Lacon. for καρτερίζει).

data.quote: τὰ δʼ ἀδύναθʼ ἡμῖν καρτερεῖν οὐ ῥᾴδιον

children.definition: act of endurance, Pl. Men. 88c (pl.).
bearing patiently, patience, Pl. La. 193d: in pl., Id. Lg. 637b.
patient endurance of a thing, αἱ τοῦ χειμῶνος κ. Id. Smp. 220a; αἱ κ. τῶν ἀλγηδόνων Id. Lg. 633b.

patient endurance, perseverance, opp. μαλακία, X. Cyr. 8.8.15, cf. Pl. La. 192b, al.; κ. ἡ περὶ τοὺς πόνους D.H. 2.28; distd. from ἐγκράτεια (self-control), Arist. EN 1150b1: pl., εἴ πού τινες . . κ. πρὸς ἅπαντα . . λέγονται Pl. R. 390d.

data.quote: εἴ πού τινες . . κ. πρὸς ἅπαντα . . λέγονται

thundering mightily, Pi. Fr. 155.

strong-hearted, of heroes, Od. 21.25, Il. 13.350; Μυσοί 14.512; [ Ζεύς], Ἔρις, Hes. Th. 476, 225: generally, strong, mighty, ἄνεμοι ib. 378.
striking fiercely, D.S. 5.34 (v.l. -πλῆγες, nom. pl.).

strong, staunch, φάλαγγες Il. 5.592; καὶ εἰ μάλα κ. ἐστιν [Hector] 13.316; Ἡρακλῆς ὁ κ. Ar. Ra. 464: c. inf., κ. ἐστι μάχῃ ἔνι φῶτας ἐναίρειν Il. 13.483; πολέμῳ ἔνι κ. ἐσσι 9.53; Ζεὺς Τυφῶ -ώτερος μάχῃ A. Th. 517; τὰ καρτερώτατα the strongest, S. Aj. 669.

mighty, potent, ὅρκος Il. 19.108; κ. ἔργα deeds of might, 5.872; κ. ἕλκος severe, 16.517; κ. μάχη strongly contested, sharp, severe, Hdt. 1.76, Th. 4.43; ναυμαχίη Hdt. 8.12; ἀγών Plb. 1.27.11; ἀλαλά, μέριμναι, Pi. I. 7(6).10, 8(7).13; λίθος Id. O. 1.58, E. Fr. 1044; κτύπος A. Pr. 923; -ώτατον βέλος Pi. O. 1.112; τὸ κ. force, violence, A. Supp. 612; but τόλμης εἶμι πρὸς τὸ κ. the utmost verge of . . , E. Med. 394; κατὰ τὸ κ. in Adv. sense, Hdt. 1.212, 3.65, Ar. Ach. 622, etc.; πρὸς τὸ κ. A. Pr. 214: abs., τὸ κ. Theoc. 1.41.
strong, Hdt. 9.9, Th. 4.3; τὸ -ώτατον τοῦ χωρίου Id. 5.10; λόφος κ. Id. 4.131.
fixed, determined, τοῦτο κ. εἶναι SIG 45.22 (Halic., V B.C.).

garment, Juba Hist.85.

nut-bearing tree of various kinds, S. Fr. 759 (pl.), LXX Ca. 6.10(11), Plu. QConv. 2.647b, etc.; esp. hazel, Corylus Avellana, Thphr. HP 1.12.1, 3.2.3; κ. Περσική walnut, Juglans regia, ib. 3.6.2, 3.14.4; κ. Εὐβοϊκή sweet chestnut, Castanea vesca, ib. 5.4.2; κ. Ἡρακλεωτική filbert, variety of Corylus Avellana, ib. 1.3.3; -ῶτις ib. 3.3.8; cf. κάρυον.

ear-rings, Poll. 5.97.

nuts ( Lacon.), Hsch.

of nuts, ἔλαιον Gal. 11.871; κ. χρῶμα nut-brown, Thphr. Sens. 78; cf. καρόϊνος.

meddling, Hsch. (pl.).

Men. 462.7, Sor. 1.51, Alciphr. 3.53; ἐς ταὐτὸν κ. make up into one sauce, Men. 518.7: metaph., κ. λόγον season a story well, Plu. Adul. 2.55a; [ ἡ ἱστορία] κ. τὰς ἀπαγγελίας τῇ ποικιλίᾳ τῶν παραδειγμάτων Agath. Praef.

rich sauce, invented by the Lydians, composed of blood and spices, Pherecr. 181, Ath. 12.516c, Gal. 8.568, Max.Tyr. 3.9, Luc. Tim. 54: in pl., Ath. 4.160b, Plu. QConv. 2.664a. (Freq. written καρύκκη in codd. (as also in derivs.), and this spelling is preferred by Hdn.Gr. 1.317.)
of the colour of καρύκη, dark-red, X. Cyr. 8.3.3.

maker of a καρύκη, Achae. 12.

walnut-tree, Gloss.

nut, Ar. V. 58, Pl. 1056, Theoc. 9.21; κάρυα, = ἀκρόδρυα, Ath. 2.52a (but τὰ κ. ἢ . . τὰ ἀκρόδρυα Thphr. Char. 11.4); κ. πλατέα, i.e. filberts, X. An. 5.4.29; esp. of walnuts, Batr. 31, Epich. 150, Philyll. 25, Gal. 6.609; but this is prop. κ. βασιλικόν, Thphr. CP 4.2.1, Agatharch. 96, PCair.Zen. 13.6 (iii B. C.), Dsc. 1.125; or Περσικόν ibid.; κ. Εὐβοϊκόν sweet chestnut, Thphr. HP 1.11.3, 4.5.4; also κασταναϊκόν ib. 4.8.11, Agatharch. 43; κ. Ἡρακλεωτικόν filbert, Thphr. CP 4.2.1, IG 2(2).1013.19; also κ. Ποντικόν PCair.Zen. 12.48 (iii B. C.), Dsc. 1.125, Ruf. ap. Orib. 8.47.20; κ. πικρά almonds, Archig. ap. Gal. 12.409, Erot. s.v. νίωπον; so κ. alone, LXX Nu. 17.8, Ph. 2.162.
nut-shaped boss as ornament, OGI 214.49 ( Branchidae, iii B. C.).

καρυχρω (sic cod.) · καρυοβαροῦς, Hsch. (fort. καρυκοχροῦς (gen. of *κᾰρῡκοχρής) · καρυοβαφοῦς).

date, Dsc. 1.109.

dry, parched, ὡς ἄνεμος ἠΐων θημῶνα τινάξῃ καρφαλέων Od. 5.369; δέρμα Hp. Aph. 5.71, Prog. 2, Gal. 10.674; ἀστάχυες, ἄρουρα, AP 9.384.14, Orph. L. 269; κ. δίψει AP 9.272 (Bianor), 7.536 ( Alc.); of sound, καρφαλέον δέ οἱ ἀσπὶς . . ἄϋσεν the shield rang dry, i.e. sharply, Il. 13.40

rake for collecting fallen ears of corn, Hsch.
ripe fruit or (as Sch.) chips, κέδρου Nic. Al. 118.
of dry straw, εὐναῖαι καρφηραί nests, E. Ion 172:—misquoted as καρφυραί, Hsch.; cf. καρπυραί.
= Lat. carpineus, Apollod. Poliorc. 176.5.

definition: καρφίον, τό, Dim. of κάρφος, Dsc. 4.102, Ruf. ap. Orib. 8.47.20.

gleaning, CIG 2700e ( Mylasa).
built of κάρφη (pl.): θάλαμος κ., of a swallowʼs nest, AP 10.4 ( Marc. Arg.).
like dry sticks, κλῶνες, κλωνία, Dsc. 4.42, Gp. 2.6.29.

any small dry body, esp. dry stalk, as of the dry sticks of cinnamon, Hdt. 3.111; of rice-straw, Polyaen. 4.3.32, cf. Luc. Herm. 33: generally, in pl., dry twigs, chips, straws, bits of wool, such as birds make their nests of, Ar. Av. 643, Sophr. 32, Arist. HA 612b23, AP 10.14 ( Agath.): collectively in sg., A. Fr. 24, Arist. HA 560b8, Ath. 5.187c: in sg., chip of wood, Ar. V. 249; toothpick, Alciphr. 1.22: prov., κινοῦσα μηδὲ κ. ‘not stirring an inch’, Ar. Lys. 474, cf. Herod. 3.67; οὐδὲ κ. ἐβλάβη Epigr.Gr. 980.9 ( Philae); ἀπὸ τῆς κύλικος κάρφος τῷ μικρῷ δακτύλῳ ἀφαιρετεῖν Ion Hist.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: = Lat. festuca, Plu. Vind. 2.550b.

children.label: III
children.definition: a small piece of wood on which the watchword was written, Plb. 6.36.3.

children.label: IV
children.definition: ripe fruit, Nic. Al. 230, 491, Th. 893, 941.

children.label: V
children.definition: Dsc. 2.102. ( σκάρφος is v.l. (perh.right) in A. l.c., Plb. l.c.: perh. cogn. with Engl. sharp.)
AP 7.385 ( Phil., Pass.).

children.label: II
children.definition: nail, Sch. Ar. Ra. 844 ( Pass.).
Id. κάρφυροι· νεοσσοί, Id.; cf. καρφηρός.

dry up, wither, κάρψω μὲν χρόα καλόν will wither the fair skin, wrinkle it, Od. 13.398, cf. 430; ἠέλιος χρόα κάρφει Hes. Op. 575:—and in Pass., [ χρὼς] κάρφεται ἤδη Archil. 100; πυρὶ καρφόμενα Euph. 50; περὶ χροῒ καρφομένη θρίξ Nic. Th. 328.
ἀγήνορα κάρφει Ζεύς Zeus withers the proud of heart, Hes. Op. 7; κάματοι κάρφοντες γυῖα Nic. Al. 383:— Pass., οἴτῳ κάρφεσθαι A.R. 4.1094; v. κάρφος.
full of κάρφη, of uncleansed wool, Gloss.
rough, δίψῃ καρχαλέοι rough in the throat with thirst, Il. 21.541 (v.l. καρφαλέοι), cf. A.R. 4.1442, Nonn. D. 14.426.

children.label: II
children.definition: rough, fierce, κύνες A.R. 3.1058; λύκοι Tryph. 615 (v.l. καρχαρέος); of sounds, χρεμετισμός, ἱμάσθλη, Nonn. D. 29.199, 48.307; of fire, fierce, Nic. Th. 691 (v.l. καρφαλέος, q.v.). (Redupl. of khar-, cf. Skt. khára- ‘rough, sharp’.)
EM 493.1; cf.foreg. II.
shark, so called from its saw-like teeth, Pl.Com. 173.13, Mnesim. 4.36 (anap.), Thphr. HP 4.7.2, Numen. ap. Ath. 7.327a: metaph., ἁ γαστὴρ ὑμέων κ. Sophr. 46.

with saw-like teeth, καρχαρόδοντε δύω κύνε Il. 10.360; κυνῶν ὕπο κ. 13.198; ἅρπην κ. Hes. Th. 180; applied to Cleon, Ar. Eq. 1017, V. 1031; καρχαρόδοντα . . ὅσα ἐπαλλάττει τοὺς ὀδόντας τοὺς ὀξεῖς Arist. HA 501a18; opp. χαυλιόδους, Id. PA 661b19; of the lobsterʼs claws, Id. HA 526a19.

data.quote: καρχαρόδοντα . . ὅσα ἐπαλλάττει τοὺς ὀδόντας τοὺς ὀξεῖς

children.definition: = foreg., λύκος Theoc. 24.87.

definition: κάρχαρος, ον, and α, ον Alcm. 140:—

children.definition: saw-like, jagged, so with saw-like jagged teeth, κύων Lyc. 34, Luc. Luct. 4, cf. Ael. NA 16.18; στόμα Opp. C. 3.142; ἕρκος Id. H. 1.506; ὀδόντες Philostr. Im. 2.18; δῆγμα Luc. Trag. 302; κάρχαρον μειδήσας, of the wolf, Babr. 94.6.

harsh, of sounds or language, καρχάραισι φωναῖς Alcm. l.c., cf. Luc. Hist.Conscr. 43; ῥήτωρ Id. Merc.Cond. 35; nickname of Thrason, Bato Sinop. 3; rough, rude, [ ἤθη] κ. καὶ σκολιά Plu. Tranq. 2.468c.
side with the Carthaginians, Plu. Marc. 20.
Carthage, Hdt. 3.19, S. Fr. 602:— Adj. Καρχηδόνιος, α, ον, Carthaginian, Hdt. l.c., etc.; Καρχηδονιακός, ή, όν, κόλπος Str. 17.3.13.

drinking-cup narrower in the middle than at the top and bottom, Sapph. 51.3, Pherecyd. 13J., Cratin. 38, Herodor. 16J., S. Fr. 660, Callix. 3, IG 1(2).265, al., 22.47, 12 (8).51.25 ( Imbros, ii B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: mast-head of a ship, through which the halyards worked, ζυγὸν καρχασίου sailyard, Pi. N. 5.51, cf. Hp. Art. 43, Luc. Merc.Cond. 1 (interpol.), Asclep. Myrl. ap. Ath. 11.474f: in pl., E. Hec. 1261, Plu. Them. 12; cf. sq. [καρχήσιος]--In Epicr. 10 there is a play on the double meaning (I and II).

children.label: III
children.definition: triangular instrument used in carpentry, Hsch.

children.label: IV
children.definition: cage or chamber in a torsion-engine, Ph. Bel. 74.15, Hero Bel. 88.5 ( χαλκ- codd.), Ath.Mech. 35.4.

children.label: V
children.definition: crane for unloading ships, Vitr. 10.2.10, 10.16.3.
halyards of a ship, Gal. 19.109.
cords used in surgical operations, Id. 18(1).351, 522.
caraway, Dsc. 3.57, Orib. 3.2.3: perh. to be read in Ath. 9.371e.
drowsy, heavy, ὄμματα Hp. Epid. 7.30; τὸ καρῶδες, = κάρωσις, Id. Prorrh. 1.63; τὰ καρώδεα fits of stupor, ib. 103, cf. Coac. 523.

children.label: II
children.definition: causing stupor, Id. Art. 31; soporific, Aret. CA 2.1. Adv. -δῶς Gal. 14.4, Alex.Trall. Febr. 7.

definition: Καρώνιος, ὁ (sc. μήν), name of month at Cnossus, prob. in SIG 712.21 (ii B. C.).

children.definition: heaviness in the head, drowsiness, νωθρὴ κ. Hp. Art. 31, cf. Philonid. ap. Ath. 15.675b, Aët. 9.31.
carotid arteries, Aret. SA 2.11, Gal. UP 16.12: derived fr. καρόω by Ruf. Onom. 210: sg., τὴν καρωτὶν (sic) ἀρτηρίαν Antyll. (?) ap. Orib. 45.17.6.
stupefying, soporific, κ. ὁ κρίθινος Arist. Fr. 106, cf. Dsc. 4.64; κ. φάρμακα Gal. 10.817; δυνάμεις, ἐπιβροχαί, Id. 11.711, 14.733, cf. Porph. Abst. 1.27.
carrot, dub. in Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 9.371e; but, = gleanings of grapes, PLond. 1821.202.
skin, Hsch.

definition: κἀς, crasis for καὶ εἰς, or καὶ ἐς, Ar. Ach. 184, etc.

behave like a strumpet, Hermipp.Com. 71.
κ. τοὺς στρατηγούς abuse them in strumpet fashion, Ar. Eq. 355.
strumpet, Ar. Ec. 1106, Fr. 478; cf. κασαύρα, κασωρίς.
Ar. Eq. 1285 (ap. Sch.).
Hsch. κασᾶς, v. κασῆς. κασαύρα and κασαυράς, ἡ, = κασαλβάς, Id.
brothel, Hsch. (pl.), prob. for κασαυρίοισι in Ar. Eq. 1285; cf. κασώριον.

definition: κάσεν ( indecl. ?), Lacon. for κάσις or κάσιος (v. κάσιοι), denotes relationship of a Spartan boy to the βουαγός ( ἀγελάρχης) of his class ( ἀγέλη): usu. c. dat., IG 5(1).60, al., but c. gen., ib. 298.
κασῆς, ὁ (on the accent v. Hdn.Gr. 1.63),

Cyr. 8.3.8; acc. dual κασᾶ ib. 8.3.7; acc. pl. κασᾶς ib. 8.3.6 ( καλέσας codd.), Agatharch. 20; nom. sg. κασῆς PTeb. 38.22 (ii B. C.); abbreviated in PLond. 2.402v5 (ii B.C.): written κασσ- by Poll. 7.68; cf. κάσσος, κασσοποιός. (Ethiopian word, Agatharch. l.c.; cf. Hebr. kāsāh ‘covered’.)

cassia, Cinnamomum iners, Sapph. 44.30 L.-P., Hdt. 2.86, 3.110, Thphr. HP 9.4.2, Od. 30, OGI 214.59 ( Branchidae, iii B.C.), etc.; λίβανον εὐώδεις τε φοίνικας κασίαν τε . . , τέρενα Συρίας σπέρματα Melanipp. 1, cf. Mnesim. 4.58. (Cf. Hebr. qēṣìāh, Assyr. kasia: sts. written κασσία, as in Dsc. 1.13, Str. 16.4.25, cf. κασσίζω.)

children.definition: sister, Il. 4.441, etc.; dual -τα A. Pers. 185: metaph., συκῆ ἀμπέλου κ. Hippon. 34, cf. 70A; λάγυνε, . . κ. νεκταρέης κύλικος AP 6.248 (Marc. Arg.):—Cypr. κασινήτα Gött.Nachr. 1914.95, and καἱνίτα (q.v.): Aeol. κασιγνήτα Sapph. Supp. 1.9 (prob.).
brotherly or sisterly, Eust. 775.2.

definition: κασίγνητος, ὁ, ( κάσις, γενέσθαι, cf. γνήσιος)

children.definition: brother, Od. 8.585, IG 9(1).867.6 (Corc., prob. vi B.C.), etc.; esp. of those born from the same mother, κ. καὶ ὄπατρον Il. 11.257: later as fem., sister, τώδε τὼ κασιγνήτω these two sisters, S. El. 977, cf. Ps.-Luc. Philopatr. 11: in more general sense, cousin, κ. τε ἔται τε Il. 16.456, cf. 15.545: Astrol., Gemini, Doroth. ap. Heph.Astr. 3.36.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., κασίγνητος, η, ον, brotherly, sisterly, κασίγνητον κάρα S. Ant. 899, 915, El. 1164, dub. l. in E. Or. 294; κασιγνήτοιο φόνοιο a brotherʼs murder, Il. 9.567. (Mostly poet.; also Aeol., Sapph. Supp. 1.2 (prob.), IG 12(2).526d19 ( Eresus), and Cypr., Inscr.Cypr. 135.3 H. ( Idalion): Thess. κατίγνειτος IG 9(2).894 ( Larissa).)
Dim. of Lat. cassis, helmet, Sammelb. 7247.25, al. (iii/iv A.D.).
eating cassia, of a worm, Hsch.
brothers or cousins belonging to the same ἀγέλη (q.v.) at Sparta, Hsch.
breathing of cassia, Antiph. 52.14.

definition: κάσις [ᾰ], ὁ, gen. κάσιος first in Orph. A. 1229; dat. pl. κασίεσσι Nic. Th. 345:—

children.definition: brother, A. Th. 674, etc.; voc. κάσι S. OC 1440: ἡ, sister, E. Hec. 361, Call. Aet. 3.1.23 [Fr. 75.23 Pf.]: metaph., λιγνύν, αἰόλην πυρὸς κ. A. Th. 494; κ. πηλοῦ . . κόνις Id. Ag. 495.
boat used by the inhabitants of Kasion, PCair.Zen. 289.7, al. (iii B.C.).

definition: κασκαλίζεται γαγγαλίζεται, Hsch. κάσκανα, τά, (κάς I) = κασσύματα, Id. κασκάνδιξ· ἡ γηθυλλίς, Id. (Redupl. and dissim. from σκάνδιξ.)

children.definition: little finger, Hsch. (cf. κακκόρ). κάσμορος· δύστηνος, Id.; cf. κάμμορος.
maker of thick garments, PPetr. 2p.108 (iii B.C.), Ostr. 1616, al. (ii B.C.):—also κασσοποιός (q.v.).
aor. subj. Pass. = κατασταλῶ, Sapph. 81; cf. κασπέλη· στορνύει, Hsch. (leg. κασπέλλει).
Lyc. 131: κασσαβάς, EM 493.28.

definition: Κασσιέπεια, ἡ, the constellation Cassiopea, Eudox. ap. Hipparch. 1.2.13.

children.definition: look, taste, or smell like cassia, Dsc. 1.14.
tinker, BGU 9 iv 22, 1087 iv 9 (iii A.D.).
the Cassiterides or tin-islands, prob. the Scilly Islands, Hdt. 3.115, cf. Str. 2.5.15 and 30, etc.
made of tin, ἐνῴδια IG 2(2).1388.78, cf. Arist. SE 164b24, Plu. Comm.not. 2.1075c.
Ptol. Tetr. 180.

tin (never in Od.), Il. 11.25, 23.503, SIG 247i 3 ( Delph., iv B.C.), etc.; ἐτήκετο κασσίτερος ὣς τέχνῃ ὕπʼ αἰζηῶν Hes. Th. 862, cf. Il. 18.474; χεῦμα κασσιτέροιο a plating of tin, 23.561; κ. πάνεφθος Hes. Sc. 208; κνημῖδας ἑανοῦ κ. Il. 18.613; δύο καττιτέρω two plates of tin, IG 2(2).204.23, cf. Hdt. 3.115. (Elamite word, cf. Bab. kassi-tira: hence Skt. kastīram.)

plate with tin, λέβης κεκασσιτερωμένος Dsc. 1.30.5.
Ostr. 1081, al. (ii B.C.).
thick garment, Hdn.Gr. 1.208, Hsch.

definition: κάσσυμα, Att. κάττ-, ατος, τό (cf. sq. [κασσύω]),

children.definition: anything stitched of leather, esp. sole of a shoe or sandal, Hp. Epid. 5.45, Ar. Ach. 301 (ubi v. Sch.), Eq. 315, 869, Crates Com. 29.4; of cork soles, Dsc. Eup. 2.30; ὑποδήσασθαι ἐχθρῶν παρʼ ἀνδρῶν καττύματα to put on shoes made by an enemy, Ar. V. 1160.

children.label: II
children.definition: patchings, botchings, of bad music, Plu. Mus. 2.1138b.
stitch, sew together like a shoemaker, Pl. Euthd. 294b; πέδιλα Nic. Fr. 85.6:— Med. (nisi leg. καττύομεν), Pherecr. 178.

children.label: II
children.definition: stitch up a plot, οἶδʼ ἐγὼ τὸ πρᾶγμα τοῦθʼ ὅθεν πάλαι καττύεται (says Cleon the tanner), I know the shop that this piece of leather comes from, Ar. Eq. 314; καττύειν διαβολάς Alciphr. 3.58.

definition: Κασταλία, Ion. -ιη, ἡ, the spring of the Muses on Mt. Parnassus, Hdt. 8.39, Pi. P. 1.39, etc.

children.definition: sweet chestnuts, Mnesith. ap. Ath. 2.54b, v.l. in Gal. 6.621, v.l. in Dsc. 1.106:—also κάστανοι, αἱ, Gal. Vict.Att. 10; καστανίαι ( οἱ or αἱ?) Dsc. l.c.; καστάναια, τά, IG 2(2).1013.19; καστάνεια, τά, Heracleon ap. Ath. 2.52b ( καστάν<ε>ιος as Adj., φλοιός v.l. in Dsc. Eup. 2.49); βάλανοι καστανικαί Gal. 6.777, 791; καστηνοῦ (gen. sg.) Nic. Al. 269.

chestnut-tree, Gp. 2.8.4:—also κάστανος, ἡ, Hsch. s.v. καρύαι; κάστανον, τό, Gp. 10.63.1; derived by the ancients from Καστανέα, a place in Asia Minor ( πόλις Μαγνησίας), EM 493.26 (cf. Καστανὶς αἶα Nic. Al. 271); but cf. Armen. kask: for κάρυον κασταναϊκόν,
chestnut-grove, Gp. 3.15.7.
castus) in pl., ascetic practices, Marin. Procl. 19.

of or belonging to Castor: τὸ Κ. μέλος a martial song, set to the flute, used in celebrating victories in the horse or chariot races, Pi. P. 2.69; ὁ Κ. ὕμνος Id. I. 1.16; also, of a battle-march, Plu. Lyc. 22, cf. 2.1140c, Phld. Vit. p.25 J.

children.label: II
children.definition: καστόρειος or καστόριος, α, ον, of the beaver, ὄρχεις Hsch. s.v. κάστωρ; αἷμα Dsc. 2.24:—esp. καστόρειον or καστόριον, τό, castor, secretion found in the body of the beaver, used in medicine, Anon.Lond. 37.51, POxy. 1088.27 (i A.D.), Plu. Adul. 2.55a, Sor. 2.29, Phlp. in GC 65.29, etc.
hounds, said to be first reared by Castor, AP 6.167 ( Agath.), cf. Poll. 5.39:—also καστόριαι κύνες X. Cyn. 3.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: sea-calves, seals, Opp. H. 1.398, Ael. NA 9.50.
to be like castor, τῇ ὀσμῇ Dsc. 2.8, 3.84; τῇ χρόᾳ Vett.Val. 2.23.

definition: καστορνῦσα, Ep. for καταστορνῦσα, v. καταστόρνυμι.

children.definition: beaver, Castor fiber, Hdt. 4.109, Arist. HA 594b31, Hierocl. p.17 A., Ael. NA 6.34.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hp. Mul. 2.157, Aret. CA 2.10.

definition: κασύας ὄρκυνος (Perg.), Hsch. κασύτας, ου, ὁ, prob.

fornicate, Lyc. 772.
brothel, cj. in Hippon. 74:—also κᾰσώρ-ιον, τό, Ar. Eq. 1285 ap. St.Byz. s.v. Κασώριον ( κασωρεῖον Hsch.); cf. κασαυρεῖον.
Lyc. 1385, St. Byz.
fornicator, St. Byz.
Hippon. 117, Antiph. 320.
thick, ἐσθῆτες, opp. στρεπταί, Diog.Oen. 10.

κατά [ κᾰτᾰ], poet. καταί acc. to A.D. Synt. 309.28, found in Compds., as καταιβάτης: Prep. with gen. or acc.:—

children.definition: down from, βῆ δὲ κατʼ Οὐλύμποιο καρήνων, κατʼ Ἰδαίων ὀρέων, βαλέειν κ. πέτρης, Il. 22.187, 16.677, Od. 14.399; κατʼ οὐρανοῦ εἰλήλουθας Il. 6.128; καθʼ ἵππων ἀΐξαντε ib. 232; δάκρυα . . κ. βλεφάρων χαμάδις ῥέε 17.438; ἵεις σαυτὸν κ. τοῦ τείχους Ar. V. 355; ἁλόμενοι κ. τῆς πέτρας X. An. 4.2.17; κ. τῶν πετρῶν ὦσαι Pl. Phdr. 229c; κ. κρημνῶν ῥιφέντες Id. Lg. 944a:— for κατʼ ἄκρης v. ἄκρα: Μοῖσα κ. στόματος χέε νέκταρ Theoc. 7.82 (but perh. in sense II.1).

children.label: II
children.definition: downward motion,

down upon or over, κ. χθονὸς ὄμματα πήξας Il. 3.217; of the dying, κατὰ . . ὀφθαλμῶν κέχυτʼ ἀχλύς a cloud settled upon the eyes, 5.696, cf. 20.321; τὸν δὲ κατʼ ὀφθαλμῶν . . νὺξ ἐκάλυψεν 13.580; φᾶρος κὰκ κεφαλῆς εἴρυσσε down over . . , Od. 8.85; [ κόπρος] κ. σπείους κέχυτο . . πολλή 9.330; ὕδωρ κ. χειρός, v. χείρ; μύρον κ. τῆς κεφαλῆς καταχέαντες Pl. R. 398a; νάρκη μου κ. τῆς χειρὸς καταχεῖται Ar. V. 713; κ. τῆς τραπέζης καταπάσας τέφραν Id. Nu. 177; ξαίνειν κ. τοῦ νώτου πολλὰς [ πληγάς] D. 19.197; ἐσκεδασμένοι κ. τῆς χώρας Plb. 1.17.10; οἱ κ. νώτου πονοῦντες Id. 3.19.7; ῥόπαλον ἤλασα κὰκ κεφαλῆς Theoc. 25.256; κ. κόρρης παίειν, = ἐπὶ κόρρης, Luc. Cat. 12, al.
